Hansard-Body.A: The Legislative Assembly met at 9.30 am.

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Speaker (Hon. John Mickel, Logan) read prayers and took the chair.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Energy and Water Utilities) (9.31 am): I rise on a matter of privilege. Yesterday during the debate on the Mines and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) the House was entertained by the member for Redlands, who gave a rather spirited defence of a Mr Karreman, the man who allowed his grandson to operate a 30-tonne piece of equipment. As reported in today’s Courier-Mail , the member for Redlands said that it was ‘payback’ after they had lost a recent legal battle to prevent a 10-year-old boy--
Mr SEENEY: Mr Speaker, I rise to a point of order.
Mr SPEAKER: I will hear the point of order, but we do have a matter of privilege.

Mr SEENEY: The minister had ample opportunity to reply to the comments of the member for Redlands yesterday in the debate. He chose not to enter into the debate. Therefore, I would submit that he has no right to offer a reply to those comments now as a matter of privilege. He had the chance yesterday.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! There is no point of order. I want to hear what the point of privilege is, so I will overrule the point of order. Minister, I would ask you to come to your point of privilege.

Mr ROBERTSON: What the member for Redlands failed to disclose at any stage during his contribution is that, according to the disclosure returns for the Electoral Commission of Queensland for the first half of 2010, two contributions from Karreman Quarries were made, firstly to--
Mr Hobbs: What does that have to do with the facts?
Mr ROBERTSON: Just wait for it, my friend.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Allow me to hear the point of privilege. Minister, I would ask you to do that and do it fairly rapidly.

Mr ROBERTSON: The first was for the Forward Brisbane Leadership, a fundraising arm of the LNP, and the second was to the Redlands SEC branch of $1,000. This is cash for comment. This is failure to disclose--
Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Mr ROBERTSON: --a financial contribution during a debate--
Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Mr ROBERTSON: --where you personally defended this person.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Resume your seat.
Mr ROBERTSON: It is outrageous.
Mr SPEAKER: Resume your seat!
Mr ROBERTSON: I refer it to the members’ ethics committee.
Mr SPEAKER: Resume your seat!
Mr ROBERTSON: I table those documents.

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: This is meant to be a matter of privilege. Put it to me in writing. Do not debate it. And when I am on my feet, resume your seat. I ask the minister, under standing order 269, to put that matter in writing to me. I will then determine whether it is a matter of privilege and what is to be done with it.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Alleged Deliberate Misleading of an Estimates Committee by a Minister

Hansard-Body.A: (Burdekin--LNP) (9.34 am): I rise on a matter of privilege. Last year I referred statements made by the Minister for Community Services during the estimates committee process to the Speaker for his consideration in forwarding the matter to the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee. During estimates the minister made a number of misleading statements concerning the Office for Women, one of which was the number of calls received by Women’s Infolink. Yesterday in this House the minister stood and apologised for that inaccuracy. However, by ignoring the other matters referred she compounded the gravity of the original misrepresentation of the status of the Women’s Infolink.

XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Speaker’s Ruling, Matter Previously Referred to Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Order! I say to the member for Burdekin that this matter is already before the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee. It is being determined there. This is a debate on a matter before the committee. Put it in writing to me. I will explain to the House why I allowed the minister to give an explanation yesterday.

It has always been my contention--and I have said this before--that I would rather have a minister correct the record as soon as practicable. I found out yesterday that that is what the minister wanted to do, even though the matter was before the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee, because it does not stop the matter being determined by that committee. However, there is an overriding principle that a member will correct the record in this House as soon as practicable. I am not going to entertain a debate on this matter. Put it in writing to the committee under standing order 269.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.37 am): Over the past few months Far North Queensland residents have suffered unthinkable trauma and widespread devastation as severe Tropical Cyclone Yasi invaded their communities, their lives and their homes. This morning many are continuing to face down nature at its worst as further heavy rainfall deals yet another cruel blow and again brings heartbreaking floodwaters to the region. This morning the people of towns such as Cardwell, who are still in shock and trying to put their lives back together in the wake of Yasi, are waking to ongoing floods that started to invade their homes yesterday. In fact, as the people of Cardwell wake to a new day they could be forgiven for thinking, ‘What’s next?’

XML.Hansard-Body: Today in Ingham six schools will be closed as rain continues to fall. Emergency Management Queensland and the Hinchinbrook Shire Council are maintaining a watching brief on rising river levels. Current predictions are that, thankfully, the Herbert River will not rise high enough to inundate homes. However, the situation could change dramatically as more rain is expected. Flooding in and around schools has prevented them from opening and cuts to the highway have prevented staff from arriving at work, so they are unable to operate today.

Over the past 24 hours Cardwell has received about 200 millimetres of rain. That has resulted in some of the homes that survived Yasi being inundated. Others which are still covered in tarpaulins after Yasi took away their roofs have sustained further water damage. It is fair to say that the thoughts of all members of the House are with our fellow Queenslanders in the far north, particularly in the communities of Ingham and Cardwell.

It is a timely reminder that, after our last three months of floods and cyclone devastation, our wet season is not over yet. While it is heartbreaking for them and for all of us, at the same time we hope that they can stay strong, keep their spirts up and get through this latest traumatic event.

I commend the Cassowary Coast Local Disaster Management Group and the local council for their foresight late yesterday to open an evacuation centre to assist those residents affected by the rains. I understand that at this stage no residents have had to avail themselves of the centre, but given that there are still floodwaters around town, they may need to. I congratulate them on that work.

A sandbagging machine was dispatched to the community yesterday. The state government departments are on standby to provide further support. We are hopeful that today a State Emergency Services team from Cairns will be able to make it across the highway and into Cardwell to provide support to local crews who have been working around the clock. As I said, they are all in our thoughts this morning.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.41 am): The Queensland tourism industry is one of the hardest hit by the recent natural disasters. Our state’s $9.2 billion tourism industry was already doing it tough, hit hard by the global financial crisis, and suffered further problems due to the high Australian dollar. However, the combined effect of the floods and Cyclone Yasi has really knocked it for six. That is why the state and federal governments have pledged a total of $12 million for a recovery package for this vital industry.

Last week the federal tourism minister Martin Ferguson and Queensland Minister for Tourism, Jan Jarratt, announced an additional $2 million package following the joint $10 million fund that we announced on 28 January. This additional $2 million package is designed to help operators get back on their feet and make their businesses more profitable. That money will go towards professional advice, new skills and greater awareness of emerging markets to boost this vital industry.

Today I am very pleased to advise that the work that has been undertaken on the $10 million package is now ready for announcement. I can advise that Nothing Beats Queensland is the message that will be promoted to Australia and the world as part of this $10 million global tourism strategy. The campaign will harness the unbeatable Queensland spirit to promote our state to locals, Australians and the world. Just as these disasters have not beaten us, we are out to tell the world that nothing beats Queensland. Nothing beats our beaches, nothing beats our rainforest, nothing beats our Great Barrier Reef and nothing beats a Queensland holiday just as nothing beats us Queenslanders.

The Nothing Beats Queensland--Where Australia Shines campaign will be one of the largest coordinated tourism marketing initiatives that Australia has ever seen. The campaign will target potential visitors and domestic and international media to come to Queensland and see for themselves that Queensland is open for business. The $10 million fund will comprise a number of initiatives including a $4.5 million interstate marketing campaign. This will include a range of competitive holiday packages. It will roll out by March in time for the peak Easter booking period. It also includes a $1 million intrastate--that is within Queensland--marketing campaign encouraging Queenslanders to support their mates by holidaying at home and incorporating a ‘Queensland pledge’ from the state’s tourism operators to tell the world that they are staging a comeback. This will start later this month. There will also be a number of very targeted marketing activities across a number of areas including international markets. We want the nation and the world to know that nothing beats the resilience of Queensland’s tourism industry despite everything that Mother Nature has thrown at us.

As I have stated, Tourism Queensland and Tourism Australia are about to embark on one of the largest coordinated campaigns in Australian history, incorporating a massive publicity, advertising and promotional blitz. This blitz will use activity such as television specials; major radio promotions; extensive newspaper and magazine coverage; sales campaigns in partnership with airlines, travel companies and major hotel chains; online promotions via Facebook and YouTube; and other creative initiatives. In short, over the next few weeks Queensland will be everywhere. Step 1 is to drive bookings for Easter and the school holidays in the interstate market. Step 2 is to encourage Queenslanders to get out there and support their mates by taking a holiday at home this year and step 3 will be to drive more bookings from international markets.

The gravity of our natural disasters attracted worldwide media attention. Now we want to blitz that very same media through TV, press, online and social networking channels to bring visitors back to beautiful Queensland so they can see for themselves just how fantastic our state now looks.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Australia and New Zealand, Royal Visit
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.44 am): Our push into these interstate and international markets will no doubt be given a boost by a decision announced this morning that Prince William will pay a visit to New Zealand and Australia on behalf of the Queen. Prince William will visit following invitations extended by the Prime Minister of New Zealand and the Prime Minister of Australia. The prince will visit those affected by recent disasters as well as meeting members of the emergency and other support services.

Prince William will first visit Christchurch on 17 and 18 March. He will attend a national memorial service on the Friday as well as undertake other engagements in the area. The prince will also visit Greymouth near the site of the recent mine disaster at the Pike River Mine. He will then arrive in Australia on Saturday, 19 March where over two days he will visit a number of areas and towns affected by the recent cyclone and flooding in Queensland before going to north-west Victoria to view the area recently affected by flooding. Prince William’s itinerary will be further confirmed by the palace and I will certainly be advising--
Mr SPEAKER: Order! There is too much audible conversation. This is a very important ministerial statement. It impacts on the state of Queensland. I would like to hear it.

Ms BLIGH: The precise details of Prince William’s itinerary will be made public when they are finalised. I do thank the prince for his decision to visit Australia. I hope that he sends the message back to his friends and colleagues in the UK that Queensland is open for business and that while he is here he has an opportunity to see that for himself.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.46 am): Reconstruction and recovery from these natural disasters is the Queensland government’s No. 1 priority for 2011. That is why I am pleased today to be able to announce that the National Partnership for Natural Disaster Reconstruction and Recovery between the state and federal governments has been signed. This agreement defines the roles and responsibilities of each level of government during the reconstruction. It is the overarching structure on which our respective contributions to the reconstruction effort are based. This agreement also means that the huge amounts of money needed to reconstruct our state can start to flow. It paves the way for the delivery of the $2 billion to Queensland from the federal government so that we can get infrastructure funding out of the door in the reconstruction of our state. It also paves the way for an advance payment of $400 million to local councils, as previously announced. The national partnership agreement also includes an additional upfront payment of $50 million from the Commonwealth to facilitate the recovery process in North Queensland following Cyclone Yasi.

We are determined to get on with the reconstruction of Queensland as quickly as possible, and this agreement gives us the framework that we need to do that. It also makes sure that the audit processes are in place to provide the highest levels of accountability and public confidence around the expenditure of reconstruction funds.

The national partnership recognises that there will be instances where infrastructure needs exist outside of the traditional NDRRA eligibility arrangements and it makes provisions for special principles in those circumstances. These principles of value for money, relative priority and cost-benefit analysis will be applied to the $315 million package that we have announced to help Queensland’s local councils repair water and sewerage utilities as well as transport infrastructure such as Brisbane’s ferry terminals. We are progressing the recovery and reconstruction, and the signing of the national partnership is a key step in that process.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.48 am): Honourable members are aware that few Queenslanders escaped the direct or indirect effects of our summer of disasters, with 92 per cent affected in some way. While we have already begun the enormous task of reconstructing our state, I have no doubt that Queenslanders have questions they would like to put to the government about the task ahead and about how we intend to undertake it.

XML.Hansard-Body: I am pleased to advise the House that the first people’s question time for 2011 will be held on Friday, 18 March and will be dedicated to the reconstruction of Queensland and what this means for people and their communities. Joining me on the panel will be the Treasurer and Minister for State Development and Trade, Andrew Fraser; Chair of the Queensland Reconstruction Authority, Major-General Mick Slater; Greg Hallam, Chief Executive Officer of the Local Government Association of Queensland; and Greg Goebel, the Executive Director of the Australian Red Cross. I have also invited a wide range of stakeholders who are critical to the reconstruction effort to participate. This includes construction firms; experts in planning, agriculture and tourism bodies; charities and support services; and environmental groups.

This is a chance for all Queenslanders to ask questions of me or any member of the panel about our processes in place to reconstruct and rebuild Queensland. As of now, Queenslanders can put their questions to me and the panel by going to the Queensland government website and following the people’s question time link. As with previous events of this nature, people can also submit their questions through the link and an independent moderator will choose questions for discussion and facilitate the session, which will be streamed live online from 10.30 am on 18 March from the State Library. We have an enormous task ahead of us. I look forward to hearing the questions and comments from Queenslanders across the state as we embark on that process.

Hansard-Body.A: (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Attorney-General, Minister for Local Government and Special Minister of State) (9.50 am): As we continue with the job of rebuilding Queensland, the Bligh government remains committed to planning for the future. As we rebuild the homes and lives of those Queenslanders devastated by the recent flooding and cyclone, we continue to plan for the homes of tomorrow’s residents.

XML.Hansard-Body: The Urban Land Development Authority has a busy year ahead. By the end of the year it is estimated that there will be more than 5,600 lots or dwellings approved for development across the ULDA’s 14 declared urban development areas. By mid next year, work will be underway on more than 30 projects within these UDAs, with a total end value of almost $3 billion. This means local jobs, improved housing affordability and well-planned, new communities that will take the pressure off our growth hot spots.

Less than 12 months ago the government tasked the ULDA with delivering major new satellite communities at Flagstone, Ripley Valley, Yarrabilba and Caloundra. Between them, these greenfield sites will eventually provide a place to live, work and play for more than 340,000 people. Since taking charge, the ULDA has moved these major development areas forward with the release late last year of interim land use plans for each of these four sites.

Today we reach the next major milestone in the delivery of these greenfield sites. I am pleased to inform the House that the ULDA has today approved the first development application for these new communities--a 126-lot residential development at Newbeith in the Greater Flagstone UDA. Land prices within the development will start from around the mid-$90,000 mark for a 225-square-metre terrace lot, increasing to around $130,000 for a villa lot and $190,000 for a traditional lot of over 800 square metres. House and land packages are expected to start from under $300,000, making the area affordable and attractive to a range of buyers.

The developer, MTAA, expects to begin construction in mid-April. By the end of the year, further lots are expected to be approved for Ripley, Yarrabilba and Caloundra South, and the final development schemes will be in place for each of these new communities. The ULDA continues to demonstrate that good planning can be completed quickly without compromising community consultation.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for State Development and Trade) (9.52 am): The distribution of GST money to the states always creates lively debate among state treasurers. And so it should: the GST makes up around a quarter of every state’s entire revenue base. Tinkering at the edges of payroll tax and stamp duty--so often the focus of many interest groups--pales in comparison to getting the distribution of the national GST pool right.

The Commonwealth Grants Commission is the independent body responsible for the GST carve-up, and recently it released its 2011 update report. Our allocation builds on our policy victory of 2010 which, for the first time, sees the Grants Commission recognise the infrastructure pressures of growth states like Queensland and Western Australia. The 2011 update includes several changes--and revealed a fundamental flaw.

The distribution reflects the challenges Queensland has faced from the lingering effects of the global financial crisis on the property industry in particular. Our allocation has increased from 18.6 per cent to 19 per cent of the total distribution. This is likely to lead to a slightly improved net position for Queensland in the 2011-12 allocations. However, this will not be confirmed until the release of the federal budget in May.

As members will recall, the percentage share is but one factor. What matters more is the size of the GST pool, which was forecast lower by around $5 billion late last year by the Australian Treasury. One thing that has not changed is the grossly unfair nature of the mining assessment--in other words, how states like Queensland and Western Australia are penalised for having wealth-producing mining sectors.

Queensland remains a donor state. As one of the stronger, prosperous states of the federation we acknowledge our obligations--that is, Queensland will contribute $1.2 billion to the national pool. However, we do not see our role as propping up the likes of New South Wales and Victoria.

Next year around 90 per cent of the net redistribution from Queensland’s revenue assessment will be due to mining, which makes up less than 10 per cent of government revenues. The fact that Victoria and New South Wales earn far greater revenue from their higher stamp duty and payroll tax regimes does not get a similar treatment from the Grants Commission. The end result is that next year every Queenslander will donate $154 to the national GST pool--$60 more than every New South Welshman.

In fact, the situation means that the Victorian Treasurer is the person with the highest stake in the success of the mining industries in Queensland and Western Australia. Given that Victorian taxpayers do not do a hell of a lot to fund the economic and social infrastructure to support mining industry expansions, the result is pure risk-free, free-riding profit for Victorians--at the expense of Queenslanders and Western Australians. It is a smash-and-grab job in proportions that most thieves would only dream of.

In my view, the resource states are being pillaged by the two big southern states--and it is being sanctioned by a Grants Commission methodology obsessed with royalties and almost ignorant of other states’ burdensome payroll tax and stamp duty regimes. I have already had discussions with the Liberal Treasurer from Western Australia, and it is a matter we intend to pursue with the Grants Commission

At present the Grants Commission proposes not to revisit this matter until their next five-year methodology review. Queensland and Western Australia should not and cannot abide another five years of this inequity. I implore those opposite--the great knockers of the Queensland economy--to rise above their negativity on this occasion, put aside the politics and enjoin this debate to support Queensland’s and Western Australia’s case.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Gallery of Modern Art, Surrealist Art Exhibition

Hansard-Body.A: (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Finance and the Arts) (9.56 am): The Pompidou Centre in Paris holds Europe’s most significant collection of surrealist art. Every surrealist master has their work there--Salvador Dali, Picasso, Joan Miro, Max Ernst, Man Ray. This is not a collection loaned often, nor easily. I therefore have great pleasure in announcing that the Pompidou Centre and our very own Gallery of Modern Art are bringing this incredible collection of more than 180 artworks by 56 artists here to Brisbane this winter.

XML.Hansard-Body: It has been a tough 2011 to date, with GoMA suffering quite significant flood damage, but this exhibition shows defiantly that Queensland is well and truly open for business after the cyclones and floods. GoMA will be the only Australian venue for the exhibition, which is right now enjoying enormous popularity at Tokyo’s National Art Centre.

The show is Surrealism: The Poetry of Dreams and it will attract hundreds of thousands of visitors here from across Queensland, Australia and, no doubt, the Asia-Pacific. Like previous GoMA blockbusters that have won national and international acclaim-- Andy Warhol , Picasso and his collection and Valentino Retrospective --this exhibition will also bring a significant injection into the local economy. Valentino alone attracted more than 200,000 visitors and generated an economic benefit to Queensland of $18.4 million--and that was in just over three months.

The Bligh government’s vision is now our daily reality. Before our investment in GoMA, 300,000 people a year visited the Queensland Art Gallery. Last year there were more than 1.8 million visitors--more, I note, than to Suncorp Stadium. We imagined that Brisbane could be a world-class centre for the arts, and it is.

Surrealism: The Poetry of Dreams traces the history of surrealism, and this will be the first major survey of surrealist art in Australia since 1993. Accompanying the exhibition will be an extensive film schedule, a children’s art program, music performances and talks. I congratulate the Queensland Art Gallery, GoMA and Events Queensland on this latest outstanding achievement, and I invite Queenslanders to pencil in Surrealism: The Poetry of Dreams as a must-see event from 11 June to 2 October this year.

Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Employment, Skills and Mining)
(9.59 am): Many residents of Far North Queensland have had their lives torn apart by Cyclone Yasi. The state government wants to provide whatever assistance it can to help them rebuild. That is why residents in some of the hardest hit areas like Tully, Cardwell and Mission Beach are being given access to free TAFE courses. The practical training is being offered at the Innisfail and Tully campuses of the Tropical North Queensland Institute of TAFE.

The free construction and building courses include courses in bobcat, front-end loader, backhoe and crane operation, truck licences, chainsaw operation, construction white cards, traffic control and food hygiene. So far, 149 people have taken advantage of the scheme in Tully, undertaking traffic control, white card and chainsaw courses. Another 48 people are registered in courses that would normally cost between $50 for a chainsaw ticket and $800 for bobcat or backhoe licences. This means local workers can take part in the local recovery effort and gain important employment skills, experience and qualifications. We have recognised the immediate need to run these practical courses to enable these residents to physically rebuild their lives and to rebuild safely. That is why the free training courses are running over half and full days.

The free TAFE courses offered in Far North Queensland are in addition to other great work being carried out to help Queensland recover. At the same time as offering assistance to communities, we are getting on with the very important business of making sure skilled workers are available to take advantage of employment opportunities being created across Queensland.

At the weekend, the state government announced a joint $83 million jobs and skills package with the Commonwealth government to help disaster affected communities. The package includes help to provide more than 1,500 placements through the Green Army; support 2,500 apprentices or trainees to continue their training; provide training to ensure there are enough people ready to enter apprenticeships and traineeships once the economy picks up; and 30 jobs skill development officers across the state to work closely with local governments, organisations and businesses to coordinate skills training and provide job opportunities for Queenslanders in the recovery areas. The measures the Bligh government is putting in place to help Queenslanders now will help create jobs and skilled workers well into the future.

Hansard-Body.A: (Yeerongpilly--ALP) (Minister for Government Services, Building Industry and Information and Communication Technology) (10.01 am): The summer floods which devastated Queensland did not just wash away homes, farms and businesses; they also damaged some real Queensland icons. Many of us are aware that the iconic Suncorp Stadium was swamped by floodwaters and remember its triumphant return as a major sporting venue when the Queensland Roar stormed into the A-League final in February.

XML.Hansard-Body: But let us not forget our other cultural icons like the Queensland Tennis Centre at Tennyson, the cultural precinct at South Bank and the nearby Queensland Maritime Museum. When the floodwaters receded, QBuild workers were out in force at these iconic sites, leading the rebuilding effort.

The Queensland Tennis Centre is a great asset in my local community. It is hard to believe that just one week before the floods, the centre court was the focal point in the Brisbane international tournament. Seeing the images of the centre court submerged under 3 metres of water just days later was heartbreaking.

But, amid this devastation, we did not lose our determination to rebuild. Our workers began the massive repair and rebuilding task at the centre on 17 January. They got on with the job of repairing flood damaged courts, electrical switchboards and air-conditioning units. They carried out repairs to the players’ changing rooms, stores and gymnasium and removed debris from the centre. I am pleased to say that today the centre court resembles something of its old self and the Queensland Tennis Centre is on track for a full recovery.

Department of Public Works staff also carried out remediation works on the Queensland Cultural Centre which was damaged during the floods. These workers helped restore essential power and services before completing the clean-up and initiating remedial works. These works are on track to be fully completed by early April. The Queensland Performing Arts Centre’s Lyric Theatre reopened for performances on 25 January following a two-week closure due to flood damage. Performances at the Concert Hall and Cremorne Theatre commenced shortly afterwards. The centre’s Playhouse Theatre remains closed after sustaining significant damage to its fire, air-conditioning and electrical systems, with works continuing to get the theatre up and running as soon as possible.

QBuild staff also helped with efforts to restore the Queensland Maritime Museum, which sustained damage in the floods. In addition to these high-profile icons, my department is also helping residents and local councils throughout the state recover from the floods and cyclones. We are getting on with the job of helping these communities rebuild. I want to assure all disaster affected communities that they can count on our full support.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: National Disability Insurance Scheme; Mental Health Services

Hansard-Body.A: (Mulgrave--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services, Mental Health and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (10.04 am): The first stand-alone ministry for mental health could not have come at a better time for Queenslanders as we come to grips with the tragedy upon tragedy that has marked the start of 2011. I have seen the mental anguish on people’s faces in the cyclone ravaged Cassowary Coast. For many people, mental trauma can be but a heartbeat away from mental illness. As a government, we need to reach out to people right now and wherever possible give them the support and services they need to turn their lives around.

XML.Hansard-Body: I commend the federal government for putting a national disability insurance scheme on the table. We welcome the Productivity Commissions’s draft report. This is an historic opportunity to bring about great change. I look forward to working with the federal Labor government so that together we get the best outcome for our community.

Ageing carers in particular need to know that when they are gone someone, somewhere will be able to look after their autistic son or daughter, their nephew, their niece, their friend. That is what the insurance scheme is all about. As the father of an almost two-year-old, I have had to use the phrases ‘inside voice’ and ‘listening ears’ a fair bit. In terms of our government’s response, I plan to establish a working group of key stakeholders and I will certainly be putting on my listening ears so that we get our response right, so that we can put Queensland’s case to Canberra and ensure people in our state get the best deal.

Gone are the days when governments simply locked the door and threw away the key. In a few months time, Queensland’s first forensic mental health service will be open for business--a purpose-built secure facility at Wacol. There has long been a need for non-hospital based secure care for people with a cognitive or intellectual disability who are on forensic orders. Apart from post-construction modifications, the centre should be up and running by midyear. Its chief focus will be to provide services, counselling, rehabilitation and the right kind of care to clients to help them turn their lives around.

My focus as minister will be to break down the barriers around mental health--to remove the stigma, to engage with the community, business and industry and to say ‘It’s okay to be different.’ Take the staff I met at WorkLink in Cairns. Their job is to encourage employers to take on someone with a mental illness. They know that when clients walk through their doors, it is because they want a hand up, not a handout. I commend Dorothy Dunne and her team for the work they are doing in the far north and I encourage others to follow their lead.
Everyone deserves a fair go. Everyone deserves a chance. Importantly, everyone deserves the chance to reach their potential.

Hansard-Body.A: (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Health) (10.07 am): The Bligh government is responsible for the single most significant public dental health initiative in our state’s history--fluoridation of Queensland’s drinking water supplies. The Queensland government’s public dental services are the most comprehensive in Australia. Our oral health budget per capita is Australia’s most generous, with the Queensland government spending equal to that of New South Wales. We invest the same budget for only half their population. More than 50 per cent of Queenslanders are eligible for free dental treatments from our clinics. Our clinics provide nearly two million treatments each year.

XML.Hansard-Body: By contrast, sadly, those opposite have no dental health policy whatsoever except to try to roll back water fluoridation through a referendum. Their only dental policy is to try to destroy the program that the Australian Dental Association described as ‘effective, efficient and equitable’. Make no mistake: this government’s commitment and record on public dental health services is better than any government in Australia. Not only do we lead the nation in providing dental services, we lead the nation in transparently reporting the performance of our dental services. We provide more dental services than any other state and we report our waiting lists more comprehensively than ever before. There has in the past 24 hours been some misinformation in the media on this issue.

In 2009, the government committed to publishing waiting list data half yearly. We have done so twice a year since that time. The data is on the Queensland Health website. It is published in exactly the format that was used when the commitment was given. We publish the number of patients treated, the number of children treated, the percentage of patients waiting for each category of treatment and the average wait times across our districts for each category of patient. What the data shows is that fewer than two per cent of patients waiting for appointments are categorised as urgent.

The government’s record on dental health is the best in the nation. By contrast, the Liberals and Nationals have a lot more work to do. If the opposition were even slightly serious about getting people into public dental clinics faster, they would have supported the federal Labor government’s bill in the Senate, which would have delivered $52.8 million in dental funding to Queensland over four years and provided 187,000 extra treatments. LNP senators, unfortunately, failed to step up for Queensland. They voted against that extra funding for dental services in the public arena in Queensland.

Those opposite have failed time and time again to lobby their federal LNP colleagues to support this vital funding for Queensland, showing they have no credibility when it comes to dental health. This government’s record shows that we are providing the most comprehensive public dental health service in the nation. We introduced fluoridation, the single most significant public dental health initiative in our state’s history. There is always more to do and we are happy to do it, but this is a record that everyone can be proud of.

Hansard-Body.A: (Algester--ALP) (Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women) (10.10 am): Rebuilding Queensland after Cyclone Yasi will be as much about structural recovery as emotional recovery. Our thoughts are now with the people of Cardwell as they once again struggle with serious flooding. I can inform the House that Department of Communities recovery staff have remained in Cardwell to assist residents through this period of flooding.

XML.Hansard-Body: I was in Innisfail, Tully and Mission Beach last week. Local people, including the members for Mulgrave and Hinchinbrook, councillors, the mayor, local businesspeople and residents, all told me the same story--that is, they want local people to settle back in the local area as quickly as possible to power up those local economies. That is why my department’s focus is on doing whatever it takes to house people locally. We have been using private accommodation, motels, factory-built housing and ensuited caravans.

Locals were thrilled last week to see the quality of that temporary housing organised by my department, and more is on the way. For Tully caravan park owners Peter and Angela, whom the member for Hinchinbrook would know well, the new housing is as much a lifeline for their business as it is a home for the tenants and residents in that local area. They are quality homes. I walked through two 4-bedroom family homes. They are very good quality housing. They have a large timber deck outdoor living area for those families, they have built-in cupboards; they are very comfortable houses. It is temporary and it is not their own home but people seem pretty happy with them.

In places like Tully and Mission Beach, where more than one in four properties have received serious damage, I was able to see firsthand the single units as well as the two-bedroom units and some of those four-bedroom residences that I mentioned. To date, 93 family groups have been housed in emergency accommodation at local motels, at resorts at Mission Beach that withstood the cyclones, such as Castaways and others, at apartments and at caravan parks.

I do understand, though, that the temporary arrangements that people have made with family and friends can put people under a lot of strain, and I have discussed this with the member for Hinchinbrook. If you are living with family and friends for a few weeks or a couple of months, sometimes those relationships can get a bit scratchy. We are aware of that and our departmental staff are doing a lot of outreach work. In fact, they have done about 4,000 outreach visits to families and individuals to make sure they are getting the financial and housing assistance they need. That has been a mighty effort. We have had great support from our colleagues from the Northern Territory, and I met some of them when I was in Tully last week as well.

In Tully and Tully Heads alone, 70 different forms of housing have been delivered or will be delivered within the next day or so, including 40 ensuited accommodation facilities and four ensuited caravans. This housing is supporting people like the two age pensioners from Hull Heads. The husband has some very serious health issues. We have housed them in an ensuited caravan near the hospital. Again, that is temporary; it is not home. They would be desperate to get back into the home they have lived in for 18 years in that area, but that is not possible at the moment.

While I am on my feet, I would like to pay tribute to the Red Cross, Lifeline and my departmental staff. We have had 3,000 staff deployed around the state and we have been moving them around as the disasters have moved around the state. They have done a mighty job, as have our non-government agencies as they have worked with my department, the emergency services staff and the police. It has been an incredible effort and I pay tribute to all of those people.

Hansard-Body.A: (Thuringowa--ALP) (Minister for Main Roads, Fisheries and Marine Infrastructure) (10.14 am): This government wants to do everything it can to reduce the impact of Fitzroy River flooding on the Bruce Highway. We are looking to the future, and that means doing what we can to flood proof our communities and safeguard the road network for the people of regional Queensland. Coming from regional Queensland, I know just how important the Bruce is. That is why I am pushing hard to get action after a federally funded study looked at cutting congestion in Rockhampton and boosting flood immunity on the highway.

XML.Hansard-Body: The study looked at current and future demand on the Bruce and the north coast rail line. After 18 months and over 180 submissions from the community and road users, we took three road options for the Bruce Highway and two rail corridor options for the north coast rail line to the community last week. Now we are asking for feedback. Two hundred locals turned up to have their say in Rockhampton and I want even more people to give their feedback by 1 April. I personally thank the member for Keppel, Mr Hoolihan, who also attended that session and who provided valuable feedback.

We want to choose the route and we want to get it right. The options will now undergo technical, engineering, environmental, cultural heritage, social, safety and community analysis. All the options have the potential to make significant improvements to traffic flow and to reduce the impact of flooding on the Bruce Highway through Rockhampton. I well remember in 1991, after another big flood event in Central Queensland, that the Bruce Highway south of Rockhampton was closed for 13 days on that Yeppen flood plain. That stopped essential medical and food supplies getting through not only to Rockhampton but also to points north.

Over 20 years there has been a lot of talk about upgrading the Bruce south of Rockhampton but, unfortunately, there has been very little action. We are working shoulder to shoulder with the federal government and we are taking action right now. We are taking steps to flood proof our communities and we are going to safeguard this vital highway for the people of regional Queensland.

Hansard-Body.A: (Whitsunday--ALP) (Minister for Tourism, Manufacturing and Small Business) (10.16 am): In just over 14 days as tourism minister I have seen more than $14.3 million worth of initiatives rolled out to support Queensland’s tourism industry. That is almost $1 million a day to support the recovery of our industry and its operators and small business owners. This includes the $10 million joint state and federal tourism marketing campaign discussed by the Premier this morning. In the wake of recent natural disasters, this campaign will promote the state to Queenslanders, Australians and the world. It will be one of the largest coordinated tourism marketing initiatives Australia has ever seen. It will call on Queenslanders to continue their flood and cyclone efforts by holidaying at home. It will ask travel, accommodation and service providers to turn their service levels up to 11 and provide random acts of upgrade. It will ensure that interstate and international visitors know that our beaches, islands and many other tourist attractions are unharmed and looking better than ever.

XML.Hansard-Body: The release of details of the $10 million marketing campaign follows the 3 March announcement of an additional $2 million in state and federal government tourism funding. This additional funding will back a raft of initiatives to help tourism operators grow and promote their businesses. It will inform, educate and help operators and small business owners help themselves.

In the last two weeks, I have announced additional tourism campaigns and initiatives worth more than $2.3 million. These include a European marketing blitz--valued at close to $1 million--that saw iconic Queensland images displayed on billboards in Munich and Berlin as their temperatures hit minus 12. It also includes a $945,000 campaign promoting affordable Queensland travel options interstate and a tropical North Queensland campaign valued at $530,000.

In my first two weeks as minister I have travelled the length of the state and met with small business owners in Cairns, in the Whitsundays and on the Gold and Sunshine coasts to hear their experiences firsthand. I have asked for their advice on how the state government can best assist an industry that last year generated $9.2 billion and supported 222,000 direct and indirect Queensland jobs.

It is an important industry and I understand that they need our help. The $14.3 million in recent announcements highlights the Bligh government’s commitment to working with the state’s tourism industry and promoting Queensland not only to the nation but also to the world.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Agriculture, Food and Regional Economies) (10.19 am): Today I am pleased to announce $2.35 million for Racing Queensland to repair flood and cyclone damaged racecourses and for country racing clubs to undertake work to meet health and safety standards. In excess of 30 racecourses across Queensland were affected by flooding and Cyclone Yasi, and I am pleased that my first announcement as the new minister responsible for racing is for funding to repair this damage. I want to acknowledge the former racing minister, the member for Southport, for his work in securing this funding for Racing Queensland. Some $1.45 million will be spent to undertake flood and cyclone remediation work on a number of key racecourses primarily at Rockhampton, Emerald, Warwick, Townsville, Cairns, Albion Park and Ipswich. This funding will assist by covering the shortfall from insurers for damaged clubs so that racing can get back to normal as soon as possible.

XML.Hansard-Body: As an example, the government will provide up to $235,000 at Rockhampton to resurrect the grass track and greyhound track, which were both under water for 10 days and covered in silt; $100,000 at the Emerald racetrack to fix the sand training track and repair the perimeter fencing and road infrastructure; and $150,000 at Warwick to resurrect the sand training track. In addition to the $1.45 million allocated for key racecourses, an additional $900,000 has been specifically allocated to assist country thoroughbred race clubs. Some $200,000 will be provided to address workplace health and safety related damage caused by the recent floods and Cyclone Yasi and $700,000 will be given to assist clubs in meeting the minimum venue and equipment standards required to ensure the health and safety of racing participants. Country racing is an integral part of community life in rural and regional Queensland. This funding will ensure racetracks and meetings are back up and running and local communities can enjoy a day out at the races. I also thank Racing Queensland for its leadership on this issue, ensuring facilities are returned to racing order as quickly as possible and enabling participants to remain in business.

Hansard-Body.A: (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Environment and Resource Management) (10.21 am): Today the federal House of Representatives standing committee inquiry into Indigenous economic development in Queensland and review of Tony Abbott’s wild rivers bill will be holding hearings in Brisbane. The Queensland government will be highlighting the significant investment we have made into creating new economic opportunities for traditional owners in Cape York, including skills development through the wild rivers program. In total we have 40 wild rivers positions and already some wild rivers rangers who have benefited from this training have moved on to employment in the mining sector, defence forces, Main Roads or other positions in the private and public sectors. It is also an opportunity to once again debunk the myths that Tony Abbott and others are spreading about wild rivers to the detriment of the economic development in Cape York. The government’s submission to the inquiry outlines 141 development approvals that have occurred in declared wild rivers areas. These approvals are for activities including mining exploration, mining, roads and other infrastructure, vegetation clearing, sewage treatment and other activities. In wild rivers areas grazing, fishing, tourism, camping, hunting and gathering can continue unaffected. Wild rivers does not stop development; it ensures sustainable development and will help avoid mistakes of the past.

XML.Hansard-Body: Today I am announcing a new package of actions that the Queensland government will undertake to work with Indigenous people on the cape. The next plank of our wild rivers agenda--sustainable cape communities developed in consultation with Indigenous representatives--is aimed at further increasing their involvement in wild rivers decision-making processes and the economic opportunities that follow. Under the sustainable cape communities initiative we will be establishing an economic development mentor support network where successful entrepreneurs will work with Indigenous communities to establish new businesses in wild rivers areas. We will also be building the capacity of Indigenous local governments to quickly and effectively progress development applications in these areas. We will also be initiating a strategic economic development plan to create real jobs in growing sectors that provide economic opportunities, capitalising on the cape’s outstanding natural values. The government is also committed to extending Indigenous water reserves from the cape wild rivers to the gulf wild rivers, the first such allocation in Australia. Further to our economic initiatives, we will also be establishing new Indigenous reference committees to provide direct feedback to me as the minister from those who speak for country in areas proposed as a new wild river. We want to work hand in hand with Indigenous people to ensure that our wild rivers declarations provide the right protections for our pristine waterways while also supporting the communities that live and work around them. Wild rivers is not a threat to development, but talking down the cape is.

While I am on my feet talking about wild rivers, I had the pleasure of going to the honourable member for Gregory’s electorate last week to meet with graziers, landowners and locals to discuss the Cooper Creek wild rivers declaration. Significant impacts have been experienced throughout the Cooper Creek Basin due to the summer flood events and people who have been busy coping with flooding issues have not had the time or opportunity to properly consider the wild rivers proposal declaration. Given the delays and the importance of informing stakeholders about the wild rivers declaration proposal, and taking into consideration the wishes and what I heard while I was out there on the ground in Longreach, today I announce an extension to the consultation period for the Cooper Creek Basin wild rivers declaration proposal to 30 June this year.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (10.25 am), by leave, without notice: I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That, not withstanding anything contained in the standing and sessional orders, at noon today I will move that the report of the Committee System Review Committee, titled Review of the Queensland parliamentary committee system , tabled on 15 December 2010, be noted.
XML.Hansard-Body: Motion agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Child Protection (Offender Reporting) and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
Child Protection (More Stringent Offender Reporting) Amendment Bill

Hansard-Body.A: (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (10.26 am), by leave, without notice: I move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (1) That, in accordance with standing order 129, the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) and Other Legislation Amendment Bill and the Child Protection (More Stringent Offender Reporting) Amendment Bill be treated as cognate bills for their remaining stages as follows:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) second reading debate, but with separate questions being put in regard to the second readings;
(b) the consideration of the bills in detail together; and
(c) separate questions being put for the third readings and long titles.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (2) That, notwithstanding anything contained in the standing and sessional orders:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) debate of the bills shall be considered during government business;
(b) the time limits and order for the reply to the second reading debate shall be: Leader of the Opposition (or nominee) in reply--30 minutes, followed by minister in reply--30 minutes; and
(c) that for this day’s sitting, government business shall take precedence after private members’ motions until the adjournment is moved.
XML.Hansard-Body: I wish to advise the House that both the government bill and the private member’s bill seek to amend the reporting requirements for offenders as outlined in the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act.

Mr Speaker, I note your ruling on 24 November 2010 in which you advised the House that the bills are in fact so similar in part that the same question rule would be enlivened for some sections of the bill. Therefore, I consider the most appropriate way of dealing with these bills is in the form of the cognate debate, which is why I am moving this motion today.
Motion agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Public Accounts and Public Works Committee
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr WENDT (Ipswich West--ALP) (10.27 am): I also lay upon the table of the House report No. 7 of the Public Accounts and Public Works Committee titled Inquiry to formally review the report of the 2010 strategic review of the Queensland Audit Office to consider the recommendations made and comment on other findings where appropriate . The 2010 strategic review of the Queensland Audit Office was completed and tabled in the parliament by the Premier in March 2010. Under the Auditor-General Act, the report is deemed to be referred to the committee. At the time the strategic review report was tabled, the committee was undertaking its own review of the Auditor-General’s performance management systems audit mandate. A number of recommendations in the review report addressed issues already being considered by the committee and we elected to consider those recommendations as part of that inquiry. The committee tabled its report in September 2010. This report addresses the remaining strategic review recommendations and also comments on conclusions where applicable.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Public Accounts and Public Works Committee: Report No. 7--Inquiry to formally review the report of the 2010 strategic review of the Queensland Audit Office to consider the recommendations made and comment on other findings where appropriate [ 4044 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: On behalf of the committee, I want to thank the Auditor-General and the staff of the QAO. The committee is proud of the achievements of all QAO staff and the professional and diligent manner in which they undertake their duties. The dedication and commitment of QAO staff is reflected in the predominantly positive strategic review report. Finally, I want to thank the strategic reviewers and other members of the committee and research team for their continuing hard work and dedication in ensuring that there is a thorough examination of all of the issues brought before the committee. I commend the report to the House.
Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP) (10.29 am): I give notice that I shall move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1) Condemns the incompetence of the former Minister for Mines and Energy in issuing an exploration permit over a closely settled area at Gowrie Junction near Toowoomba.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And calls on the newly appointed Minister to:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 2) Recognise the grave concern, the emotional turmoil and the negative impact on property prices the EP has caused across the local community and in Toowoomba area generally.

3) Immediately make whatever legislative change is necessary to revoke the exploration permit at Gowrie to remove any suggestion, no matter how remote, that a mine could ever be established in what is an entirely unsuitable area for mining.

4) Strictly enforce the provisions of section 147A of the Mineral Resources Act to ensure all of the exploration permits covering the Felton valley and other areas of Prime agricultural land are not renewed so that landholders and communities in the region can be given some security and can be freed from the threat of an inappropriate mining development in their area.

5) Ensure no more exploration permits or other mining authorities are issued and no existing permits or other mining authorities are renewed for the Darling Downs region until a statutory regional plan is established identifying appropriate land uses across the region and giving statutory legal protection for prime agricultural land and establishing statutory separation distances between all resource industry authorities and urban areas.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (10.30 am): He is starting to sound like an Independent! I give notice that I will move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House notes that:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1) The National Party of Western Australia used its balance of power to force the Liberal party to agree to a policy of Royalties for the Regions.
2) Royalties for the Regions ensured that a greater and fairer share of Mining Royalties was given back to regional and rural communities for investment in vital local projects and infrastructure.
3) A policy of Royalties for the Regions is urgently needed in Queensland to address the unfair imbalance in funds being spent between Brisbane’s south east corner and the rest of Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And calls on the Premier and Opposition Leader, to support a Policy of Royalties for the Regions, similar to the National Party of Western Australian model, in order to allow regional and rural Queensland to more fairly share in the wealth of our mining industry.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Leader of the House, I have two notices of motion.
Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (10.31 am): Mr Speaker, the government would like to support the opposition’s motion.
Mr SPEAKER: For discussion tonight?
Ms SPENCE: For discussion tonight. There is not that much goodwill!
Mr SPEAKER: I just needed to clarify that for the Hansard .

Mr SPEAKER: This morning parliament will be visited by the students and teachers of the Tamborine Mountain State High School in the electorate of Beaudesert and the North Arm State School in the electorate of Nicklin.
Mr Wellington: Hear, hear!
Mr SPEAKER: I just do them; I do not explain them. Question time will end at 11.32 am.

Mr LANGBROEK (10.33 am): My first question without notice is to the Premier. The Premier would be aware that the success of the royal commission into Dr Patel was only made possible because victims could appear at that inquiry. I ask: will the Premier explain why under her terms of reference for the royal commission into floods victims are being formally advised that they cannot appear and only people about whom adverse findings are likely to be made can appear?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for his question. It is absolutely imperative for the government, and I believe for the public of Queensland, that an independent inquiry be allowed to conduct its business into questions that are legitimate about our disasters and questions that, frankly, I want the answers to as much as any other Queenslander. I live in this city and my family lives in this city. Some of the questions in relation to the operation of Wivenhoe Dam are as critical to me and my family as they are to the broader public of Queensland. They are legitimate questions and I want them answered. I want them answered in time for us to be able to take on board any lessons out of this event that might assist in protecting people and their property further in any wet season that we might experience next January and February.

In relation to the allegations by the member that there are people seeking to provide submissions or speak to those submissions and being denied any opportunity to do so, I would invite him to provide me with information about that and I would be very happy to consider it. The member might recall that, in fact, I and the minister for communities have spoken in this House now about a program that we are funding to actually assist people to prepare submissions and provide them to the commission and to assist them in appearing before the commission. So it is certainly our intention to ensure that people are able to do that. In fact, it is not only our intention; we are funding a program that will assist people and enable them to do that.
I go to the terms of reference, which basically require the commission to--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Take into account the regional and geographic differences across affected communities
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: and to--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Seek public submissions and hold public hearings in affected communities.
XML.Hansard-Body: So if there is some misunderstanding or concern on the part of anybody who has contacted the Leader of the Opposition, I would be very happy to not only take up their concerns but also ensure that they are provided with information about how they could get assistance to appear before the commission.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question without notice is also to the Premier. In the last session of parliament the Premier was asked on two occasions whether she would publicly release for Queenslanders the actual cabinet minutes from the meeting held on 18 October 2010 when the Premier and ministers were briefed by the Bureau of Meteorology. Those minutes have still not been made public. I ask the Premier for a third time: will she now put those cabinet minutes into the public domain so that Queenslanders can see the government decisions that were taken as a result of the briefing or will the Premier be keeping those minutes hidden?

Ms BLIGH: As part of our right to information reforms put in place I think two years ago now, which made Queensland and our government the most transparent in Australia, we established a website. What that website does is provide cabinet decisions within months of them being made. I do not know whether that particular decision is yet on the website, but there is no reason it would not be if it is not. I would invite the member to peruse that website, which is publicly available, more often.
Mrs ATTWOOD: My question is to the Premier. Can the Premier update the House on the significant increases in the uptake of solar energy throughout Queensland?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. As the member for Mount Ommaney knows only too well, we have experienced unprecedented rain and it has wrought unprecedented havoc. Nevertheless, we are as determined as ever to make Queensland the solar state of Australia. We do not anticipate the rain that we saw in January to in any way diminish our reputation for great, high-quality sunshine.

Queenslanders are following and taking up solar at an unprecedented rate. They are doing the bright thing in towns and cities right across Queensland. I said last year that our aim was to create a virtual power station across the roofs of Queensland, with a 500 megawatt generating capacity target by 2015. Today, we are at 375 megawatts, with an astounding 63,000 solar PV systems on Queensland roofs. That figure compares to just 1,000 five years ago. So five years ago we had 1,000 solar panels; we now have 63,000. At this rate, we will reach the target next year--three years ahead of schedule.

All of that has happened because Queenslanders want to take up clean energy. But it has also happened because our government worked to make it possible. We worked to make it happen. We put in place a Solar Bonus Scheme, where people who are generating power from their own roofs can actually be paid for the excess that goes back into the grid and there are many Queenslanders who are now receiving the benefit of that. We also put in place a solar hot-water cash rebate so that homeowners could take up solar hot water and bring down their bills. We made it happen by giving an opportunity to sporting and community clubs to come on board and to join the solar revolution.

We have made the Gambling Community Benefit Fund available specifically to clubs that want to install this sort of equipment. I am pleased to advise that our clubs and community centres have jumped on board as well. In the first round we had 186 applications and 118 of those were approved, with more than $1 million going out the door in that very first quarterly round of the first identification of $10 million over three years. We anticipate that most normal size sporting clubs in the community could save around $415 a year on their power bills. That is money they can put straight back into the operation of their clubs. We all know that the little football clubs often do not operate on a very big margin, so if they can be part of this effort then it brings down their costs but it also means they are part of our virtual solar power station. On the roofs of Queensland, whether it is in our streets, our suburbs or our community centres, we are seeing Queenslanders doing the bright thing and I congratulate them.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Minister for Finance. After it was revealed that this Labor government failed to take out flood insurance, the Premier claimed that the government had shopped around for insurance in 2004 but found the cost to be too prohibitive. Will the minister give a commitment to publicly release for Queenslanders all tender documents or expressions of interest, along with any analysis that the Labor government claims it undertook for flood insurance, or will it also be hidden from Queenslanders?

Ms NOLAN: The Queensland government announced two weeks ago that it would now engage in a process to go to market to get a 2011 price on the full cost of reinsuring Queensland’s assets--all of our assets including roads, bridges, tunnels, schools, hospitals; the gamut of our assets--for the impacts of a full range of natural disasters, including flood. It is not, frankly, my intention to put into the public domain any commercial material which may influence the price which we are now seeking to get from the market.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable gentleman has asked the question. I am listening carefully to the answer and, as I can work it out, the minister is answering the question so let us hear the answer.

Ms NOLAN:
It has never been the case that other states have had the gamut of insurance that is now being spoken about in the national arena. Indeed, the Queensland Treasury’s investigations have revealed that Victoria is the only state that covers its roads and that other states have a whole range of different levels of insurance. For instance, South Australia, which Senator Xenaphon has widely spoken about in this national public debate, does not cover its roads; it covers only its bridges. I do not think any Queenslander would find it hard to imagine that the state with the most devastating history of natural disasters, the state that is the most prone to cyclones, for instance, and the state that has, unlike Western Australia, by far the largest network of regional infrastructure, would not find it cheap to get this kind of insurance coverage. Indeed, I do not think anyone thinks that little councils in regional parts of Queensland should have to pay those kinds of insurance premiums. Why, if you live in Cardwell, should you be subject to a higher insurance premium as part of your day-to-day rates than a council in western Victoria, for instance?

It is a fundamental of being Australian that we help each other out in times of need. We will go to the market, we will get an informed price, but there has been a system for covering our assets under the NDRRA.

Mr WATT: My question is directed to the Premier. I know that the three soccer clubs in my electorate are excited about this Sunday’s A-League grand final featuring the mighty Brisbane Roar, who have had a record-breaking year.
Mr SPEAKER: Come to your question.
Mr WATT: Can the Premier update the House on another award for Suncorp Stadium, the venue for the grand final?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for Everton for his enthusiasm for ‘the beautiful game’, which we will see on centre stage at Suncorp on Sunday night. I am very pleased to advise the House that Suncorp Stadium has received yet another accolade as a great spectator venue. Professional Footballers Australia voted Suncorp Stadium the best pitch in the A-League for the second year in a row. This is a great achievement, particularly given the floods that so badly affected Suncorp Stadium. I really do take my hat off to the grounds team and the stadium staff. They pulled out all stops to make sure they could get it operational as quickly as possible.

I want also to acknowledge the efforts of the A-League players who have raised $70,000 for the Premier’s Disaster Relief Fund. I very much thank them for their efforts. This Sunday we will see the Roar out there on centre stage in the grand final. The Roar will be versing the Central Coast Mariners in the A-League final. I understand that ticket sales are continuing to be very strong. They are expecting a crowd in the 40,000s but I hope that a late surge will see a full house and a house decked out in orange.

This has been a record year for the Roar. They have been undefeated for 27 games. Members can see the Minister for Energy and Water Utilities proudly wearing the tie. He has been there for many of those games. To acknowledge the accomplishment of this team, this is a record for the longest unbeaten streak in a major national football competition in any code--league, union or Aussie rules. The previous record I understand was set more than 50 years ago by Geelong in the VFL. They went undefeated for 26 matches in 1952-53. It really does stand out as a remarkable sporting accomplishment. I hope that it will be matched by a win on Sunday night.

What the Roar are hoping to do on Sunday night is break with routine and travel to Suncorp Stadium by bus. They may, in fact, do a State of Origin style bus trip down Caxton Street. They deserve to revel in the moment. It is not only a record-breaking streak; the last time a football decider was held in Brisbane was in 1997, when the Brisbane Strikers defeated Sydney United. Now it is the Roar’s turn.

Having just celebrated International Women’s Day, I want to note that the Brisbane Roar women’s team won the final last week against Sydney Football Club 2-1 to claim their second title in three seasons. We hope that the men’s team can emulate their success on Sunday night. We should all be very proud of what is being achieved in the A-League by Queensland’s team, the Roar. I also note that the Gold Coast team came very close as well. It is important that we support all of our codes and I look forward to them doing well on Sunday night.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Minister for Energy and Water Utilities. Good news just in, Minister. At last night’s Brisbane City Council meeting bipartisan support between the LNP and Labor councillors ensured a motion was unanimously passed. The motion read--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This council calls on the state government to immediately cap wholesale bulk water prices in line with CPI.
XML.Hansard-Body: In the spirit of bipartisanship, will you now implement this joint call from the LNP and your Labor council colleagues to help relieve the cost of living on struggling Queensland families or, Minister, will you continue to play politics with people’s lives?
Mr SPEAKER: You will direct your comments through the chair. Rephrase the second part of your question or I will sit you down.

Mr NICHOLLS: Will the minister now implement this joint call from LNP and Labor councillors to help relieve the cost of living on struggling Queensland families or is the minister instead going to play politics with people’s lives?
Mr SPEAKER: Thank you for conforming.

Mr ROBERTSON: I think a far better thing for the Brisbane City Council to do is back our lord mayoral candidate’s policy of providing a rebate from the profits that Brisbane City Council will receive from Queensland Urban Utilities. There is a fundamental difference here: you have asked the question--
Opposition members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! Minister, resume your seat. Member for Clayfield, you have asked the question in a certain spirit and the minister is answering it in the same spirit. Therefore, I would ask that you desist and allow the minister to answer the question. Minister, you will stay relevant to the question that was asked.

Mr ROBERTSON: As I was saying, the best thing that the Lord Mayor of Brisbane can do is follow his counterpart in the Moreton Bay Regional Council and provide a rebate from the profits that the Brisbane City Council will earn from the sale of water to ratepayers.

Let this difference be understood: this year alone, $407 million of subsidy is provided by the Queensland government. That is $407 million that we do not get back in terms of the sale of bulk water to councils. Unlike the Queensland government, which subsidises $407 million to the ratepayers of South-East Queensland, in addition to the $100 rebate that we provide to pensioners and in addition to the downward pressure that we have put on water prices, the Brisbane City Council and other councils like that of my good friend the Mayor of the Gold Coast refuse to provide satisfactory rebates from the profits that they earn.

From memory, I think the Brisbane City Council will earn a profit of about $195 million this year. It is around that figure. That is the profit that the Brisbane City Council will take out of the back pockets and the wallets of hardworking ratepayers in Brisbane. The best thing that the Lord Mayor of Brisbane can do is to use the profit that he receives and give it back to the ratepayers of Brisbane through rebates. That is the policy that Ray Smith, our Labor candidate and next lord mayor of Brisbane, has already announced. In the spirit of bipartisanship, perhaps the Lord Mayor can join with him in offering exactly the same rebate. That is the best way that those profits can be returned to the good people of Brisbane.
I will say this: each and every day, up to the next council elections, when it comes to hands in the back pockets of ratepayers there is no-one better than the Lord Mayor of Brisbane.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The House will come to order. The matter is completed.

Ms CROFT: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Attorney-General, Minister for Local Government and Special Minister of State. As the Deputy Premier knows, I have a strong working relationship with the Animal Welfare League in my electorate and the RSPCA of Queensland. I ask the Deputy Premier to update the House on the implementation of the Animal Management (Cats and Dogs) Act.

Mr LUCAS: I am more than happy to assist the honourable member with her inquiry. On 1 July 2009, new uniform state-wide requirements commenced for the management of declared dangerous dogs. In fact, the honourable member and the House might like to know that since the commencement of the act 1,773 dogs have been entered on the register, including 114 restricted dogs, 1,447 dangerous dogs and 212 menacing dogs.

However, one attack dog that you will not find on that register is the Leader of the Opposition. Yesterday members may have heard the Leader of the Opposition’s MPI speech or read it subsequently, at page 341 of Hansard . I do exhort everyone to read it. Certainly, it is worthwhile reading it or watching the video link that Mr Speaker had. The Leader of the Opposition reached new heights of wackiness. He was not unlike a Surfers Paradise attack poodle. Traditionally, the Tuesday MPI speech is a leader of the opposition’s set piece for the week. It is his or her opportunity to set the agenda and to guide the team by providing leadership and by delivering an inspirational speech.

In my 15 years in this place I have never heard such a rant. In fact, one of the media outlets said that, upon hearing the speech, his colleagues were cringing. It was a tirade that had water, it had Wivenhoe, it had fantasies about factions, it had ‘Big’ Bill Ludwig, it had zombies. The only thing he missed was tiger blood and the international conspiracy. It was like a Charlie Sheen conspiracy.

We know that the Leader of the Opposition is under pressure, but surely no-one in his office wrote that speech. Surely no-one there would have written that, unless they were trying to get at him. Surely the Leader of the Opposition did not write it himself, because he does not do angry very well at all. It is not in his character to do it and when he does it it does not come off. I can only conclude one thing about his contribution. There is only one person who could have written it; there is only one person who could have supplied it. He has outsourced it to the member for Burnett.

Mr SEENEY: My question without notice is to the Premier.
