Four years ago, on 10 March 2007, the Premier, then as Treasurer, promised that ‘water is an essential service and I will not see it priced beyond the ordinary reach of Queenslanders’. On the fourth anniversary of that pledge, would the Premier agree with struggling Queensland families that yet another promise has been broken by a dishonest Labor government?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. I stand by the efforts that our government has made consistently to ensure that the increased costs associated with building a water grid put the water needs of South-East Queensland, one of the fastest growing areas of Australia, beyond doubt and beyond drought. We have seen those efforts--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr Seeney interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable the Premier was asked a question. I am listening for the answer. The Premier is answering the question that was asked. Therefore, I would ask that those on my left cease interjecting.
Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. The water grid was a very big investment in the future of the fastest growing region of Australia. That investment--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr Seeney interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left. That is the second time for the member for Callide.
Ms BLIGH: Of course, that investment has to be paid for as investments in water have always been paid for. However--
Ms Simpson interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The member for Maroochydore will cease interjecting. The honourable the Premier has the call.

Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. However, we took the view that it was an unreasonable imposition on ratepayers and on consumers to bear the full brunt of that repayment in one or two upfront increases. What did we do? We put in place a price path. We gave a 10-year price path. There were no secrets about it. We said, ‘This is going to cost us all a little more and here is what it will cost.’
Opposition members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left. I could understand it if the Premier was making no effort to answer the question. Under the standing orders, the Premier is answering the question. I would ask those on my left to cease interjecting.

Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. We could never have foreseen the intention of some local councils to do little more than price-gouge with the new water arrangements. On the average bill for water and sewerage, state charges account for 25 per cent. The other 75 per cent is being driven by local councils. Some of those local councils, like the Gold Coast, are increasing their costs by 23 per cent. This is unreasonable. I have indicated--
Mr Horan interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Toowoomba South will cease interjecting.
Mr Robertson interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The minister will cease interjecting.
Ms BLIGH: I have indicated that the government will consider curbing the profiteering of councils on water and that is precisely what we are doing.

Ms MALE: My question without notice is to the Treasurer and Minister for State Development and Trade. Would the Treasurer please inform the House of any initiatives from the Bligh government focused on diversifying our economy and supporting Queensland innovation?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Pine Rivers for her question and for her support of businesses in her electorate so vital to producing jobs for the people of Pine Rivers. Today I can announce that the Bligh government is providing a further round of funding under the Proof of Concept Fund. Four new projects totalling $186,000 will be funded under this round, including a new project for a southside Brisbane company looking at thermal panel manufacture to take house design to the next level--to an eight-star standard--as well as another company looking at a new test for metabolic diseases that potentially has worldwide application in the detection of metabolic diseases. This is our commitment to providing the funds to support businesses, to support new innovation, to prove up concepts, to commercialise new products and to create the jobs of tomorrow. That has been our clear economic agenda. That has been our policy in action. It stands in contrast to the base politics being practised on the other side of the chamber.

Of course, as the deputy has already alluded to, what we saw yesterday was a bizarre contribution from the Leader of the Opposition. It did not belong in this sandstone building; it belonged next door at the university. It was a student politics speech that could only have been written by the bovver boys up in the opposition leader’s office. The point, however, is that he was likened to Charlie Sheen, and just like Charlie Sheen these days he is incapable of even delivering a scripted line without crumbling. The opposition leader is a man under pressure. How do we know he is under pressure? We need to look no further than the great transcript that the ‘pineapple’ has given us about a recent long chat with the Leader of the Opposition in which he admitted that there are divisions in the LNP, in which he admitted that he faced criticism over his leadership in recent months and in which he had a crack at the long-serving members on his own side. Is any of this ringing a bell for anybody who has watched Queensland politics for the last generation? Of course, the best part of that contribution was when the journalist put to the opposition leader that names like ‘Springborg’ and ‘Nicholls’ have a higher currency.
Mr SPEAKER: You will refer to the members by their correct titles.

Mr FRASER: Sure. To quote from the interview transcript, the opposition leader’s reply was, ‘They know Nicholls?’ What we do not know is whether he asked that in jest, in horror or in fear. Of course, we know that daily the shadow treasurer is counting up the numbers of a different sort. We know that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is doing the circle for the Yelarbon barn dance. We know that ‘Uncle Bruce’ has let him go and we know that the member for Gympie and the member for Indooroopilly have positioned themselves in the outside barriers ready for a run. What do we find in the last 12 months of the term? We find the same old manoeuvring, the same old divisions, the same old leadership tensions, the same lack of policy, the same policy-free zone which the LNP in this state has been in forever, and that is why they are unfit to proclaim.

Mr RICKUSS: My question is to the Deputy Premier. I refer the minister to the 2003 State Planning Policy 1/03, mitigating the adverse impacts of floods. The State Planning Policy requires a flood plain advisory committee to be established in each local government area to comprise elected, administrative and community members. Will the minister explain why not one of these committees has been formed in the eight years since the Labor government introduced the State Planning Policy in 2003 to improve safety during flooding?
Mr LUCAS: I am happy to validate the claim made by the honourable member and get back to him in relation to this matter. I will say this--
Mr Rickuss: I will table it.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Email correspondence, dated 8 March 2011, between the Parliamentary Library Inquiries, the Principal Policy Advisor, Policy and Legislative Reform, Department of Community Safety, and the Lockyer electorate office relating to membership of flood advisory committees [ 4045 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LUCAS: Fine. What I will say in relation to the State Planning Policy is that, generally and in the past, individual flood levels have been matters established by local councils. Off the top of my head, the State Planning Policy has a requirement that councils adopt a Q100 or higher policy. Some councils such as the Brisbane City Council have done that, one in excess of that and indeed they have had a recent review which they are revisting as well. I suspect that the royal commission will recommend that those matters be done on a more uniform basis and at an even higher level.

I note that a number of councils have done this quite extensively. Bundaberg, for example, undertook very accurate flood mapping in the old Bundaberg area. Similarly, I think Emerald invested fairly heavily in that sort of mapping, as did Mackay. A number of other councils have also done that. Frankly, I look forward to what the commission believes is probably best practice in each of those areas. If there are better ways for us to establish how we might undertake those planning initiatives then I am happy to hear about them. However, in the past not all councils have welcomed state planning initiatives. Not all councils have welcomed state government involvement in those planning matters. Indeed, people such as the member for Warrego have made it their life effort to have the state not take an interest in those sorts of matters.
Ms Bligh interjected.
Mr LUCAS: As the Premier indicated, the contemporary matters that might be dealt with later indicate that the opposition may have changed its view in that regard.

I say to the honourable member that I will revert back to him on that particular aspect. However, the State Planning Policy does set a flood height and individual councils have an ability to raise it. Some individual councils have and some have not. One thing we do know in Queensland is that not all floods are the same. One size does not always fit all. I am more than happy to hear of those deliberations from the royal commission.

Mr MOORHEAD: My question is to the Minister for Main Roads, Fisheries and Marine Infrastructure. Can the minister inform the House what steps the government is taking to protect swimmers from our most dangerous sharks?
Opposition members interjected.
Mr Robertson: The loan shark? He is over there.
Mr SPEAKER: Resume your seat. I will wait for the House to come to order. The minister was asked a question. I am waiting for the House to show him the courtesy.

Mr WALLACE: Thank you for your protection, Mr Speaker. Last week I was briefed about Queensland’s large shark tagging program, which is based at the Queensland Boating and Fisheries Patrol headquarters at Southport. The program is tracking some of the world’s most dangerous sharks as they move along our beaches. The member for Waterford and I had a conversation earlier about the incidence of bull sharks in the Logan River. So it is an important program.

The program will help improve bather safety by giving exact information about shark movements. Acoustic tags are fitted to the sharks’ dorsal fins and send a series of pings underwater. Each shark has a unique ping signature which can help experts follow them. We hope to tag about 150 sharks from two metres to four metres by the end of the project. The species being tagged include great whites, tigers, bull sharks and dusky whalers. They are some of the most dangerous species of sharks that we find along the Queensland coastline.

I have a suggestion, however. Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition should consider walking down to Southport and getting some of these tags. He would then be able to keep tags on the LNP sharks that are circling him at the moment to take his job. He will be able to identify the unique ping for each LNP man-eater and see when they are meeting in a pack. The most dangerous species he will come across is the ‘Clayfieldeous’, also known as the tiger shark. There is also the ‘Warregoeous’, or the fossil shark, the ‘Noosaeous’, also called the wobbegong, and then there is the ‘Toowoomba Southeous’. It looks fearsome but really is the dummy shark.

The Leader of the Opposition should really tag the nastiest shark of the lot, the ‘Bruce McIvoreous’, or the great white shark. It is circling at the moment. It smelt the blood in the water--the ‘Bruce McIvoreous’, or the great white--and it is ready to take him out.
A government member: The Clive Palmer.

Mr WALLACE: Or the ‘Clive Palmer’. That might be the basking shark. The Leader of the Opposition’s disastrous reshuffle of his shadow ministry and the insulting appointment of a junior shadow minister for flood recovery shows that the feeding frenzy is underway. The member for Surfers Paradise needs to put those tags on his LNP predators to know where they are, to keep track of them. The opposition leader is, unfortunately, an endangered species. He is out of his depth and the LNP predators are closing in for the kill.

Mr DEMPSEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Environment. Yesterday the Premier attempted to justify her silence on Labor’s carbon tax claiming, ‘These are things on which we will need to take advice from experts.’ Given that Queensland’s hand-picked so-called expert is the head of the Office of Climate Change, Mr Greg Withers, will the minister reveal what Mr Withers has advised in relation to Labor’s carbon tax?

Ms SPENCE: I rise to a point of order. Mr Speaker, I seek your ruling. Under the standing order names of persons, unless they are strictly necessary to render the question intelligible and can be authenticated, should not be part of a question.
Mr SPEAKER: I would agree with that.
Ms SPENCE: I think in this instance it was unnecessary.
Mr SPEAKER: Under the standing orders I have the discretion to ask you to rephrase your question.
Mr DEMPSEY: Thank you, Mr Speaker.
Mr SPEAKER: I would ask you to do that. I am not aware of any wrongdoing in relation to the public servant. I do not think it weakens your question if you rephrase it.

Mr DEMPSEY: I am happy to do it, Mr Speaker. Given Queensland’s hand-picked so-called expert is the head of the Office of Climate Change, will the minister reveal what the head of the Office of Climate Change has advised in relation to Labor’s carbon tax?
Government members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order!
The House will come to--

Ms JONES:
Mr Speaker--
Mr SPEAKER: Resume your seat. I will wait for the House to come to order. Those on my right were interjecting while the question was asked. The honourable the minister.

Ms JONES: I was going to start with the usual and thank the member for the question, but I think the question has shown the calibre of the honourable member opposite and his true interest in protecting the environment in Queensland. We know where you stand when it comes to protecting the environment in Queensland. Just look at your voting record.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The minister was asked a specific question. Under standing order 118, the answer has to be relevant to the question asked. I would ask the minister to be relevant.
Ms JONES: I am happy to do that. I just wanted to make reference to the tenor of the question. I thought it was worth putting on the record.
Mr Dempsey: So you haven’t spoken to your head of Climate Change?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Bundaberg has asked the question. I am waiting for the minister. The minister is answering the question and giving a preamble on the way to the answer.
Mr Schwarten interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Rockhampton will cease interjecting.
Ms JONES: As the Minister for Environment and Resource Management, I hold regular meetings with all of my senior executive staff. That includes, of course, the head of the Office of Climate Change.

Let me talk about--as we have done for some years now--the work that we are doing in regard to preparing Queensland for the threats of climate change. If the member had actually read any of the information that has been released by me in the last two years in regard to what we have done to set Queensland up to be in the best position possible for if and when any price on carbon is built into the Australian economy, he would know this. What we did was focus on the things that we can do to help businesses, to help farmers, to help ordinary Queenslanders adjust to any price. Instead of waiting for the bickering to be sorted out at the federal level, what we did was get ahead of the game and actually put in place new policies and new programs to help ordinary Queenslanders, ordinary businesses and farmers to prepare for that. So let us talk about that.

One of the most popular programs that we have put in place to ensure we are helping ordinary Queenslanders work with climate change is the ClimateSmart Home Service, which many members from the opposite side of parliament have written to me about, congratulating that service--although probably not the new shadow minister. We have also been working very closely with CSIRO and AgForce--this is work that we are doing out of the Office of Climate Change. We are the only state in Australia that has scientific experts based here in Queensland to look at the effects of climate change and how we can ensure farmers in Queensland can gain from that. What did we do? We released new research with CSIRO which shows how we can lock up carbon in our landscape and how we can build into any carbon tax or CPRS system a way for farmers to actually gain income from their land. That is the work we have been doing. That is the work the Office of Climate Change does. It is leading the world, as the Premier said. It has actually been used now in America. California, which has a very similar economy to ours, has looked at it.

I am very proud of the work that we have done at a state level and through the Office of Climate Change. We are leading the way, as Professor Garnaut recognised last week when he was in Brisbane announcing a new initiative to help the people those opposite are meant to represent--farmers in Queensland--to ensure they are not ripped off.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Cyclone Yasi, Restoration of Electricity Supply
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms JOHNSTONE: My question is to the Minister for Energy and Water Utilities. Can the minister please update the House on progress with electrical repair work following Tropical Cyclone Yasi, which left a path of destruction in North Queensland last month?

Mr ROBERTSON: I thank the honourable member for the question. Restoring power and other essential services to Queenslanders affected by natural disaster is a priority for this government. Ergon Energy, I am pleased to report, has now restored power to all customers affected by Tropical Cyclone Yasi where it is safe to do so. To reconnect more than 200,000 customers in three weeks is an amazing effort by Ergon crews and their comrades from the south-east corner and of course interstate. I applaud the 2,000 staff members involved. I also thank the community for their support and patience while the repair work was being done.

The Bligh government is committed to reconstructing Queensland and delivering on vital government services like electricity. The stark contrast with those opposite is that customers would still be in the dark, with a bigger electricity bill to pay if the LNP were in power. For years those opposite have been calling for the whole network to be put underground. Putting powerlines underground, as is LNP policy, is up to 15 times more expensive than the traditional overhead method. Faults to the network are harder to pinpoint underground. It could take months longer to repair than easily accessible overhead lines.

Treasury estimates that the cost of replacing Queensland’s existing overhead network with underground power would now be in excess of some $62 billion. Can you imagine how much electricity prices would have to increase to fund that? It just so happens that I can tell you, Mr Speaker. Based on the Queensland Competition Authority figures from September 2010, it equates to an extra $30,926 on the power bill of every household and business in Queensland. Let me say that again: $30,926 on each and every Queenslander’s power bill. The LNP want to not only bury powerlines but bury Queensland under crippling debt and higher electricity prices as a result.

Earlier in an answer to the member for Clayfield I mentioned--and I was going from memory--that the profit the Brisbane City Council would receive from Queensland Urban Utilities was $195 million or $198 million a year. I have now been informed that the accurate figure is indeed $129 million this year. It will be $171 million next year and $179 million the year after that. Based on the fact that there are about one million households in Brisbane, what the Lord Mayor could do this week is announce a $100 rebate for every household in Brisbane that would come out of that $129 million profit. That would still leave him with $29 million to put in his back pocket. But that is the profit that the Lord Mayor will pocket and not put back into rebates for the good people of Brisbane who are suffering higher water bills as a result of decisions by those councils that make up the shareholders of those distributor-retailers.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: My question without notice is to the Deputy Premier and Attorney-General, Minister for Local Government and Special Minister of State. The Gladstone Public Trustee office provides a wonderful service. However, residents have advised me that more and more of their requests for services are referred to Brisbane and that staff numbers in Gladstone have reduced. With the population in Gladstone expected to double in the next 15 years or so, will the minister review staffing and services in the Gladstone office to ensure services can grow with demand?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for her question. I am more than happy to look into the matter personally for her. As usual, the honourable member asks questions in good faith about issues and I will attempt to examine current staffing levels there.

I have to say in relation to the Public Trustee, or indeed the legal profession, that things have changed over time. When I was first an articled clerk we had a telex machine and someone had to know how to operate that. Then we went to fax machines and most people could operate those. Indeed, what we have sought to do in the legal profession is change over time how things might be done remotely.

The other thing I should say is that the Public Trustee performed a traditional role in communities, as did the clerk of the court, that has actually evolved over time. With the growth and extent of the legal profession in regional Queensland, the legal profession in many instances has been the organisation that has played a greater role. That is no bad thing necessarily if it is there ready, willing and able to do that. I do not think honourable members would quibble with the private sector providing those sorts of services if they can do them appropriately.

Having said that, the Public Trustee does have a very important role when it comes to independently managing, for example, estates. I know that people can get quite frustrated in an estate situation if they do not have the ability to talk to someone face to face so that they can have that relationship in terms of managing that estate. I understand the honourable member’s concerns in that regard.
These days the Public Trustee provides a service in relation to the preparation of wills, but so do many private solicitors as well.
A government member interjected.

Mr LUCAS: No, he is into writing his own epitaphs. As I said before, I am more than happy to look into the matter on behalf of the honourable member. When I am in Gladstone I am happy to visit the Public Trustee office to examine whether there are any particular issues that might assist or whether there are any particular technology issues that might assist as well.

Mr SHINE: My question is to the Minister for Employment, Skills and Mining. Could the minister please advise the House what measures are in place to protect landholders if permission for mining exploration has been issued over their land?

Mr HINCHLIFFE: I thank the member for Toowoomba North for his question. I know that it is an issue that is very important to him and to the people living in his local community. Almost immediately upon my becoming the minister for mining he contacted me to raise these concerns about mining exploration and specifically mining exploration in the Toowoomba region. He has been very active in encouraging people with questions about the process to register for deputations at the upcoming Toowoomba community cabinet. I look forward to seeing him there.
Mr SEENEY: I rise to a point of order, Mr Speaker.
Mr SPEAKER: Stop the clock.
Mr SEENEY: I do not want to curtail the minister’s answer because I am interested in hearing what he has to say, but I would remind him of the motion before the House.

Mr SPEAKER:
I have not got the wording of the motion in front of me but I would ask that the minister’s answer not infringe upon the discussion that will take place later this day. I call the honourable minister.

Mr HINCHLIFFE:
Understanding the rules of anticipation, I was about to note that I am mindful of the rules of anticipation given the notice of motion before the House.

I would like to reassure the member and his constituents that the Queensland government has implemented a suite of policy initiatives to help ensure the long-term future of Queensland’s mining and petroleum industries is balanced with and contributes to the economic viability of our local communities, the environment and the agricultural sector. Specifically, this government has very strong laws in place in relation to companies and individuals accessing private land to conduct advanced exploration activities. Legislation put in place last year makes it absolutely necessary that companies have agreed with landowners when it comes to conduct and compensation before advanced exploration activities begin.

Permission to explore in no way gives a company or an individual permission to mine. In short, permission to explore allows a company to find out what is in the ground, not to dig it out. Historically speaking, when permission to explore is granted it is rare that land is ever to be mined. Less than one per cent of land explored for mining has a mining lease placed over it. Even if exploration reveals that a commercially viable operation may be possible there are still a number of boxes that a company must tick before operations can start.

I am talking about assessing the project against legislation like the Environmental Protection Act, the Nature Conservation Act and the Vegetation Management Act, if it applies. The important thing is that there will be several chances for public input along the way and it may even require Commonwealth approval. Any mining application that does not uphold the strictest environmental standards will not go ahead.

The LNP must have a very short memory when it comes to some of the issues that it has been going on about. This has been the case for a very long time. We need to balance the needs of the mining industry, which brings benefits like jobs, with the needs of communities. That is why rigorous processes and strong laws are in place.

Mr McLINDON: My question without notice is to the Minister for Employment, Skills and Mining and relates to coal seam gas. Given the adviser to the federal government body which assesses and regulates industrial chemicals, Dr Mariann Lloyd-Smith, stated on Four Corners on 21 February 2011 that QGC’s environmental authority applications are ‘certainly not the Australian standard and as such are in breach of both the Queensland act and the national code for material safety’--and I table the transcript of the Four Corners program--will the government now reconsider its position and support The Queensland Party’s motion moved on 24 November 2010 and the member for Warrego’s e-petition on 24 November 2010--
Mr SPEAKER: Round up and ask your question.
Mr McLINDON: --calling for a moratorium on all future CSG activities?
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Extract, dated 21 February 2011, of Four Corners program transcript (pages 7 and 8) [ 4046 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr HINCHLIFFE: I thank the member for Beaudesert for his question. The Bligh government has put in place very strong laws to manage the development of the coal seam gas industry. We understand that there are some members of the community who are concerned. That is why we have held dozens of community forums on the ground to inform the community about their rights and what we are doing as a government to get the balance right.

I watched with great interest the Four Corners documentary a couple of weeks ago. I am certainly seeking more information and advice--and I know that some of my colleagues are too--about some of the things that were reported in that program. Getting to the nub of the truth of these matters is vitally important. That is what we will do.

It is important for people to understand that coal seam gas has been safely produced in Queensland for the domestic market since the 1990s. The expansion of this industry into the export markets brings enormous opportunities in terms of jobs and investment. But this cannot come at any cost.

I noted an editorial in the Courier-Mail yesterday about CSG. I could not agree more. If the projections are right this is the beginning of a new and prosperous era for the state, but we do need to get it right. That is what we are doing, as acknowledged by the member for Callide yesterday. He said in this House yesterday--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... commend the Labor government. I do not often commend the Labor government and I grit my teeth when I do. However, I commend the Labor government for acting decisively ...
XML.Hansard-Body: The problem is that sometimes nobody really knows where the LNP stands on some of these issues. While the member for Callide supports CSG and the resources industry when it is done properly, as we do, the member for Condamine is out there calling for moratoriums at times. Our priority is to strike the right balance between the needs of the community and the environment and industry and economic development for regional Queensland. This government is working hard to provide legislation and other assistance to achieve that outcome. We have a series of initiatives on record and we will do more to get the balance right.

Mrs SMITH: I am pleased to ask the first question of the Minister for Tourism, Manufacturing and Small Business. Tourism supports more than 222,000 direct and indirect jobs throughout the state and is the lifeblood of the Gold Coast. Could the minister inform the House what is being done to support operators in the wake of the global financial crisis and recent natural disasters?

Ms JARRATT: I thank the member for Burleigh for her question and for her acknowledgement of the importance of tourism to our state’s economy and say how delighted I was to spend some time with her and other Gold Coast members during my first week as minister. Tourism Australia has today released the latest international visitor numbers for Queensland. The figures show international tourist numbers to Queensland have increased for the first time in three years, with 1.4 million foreign holiday makers visiting the state in 2010.

International visitor numbers to Queensland rose roughly four per cent compared to 2009. Chinese tourist numbers increased to 23 per cent, making China Queensland’s fastest growing international market. The 188,000 Chinese visitors who travelled to Queensland in 2010 spent $338 million, a massive 18 per cent increase on 2009 spending levels.

The Tourism Australia statistics released today show that Queensland also enjoyed its best results from the Japanese market in five years. The number of Japanese tourists travelling to Queensland in 2010 increased by nine per cent to 223,000, with increased spending of one per cent to $375 million. Visitor numbers from Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand also increased.

However, there is no doubt that the lingering effects of the global financial crisis coupled with the strength of the Australian dollar have had an impact on our international markets. This is reflected in the fact that, while international travellers spent an extra 725,000 nights in Queensland, their overall spending decreased by three per cent. Visitation from key European markets, France and Germany, also decreased one and nine per cent respectively.

In the wake of the global financial crisis and recent natural disasters, the Bligh government is committed to supporting our important tourism operators and small businesses. That is why we have rolled out $14.3 million in just over 14 days. This commitment includes a $10 million state and federal marketing campaign to promote Queensland to Australia and the world. It also includes an additional $2 million in joint Commonwealth and state funding to help tourism operators tap into and benefit from growing markets, such as Chinese visitors. Our commitment to this important industry has never been stronger.

Mr CRIPPS: My question without notice is to the Minister for Government Services, Building Industry and Information and Communication Technology. The minister would now be aware that from Bundaberg to Badu none of the structures built through the federal government’s Building the Education Revolution program were built to category 5 cyclone standards. Will the new minister indicate if he shares the view of his predecessor that building cyclone rated shelters would amount to squandering public money?
Mr SPEAKER: The minister has two minutes to answer this question.

Mr FINN: I thank the honourable member for the question. I acknowledge that his area, which I was fortunate to visit recently, was severely hit by the biggest storm that we have seen hit the Queensland coast since the early 1900s. We do have a commitment to cyclone safety and the construction of cyclone evacuation centres throughout Queensland. In relation to the question of cyclone safety shelters, what we have learnt from this event is that we have a whole lot of new data about the impact of these severe storms on our coast on buildings constructed under the BER and buildings constructed as purpose-built shelters. We have seen a fairly good rate of stand-up to the storm that hit the coast.

It is important that we gather all of the data that we can from this event and determine how we best apply that to future cyclone safety. When I was in Tully Heads, there were researchers out on the ground measuring storm surge impacts, measuring the impacts of that cyclone and gathering a range of data to enable us to inform the future buildings and cyclone safety plans. The last cyclone of that size was in the early 19th century, and our data on those impacts is significantly old. What we have seen is a very good performance in Innisfail of the building structures that came following Cyclone Larry. We will be able to use that data as well to inform our future cyclone safety strategy.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The time for question time has ended.

Hansard-Body.A: (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (11.33 am): The Premier has told Queenslanders affected by the floods that they will be heard at the flood inquiry, yet today we have learnt that victims of the flood--in this case Rocklea business owners who have lost many millions of dollars in the Brisbane floods--are not being granted leave to appear and cross-examine witnesses at the flood inquiry. It would appear that the same fate awaits any person or group of people who may have been adversely affected. Victims of the floods are being denied the right to appear at the inquiry and ask legitimate questions of those people who made decisions that had major impacts on their families or their businesses.

XML.Hansard-Body: We have secret cabinet minutes, secret water releases and secret pages of dam manuals, and now victims of the floods are prevented from having leave to appear and cross-examine government officials. This is not the way the Patel inquiry operated. This is not the way the Victorian bushfire inquiry operated. Victims in Victoria were granted leave to appear. When I sought the reassurance of an extra term of reference for the commission of inquiry to investigate any other matter that the commissioner should seek information about, the Premier rejected that and said everything was on the table.

Queenslanders cannot have confidence in an inquiry where victims are silenced or restricted to only making written submissions. I will not have confidence in an inquiry that stifles the voices of victims. The Queensland flood inquiry should be focused on allowing a full, frank and unfettered examination of the events that led to the floods. I expressed my extreme disquiet and unease at the flood commission’s refusal to allow leave to appear to those who have been severely affected by these floods. This ridiculous situation needs to be rectified immediately and I urge the Premier to amend her terms of reference to guarantee victims a right to appear at the flood inquiry.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Mount Ommaney Electorate, Sport and Recreation Grants

Hansard-Body.A: (Mount Ommaney--ALP) (11.35 am): All members of this House were involved to some extent with the recent floods and devastation to communities in Queensland. There were many families who were displaced and are still trying to piece their lives back together, and the government is doing all that it can to restore people’s lives to some sense of normality, particularly where insurance companies have failed to measure up to their responsibilities. The Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport, the Hon. Phil Reeves, and I visited the Centenary Rowing Club, the Jindalee and Oxley bowls clubs, the Jindalee and McLeod golf clubs, the Jindalee Jags and the Centenary Little Athletics Club soon after the floodwaters receded. My office provided applications for grants under the Sport and Recreation Flood Fightback Plan, and only a few weeks later clubs were advised that they would be receiving funds to assist their recovery. The Corinda Pony Club and the Jindalee Swimming Club also received these grants.

XML.Hansard-Body: I am happy that the Lord Mayor is now also assisting some of these clubs with grants. However, I am appalled that the Centenary Stormers Soccer Club were advised that the upgrade of Atthows Park and their playing fields would be further delayed because they were not flood affected. This makes no sense because it means they cannot play their competitions on their home fields this year. Money was set aside for this project by council two years ago to be completed by June 2010, with 25 per cent of the funding by the state government to assist with the remediation works. Now the upgrade has been stopped by the BCC and players have to share other fields in Brisbane for the season. The cost of this delay is enormous to these clubs.

Isn’t the reason why funds are being provided to flood affected areas so that the players can get back on their fields? Yet the opposite is happening for the Centenary Stormers and the Western Districts Baseball Club because their grounds were not flood affected. They have families who were personally traumatised by the floods and they want some normality in their lives and in their children’s lives.

I urge the Lord Mayor to take a good look at this situation and reason it out. He is getting a lot of money from the state and federal governments for infrastructure rebuilding in flooded areas. He should not be robbing Peter to pay Paul, so to speak, when all clubs should be supported to keep kids active. I seek leave to table the BCC’s time line for the upgrade of Atthows Park, dated 4 December 2009.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 4 December 2009, from Murray Allan, Landfill Remediation Manager, Environmental Management, Brisbane City Council, to residents regarding remediation works in Atthows Park, Westcombe Street, Darra [ 4047 ].

Hansard-Body.A: (Maroochydore--LNP) (11.37 am): Gaffer tape and garden ties are holding together part of the Bribie Island Bridge. It is bizarre but true, and I table the evidence--photos of this completely unacceptable practice.

XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Photographs of repairs on the Bribie Island Bridge [ 4048 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Any Labor member or minister who tries to defend this as being acceptable has a question mark over their own competence. Gaffer tape and garden ties: this is shoddy, yet this is typical of the Labor Party’s maintenance programs for roads in this state. It is almost four months now since this bridge was damaged--well before the floods, well before the cyclones--yet the best the Bligh Labor government can do is to nip into the garden shed, take some gaffer tape, get some garden ties and bung it together and say that it is good enough. Well it is not good enough.

Mrs SULLIVAN: I rise to a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I find the comments by the member for Maroochydore unacceptable. This was a set-up. The member for Maroochydore was caught red-handed with her hands on the railing in an attempt to shake it. She was caught red-handed interfering with state government property. I ask her to withdraw her statements.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! Members, I am listening to the point of order. Could you keep your comments to yourself.
Ms SIMPSON: Mr Deputy Speaker, I would seek your protection but the comments are so bizarre that they deserve condemnation.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER : Order! Member for Maroochydore, I have a point of order raised. It is not a point of order. There is no personal reflection. I call the member for Maroochydore.
Ms SIMPSON: This is typical of this government--in denial, that it is good enough to go to the garden shed and get a bit of gaffer tape and then say that that is a maintenance program!
Mrs SULLIVAN: I rise to a point of order.
Ms SIMPSON: If the member feels offended by her government’s own maintenance program, that is who she should take the issue up with.
Mrs SULLIVAN: I rise to a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Please resume your seat, member for Maroochydore.
Mrs SULLIVAN: The temporary railing is a safety measure. It was put up by Main Roads. It did not--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: There is no point of order, member for Pumicestone. I call the member for Maroochydore.
Ms SIMPSON: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The member is in denial. She thinks gaffer tape and garden ties are acceptable. Well it is completely dangerous, and this has been going on since November.
Mrs SULLIVAN: I rise to a point of order.
Ms SIMPSON: She stands condemned by her own actions in defending her government’s maintenance program.
Mrs SULLIVAN: I take offence at the member suggesting in any way, shape or form that this temporary railing is dangerous. That is unacceptable and I ask her to withdraw it.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: There is no point of order, member for Pumicestone. I call the member for Maroochydore.

Ms SIMPSON: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. We are going to stand up for the constituents of Pumicestone, because the member is not. I visited this site with the candidate for Pumicestone, Lisa France. It is quite clear that it is dangerous. It is unacceptable to the community and it is unacceptable to us. How can the minister justify gaffer tape and garden ties? Clearly, the local member thinks it is okay. We do not, and we will fight for a better go. But this is just symptomatic of the wider maintenance practices of this government. The RACQ has found that Queensland’s National Highways are failing, with 89 per cent--

Ms DARLING (Sandgate--ALP) (11.41 am): Animal cruelty is a blight on society and perpetrators must be dealt a strong message and a stronger sentence that reflects our community’s abhorrence of such acts. I am proud to be sponsoring a petition organised by my constituent Gloria McClymont. The petition calls for much stricter laws governing the sentencing of culprits found guilty of cruelty to animals. So far Gloria has accumulated 4,883 signatures and is still collecting support. I completely understand this call for change. Who was not moved by the story of the joey koala whose small body was riddled with gun pellets? Who was not sickened by the story of a horse dragged along behind a car? When one compares such despicable acts with the huge effort put in to save pets and livestock during the recent natural disasters, it is difficult to comprehend the motivation behind such cruelty.

Research shows that people who are cruel to animals often go on to torment women and children in domestic violence situations. There is nothing domestic about violence. Every adult and child has the right to feel safe in their own home. Pets and wildlife should be the focus of our care, not our torment. It is time to shine a light on the dark practices of violence and intimidation, and that means strong punishment for offenders. I believe that the maximum sentences for animal cruelty must reflect the seriousness of the offence, and today I am supporting my petitioners 100 per cent and am calling for an increase in penalties and maximum sentences under the Animal Care and Protection Act. As it is, the act has significant penalties compared to equivalent legislation in other Australian states and territories and maximum penalties were increased in January 2009, with a maximum $100,000 fine or two years imprisonment for breach of cruelty. But it is not enough. I have discussed my concerns with Deputy Premier Paul Lucas and Minister Tim Mulherin and I look forward to working with my government to update these laws.

Mr McARDLE (Caloundra--LNP) (11.43 am): On 16 February I rose in this House to make a short contribution to the condolence motion. I made it clear that natural disasters have a psychological impact on the people who go through them and such impacts can vary from person to person, with short-, medium- or long-term effects. Stress, depression, anxiety and even post-traumatic stress disorder are possible outcomes and it is important that we assist those who are suffering to understand that help is available. There will be those who are close to the sufferers--indeed, their family and friends--who will be the first to notice traits or changes in behaviour that raise concerns of how they are coping in their time of emotional crisis. For society’s wellbeing, the return to work, the return to school and the return to an active life is important not just for the sufferer but for the family and as part of the economic recovery of this state.

Queensland, and in particular this government, must commence a public campaign across media outlets, print, radio, television, the web and the balance identifying telltale signs of mental health issues for a period of some two to three years, ensuring as best we can people can identify the early warning signs. In addition, it is important people understand help is available and, if a person believes their loved one is suffering from symptoms, contact telephone numbers and trained experts are advertised to assist with their recovery. In my opinion we cannot simply allow recovery to be solely related to roads, bricks and mortar. Important as they are, the mental stability and recovery of those suffering is equally important. Two bodies that may be considered in a partnership of this nature will be the AMAQ and the Royal College of Psychiatrists.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: North Queensland, Department of the Premier and Cabinet
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr O’BRIEN (Cook--ALP) (11.44 am): While the Premier was governing the state from Far North Queensland two weeks ago, it was great to be able to host her in the jewel of Queensland’s tourism crown, Port Douglas. Port Douglas and the Daintree area have been particularly hard hit by the global financial crisis and the aftermath of this summer of natural disasters, which have clearly scared off some potential visitors. This has occurred despite the fact that the region was largely--thankfully--unscathed by the ravages of Yasi. There is a real need to get the message out that places like Port Douglas and the Daintree are open for business, and the Premier has stepped up to the plate to achieve this end. While she was in the region she announced an additional $530,000 to attract people from the critical Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane markets to Far North Queensland. This comes on top of the $2 million announced afterwards of joint state and federal money to promote the state, which in itself comes on top of the $10 million, the details of which the new tourism minister announced this morning with the Nothing Beats Queensland campaign. Port Douglas is a special place.
Mr Wettenhall: That’s why you live there!

Mr O’BRIEN: It is why I live there. Its natural beauty and village feel make it a place people of all backgrounds--from backpackers to movie stars, from families to presidents--choose to visit. There is, however, a need to ensure Port Douglas keeps moving forward. Cairns Regional Council has prepared a master plan to revamp the waterfront area, and this has received widespread public support for what is being proposed. While the Premier was in Port Douglas she was able to announce $30,000 to assist the council to fast-track the approval process to build a lagoon, which is a central part of the waterfront revitalisation. Importantly, while at a luncheon organised by the Port Douglas Chamber of Commerce the Premier gave in-principle support to return any money raised from the possible freeholding of two waterfront leases into the waterfront project. I want to thank Port Douglas Chamber of Commerce President Ken Dobbs and his committee for hosting this event, which over 120 people attended. I table a copy of the Port Douglas and Mossman Gazette article which covered the Premier’s visit to the town.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Article, dated 3 March 2011, from the Port Douglas and Mossman Gazette titled ‘Bligh promises to give back marina millions’ [ 4049 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Dr FLEGG (Moggill--LNP) (11.46 am): I hope the new education minister will take note. Whilst his predecessor was out proclaiming Queensland’s approach to achieving value for money in its BER program has been successful, the final report of the BER--
Mr WILSON: Well, Mr Deputy Speaker, it has been successful.

Dr FLEGG: The final report of the BER implementation task force said that, of the $3 million spent at the Mount Crosby State School, the project fails the value for money assessment and in fact that federal government report scored this project zero out of 10 for value for money. People are sick and tired of the spin. They want results. The Mount Crosby State School has written to the new incoming minister, and I support its call that he reconsider this and allocate the funds to complete this project. One thing is for sure: the LNP will never deny local communities and schools a say in what happens with the projects that are built for them.

The new Minister for Education must reconsider this undersize, non-enclosed and inadequate hall. One of the largest state schools in Queensland with no adequate library and no hall at all has ended up with a half-built hall with no walls on two sides. It will not serve any purpose in a natural disaster in this community that has just recently been cut off by natural disaster. It will not serve any community purposes because it is not enclosed. It cannot be used for after-school care. It will stand forever as a monument to the folly and incompetence of those opposite in education. I call on the new minister to make good in this very large and rapidly growing state school and to allocate the funds necessary to at least complete the walls of an enclosed hall at the Mount Crosby State School.

Hansard-Body.A: (Redcliffe--ALP) (11.49 am): It was with great disbelief and great empathy that Queenslanders heard about the second devastating earthquake striking Christchurch. Its epicentre was in Lyttelton Harbour, over the hill from Sumner, the cosy seaside valley where I grew up. I watched the news in horror as rocks and hills crumbled, smashing homes, community buildings and roads. Along with the iconic cathedral in the city square, Shag Rock--one of two iconic Sumner Beach rock formations--is no more.

XML.Hansard-Body: Two weeks on, many homes only have electricity because of huge generators feeding power into the grid, portaloos still line the streets, the world-renowned artesian water still needs to be boiled and the aftershocks keep rocking the town, further damaging homes and nerves. It is with pride that, only a little after I was able to ensure that my sisters and their families were safe, Queensland’s specialist recovery teams were joining the New Zealand teams in the search for survivors in the rubble of the city centre. These brave Queenslanders were our hands stretching across the Tasman in support of our New Zealand cousins in their time of need.

Like many close friends and relations, we have our jokes and compete in the sporting arena but we are bound by ties of blood and culture. My heart goes out to all Cantabrians at this time of crisis, particularly to those who have lost their loved ones and to those who will be unable to live in their homes for some time to come. Living through two devastating earthquakes is difficult, but it takes even more courage and a sense of humour to endure the continuing tremors. I say to all Cantabrians: kia kaha. Stay strong. We in Queensland stand with you.

Hansard-Body.A: (Burdekin--LNP) (11.51 am): I call on the Minister for Fisheries, Mr Wallace, to heed the concerns of the coral finfish industry. Since Cyclone Yasi, reef line fishers in the Bowen area are very concerned about reduced catches, with one fisher put out to sea returning with one coral trout for the entire trip. The total unloads of coral trout in Bowen for February 2011 were 643 kilograms. In the corresponding period in 2008, prior to the cyclones, it was 26,133 kilograms. This year the catch was as a result of a similar effort being expended for this reduction in catch. Reduced catches have put a strain on individuals and the industry as a whole since Cyclone Hamish in March 2009. Since that time, cyclones Ului, Anthony and Yasi have impacted on these fishing grounds.

XML.Hansard-Body: A Tropical Cyclone Hamish working group was formed with a number of research bodies and they gathered data on catch rates and effort patterns, with some heavily impacted fishery grids confirming that catch rates were down by more than 30 per cent. The Bowen reef line fishers support the district with their flow-on work to other industries and the call for government assistance has gone unanswered, apart from some wage subsidy relief where it was applicable. The industry has been advised that it does not meet the strict natural disaster assessment criteria.

Minister Mulherin is on record as saying that there is nothing available to help Bowen fishermen restructure their businesses or get compensation for loss of income. He has stated that the department has assessed it and ‘it just does not qualify’. Fishers are left in a quandary. Their own patch is barren and they are reluctant to go elsewhere due to the expense and potential for overfishing. Many fishers are coming to the belief that the Fisheries (Coral Reef Fin Fish) Management Plan needs to have a whole-of-industry review. Many feel that the objectives of the plan and its achievement are no longer sustainable. Whilst undertaking a review, there is also the belief that best practice measures from other states need to be scrutinised for consideration.

Hansard-Body.A: (Morayfield--ALP) (11.53 am): I would like to add to the comments that I made yesterday, during last night’s adjournment debate, about International Women’s Day and the Business and Professional Women club at Caboolture. Yesterday in Caboolture, BPW Caboolture held its annual candle-lighting ceremony. This ceremony is held every year on the same day by every BPW club in the world and coincides with International Women’s Day. I commend BPW Caboolture for its contribution to International Women’s Day and for its contribution to the advancement of the status of women in our region, our nation and our world.

XML.Hansard-Body: Honourable members would certainly be interested to know that BPW Caboolture is the largest BPW club in Australia and that one of its members, Debbie Rychvalsky, serves as the national secretary of BPW Australia. BPW Caboolture also has the youngest BPW member in Australia, Aleisha Gubesch, who is in year 12 at St Columban’s College. I am very proud of the work of BPW Caboolture. They are a tight-knit, supportive group who are out there doing their best for the women of the Caboolture region and the women of our world.

I would also like to take this opportunity to commend the Queensland government’s Office for Women for its good and hard work in supporting women right around our state. I congratulate the Office for Women on their dedicated Women’s Infolink hotline service. This hotline service provides to Queensland women a free and confidential information and referral service about community services and government agency support services. The Women’s Infolink hotline service can be accessed by calling 1800177577 during business hours.

Hansard-Body.A: (Indooroopilly--LNP) (11.55 am): Growing Queensland’s knowledge economy is vital to our state’s future. It will provide job growth, wealth growth, new opportunity growth and new skills for Queenslanders now and in the future. That is why it is stunning that the state Labor government has snubbed Queensland’s information technology industry with its recently appointed Skills Queensland Board. Of the 10 board members, there is no representative from the state’s IT industry. The irony here is that, when announcing the new board, the Premier claimed in a media release that it would work ‘to ensure Queensland was equipped to meet current and future skills demand’. The Premier claimed further--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Bligh Government established Skills Queensland ... to ensure we are working with industry to skill up Queenslanders for the jobs of today and the future.
XML.Hansard-Body: Can there be any industry that is better positioned to meet current and future skill demand than the IT industry? Can there be any industry that is better positioned to skill up Queenslanders for the jobs of today and tomorrow? Yet the IT industry is snubbed by the Labor government and, instead, a majority of those appointed by the Labor government to the Skills Queensland Board are either union officials or public servants.

But perhaps the snubbing of the IT industry by Labor is not surprising. This government has taken little constructive interest in this industry, which will play such an important role in the state’s future. The government seems to have no understanding of how important a role the IT industry is already playing in our state’s economy. The local IT industry comprises almost 6,000 businesses, employs a direct workforce of 70,000 and generates revenue of approximately $29 billion and exports of $1.15 billion. Yet, when the government has a chance to put this industry front and centre on its key Skills Queensland Board, it snubs it in favour of union leaders and public servants.

I challenge the government’s newly installed ICT minister to reverse this decision. If he does not, it just shows that he will be treating IT just like his predecessor did--as a second-class industry.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Gold Coast City Council, Water Prices

Hansard-Body.A: (Broadwater--ALP) (11.57 am): The issue of water charges is a very sensitive issue on the Gold Coast at the moment. Many residents are fed up with the secrecy, buck-passing, inaction and incompetence of the Gold Coast mayor and the Gold Coast City Council on this matter. The paltry $50 rebate that Mayor Ron Clarke has offered to some ratepayers for their water and sewerage bills is simply not enough, particularly in light of the news today that it would be null and void after their rates bill will rise by $50. My Gold Coast Labor colleagues and I have called on Councillor Clarke to increase the rebate.

XML.Hansard-Body: The Gold Coast City Council is set to profit $98 million this year alone through council owned water and utility retailer Allconnex. Its own figures project that this profit will grow to $218 million in five years. If the mayor agreed to a $100 rebate to each household to help pay for water bills, he would still have $70 million left over from profits. Instead, Councillor Clarke is going to give a paltry $50 rebate but only to some residents, leaving the council to pocket more than $85 million.

Council charges make up 76 per cent of the average Gold Coast water and sewerage bill. The fact is--and we have been saying this all along--councils are making huge profits from water bills. The state government understands the current pressure on household budgets. The state government sold water to South-East Queensland councils last year for a $407 million loss. That means that the state is effectively providing a saving of nearly $350 per water connection in South-East Queensland. Despite that, in December we announced a reduction in water price increases that will grow from $5 to $30 per year per household by 2017-18.

The Bligh government also already provides a $100 water rebate for pensioners. We are doing what we can do to help. It is now time for the Gold Coast City Council to do the same. If the Moreton Bay Regional Council can offer its residents a 50 per cent rebate then so can the Gold Coast City Council.

Mr KNUTH (Dalrymple--LNP)
(12.00 pm): This morning I tabled a petition of 1,976 signatures from the residents of the Atherton Tablelands calling for a government commitment that there are no plans to cut back chemotherapy services at the Atherton Hospital. The petition also calls for a government commitment to continue funding these services as the loss of the chemotherapy unit will impact severely on cancer sufferers, their families and the community.

This petition was initiated in response to feedback that the service was going to be phased out and moved to the Cairns Base Hospital almost 100 kilometres away. In November last year I questioned the previous minister in relation to this and he replied that there were no plans to phase out chemotherapy services at the Atherton Hospital. However, Tablelanders are very sceptical and rightly so. Residents have seen many health services removed or delayed with no consideration for the negative impact on the Tablelands community. They want to ensure that vital services such as the chemotherapy unit remain and are funded adequately into the future so that they can continue to provide the quality care that the chemo unit at the Atherton Hospital gives.

The scepticism of Tablelanders is entrenched in the long list of promises by the Labor government regarding services on the Atherton Tablelands. It is entrenched in a six-year promise for a CT scanner which we are still waiting for; it is entrenched in the promise of the west wing at the Mareeba Hospital that lay idle for years until a recent positive announcement; and it is engraved in the promise of an upgrade of the ambulance station and healthcare centre in Ravenshoe that in 10 months has got no further than being pegged out.

This petition is reflective of the deep scepticism that these communities have towards this government’s policy to centralise health services. This petition shows that any inkling of a removal of the chemo unit at the Atherton Hospital will spark massive revolt. The previous minister gave a halfhearted response that there are no changes planned for the removal of the chemo unit at the Atherton Hospital. Tablelanders want and deserve an iron-clad guarantee from the new Minister for Health that this vital service will not be removed and a firm commitment that the chemo unit will continue to be adequately funded in the future.

Ms STONE (Springwood--ALP)
(12.01 pm): For 28 years Chatswood Hills State School has been caring for the environment. In that time they have created a beautiful rainforest area, ensuring that there are trees in their grounds to maintain the koala corridor. This is extremely important as the school is a neighbour to the Springwood Conservation Park. The school is also a member of Land for Wildlife and it is committed to preserving and protecting our land and natural resources for our wildlife. They are great recyclers, have won national awards for their environmental programs and liaised internationally with universities and other environmental educators about their programs. There is no doubt Chatsworth Hills is a leader when it comes to being green. In fact, I bet any of the students could come into this chamber and teach us all a thing or two about how to do it better when it comes to being green.

On visiting Chatswood Hills State School one can very clearly see how seriously they are taking caring for the environment. Last week when I had the pleasure of presenting the school with their waste buster packs I also had the pleasure of seeing a beautiful koala in the school grounds. The koala crawled along school paths, past the administration, past classrooms and then to a tree which it climbed and in which it had a rest. It possibly could have been the oohs and ahs from some of the younger students in the school that may have caused the koala to find a resting spot high up in that tree. It was a very special moment to see the joy and wonder on the faces of the young students and to see this beautiful koala wandering around as if it was part of the school community.

As I said before, I presented the school with their waste buster packs as the school is among 150 schools in the state to become part of the Do the Right Thing, Use the Right Bin program. By having a recycling and waste management program, Chatswood Hills State School will be helping deliver a greener, cleaner future for our state. The principal, Mr Keith Graham, believes the program fits in well with the school’s tradition of promoting environmental conservation and sustainability. He said that it is important to educate our children in literacy and numeracy, but it is also important to educate them in environmental awareness and responsibility. The school has a number of rainwater tanks and lots of other programs and I look forward to visiting the school soon.

Mr FOLEY (Maryborough--Ind)
(12.03 pm): Maryborough makes the best trains in Australia, if not the world. But imagine the outcry in my electorate when we hear that the Sydney Morning Herald has an article, which I table, headed ‘Trains built in China face much more work in NSW’, which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The company building Sydney’s new train carriages has conceded it will have to redo a significant amount of work in Australia, after revealing production problems at its Chinese subcontractor.

Downer EDI yesterday admitted that it would struggle to meet a deadline set only one month ago to deliver the first Waratah train by late next month, which would have made it available for service in May or June.

Releasing its half-yearly results, Downer said that while Changchun Railway Vehicles had done a good job constructing the shell of the carriages, it was having major issues with the train’s internal fit-out, such as its seats and vestibules.
Many of the carriages that have arrived in Australia have damaged interiors, said Ross Spicer, the rail executive appointed in December to oversee production.
The first 15 of 78 train sets will now be fitted out at the company’s Cardiff factory in the Hunter using more ‘skilled artisan staff’, Mr Spicer said.

Downer will then redesign the interiors to make them easier to assemble in China. But over the life of the project the company will require an extra 770,000 hours of labour in Australia than it had previously planned for.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Article, dated 1 March 2011, from www.smh.com.au, titled ‘Trains built in China face much more work in NSW’ [ 4050 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: I call on the Premier and the Treasurer not to displace Maryborough workers and business with short-sighted decisions to send Queensland work overseas. We have the absolute track record of building quality trains and I think to do anything else other than to award it to a Queensland company and keep jobs local would be a very short-sighted decision.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): The time for private members’ statements has expired.

Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP)
(12.05 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the report of the Committee System Review Committee, titled Review of the Queensland parliamentary committee system , tabled on 15 December 2010, be noted.
XML.Hansard-Body: I have had the good fortune to effect many legislative and policy changes as a minister in many different portfolios over a 12-year period and hopefully they have been of benefit to the people of Queensland. I regard the work of the committee I chaired and its outcomes as one of the most valuable contributions I have made to this parliament.

At the outset, let me thank my fellow committee members. The opposition members--the member for Southern Downs, the member for Callide and the member for Toowoomba South--collectively have 51 years of experience in this parliament. The member for Nanango has been here for 10 years. My colleague the member for Rockhampton and I were first elected over 21 years ago and the member for Pine Rivers, the member for Yeerongpilly and the member for Waterford each brought newer perspectives to our deliberations. Four of us had been ministers and served in this parliament both in government and in opposition. Between us we represented over 130 years of parliamentary experience.

We produced this report in record time--10 months, in fact--which is the time frame we gave ourselves. Members came to committee meetings as individuals. There was no sign that people had caucused along party political lines or in any other sense. I do not think I would offend any members’ sensibilities in saying that it was a regular occurrence that members frequently disagreed with their colleagues from their own party. I have to say that this has been my experience on other parliamentary committees on which I have served.

Our committee gained valuable insight from visiting the New Zealand parliament. The committee system they have fashioned for their unicameral parliament is regarded by many as amongst best practice. The member for Southern Downs and I learnt a tremendous amount from talking to members of various Canadian parliaments and their officers. Their unicameral provincial parliaments have committee structures that are much more powerful than our own. I was also very fortunate in a private capacity to visit the new Scottish parliament and the Irish parliament and talk about these matters.

It is easy to become comfortable and assume that other Westminster parliaments operate in the same way as ours and it is a learning experience to examine the differences in their operation and priorities. I think it is fair to say that the member for Southern Downs and I were quite taken with the practice in some Canadian parliaments to save all the parliamentary votes and have them in one block period every morning. We resisted the temptation to include that in our recommendation, but it is differences such as these which make us take one step back and question our own practices and the possibilities for change.

At the end of the day you are never comparing apples to apples when you are comparing different parliaments, and we were never going to copy other jurisdictions’ models and adopt them as our own. The recommendations in this report have been crafted to fit our own unique parliamentary circumstances, our geography, our history and our priorities. They could only have been framed by members of parliament because we know what is workable and achievable.

The fact that we have delivered a unanimous report is significant on many levels. We all became excited by the prospect that it was time for change and that, indeed, there was sufficient maturity and goodwill around the table to negotiate compromises. Probably there have not been many other times in our state’s history when unanimity for such parliamentary reform could have been reached. Our blueprint for reform represents the most significant change in the way that the Queensland parliament operates since the upper house was abolished 90 years ago. It will represent the most significant reform of any state parliament in Australia.

Because the senior members of our committee have been occupied as ministers, shadow ministers or opposition leaders for the past decade or so, we all realised that we had not taken a sufficient interest in the way that the parliament was being run or, indeed, how effectively the committee system was operating. Some of us, and I was one, were committee chairs in the early 1990s when we hired our own research staff, controlled our own budgets and set our own agendas. In those days we made recommendations that the government of the day did not like but nevertheless accepted. I well remember being on the public works committee and recommending that we knock down the wall of the Townsville prison. It was the first time that we recommended replacing that fixed structure with barbed wire. The minister of the day and, indeed, the prison officers thought that the world was going to end and that the prisoners were going to escape as a result. That recommendation did not make the government happy, but it proceeded with it. I can give members lots of other examples of the powers of the committees in those days.

Those were also the days when the media and academia were interested in our work. I think it is fair to say that, although our present committees have been producing many valuable reports, much of their influence, independence and status has been eroded. There are many reasons why this has occurred, but in my speaking entitlement today I do not have the time to examine them in detail. However, we do believe that giving committees of the parliament decision-making control over the budget, policies and other matters concerning their operations will make us all pay more attention to their work.

We also believe that the creation of parliamentary secretary positions with superior entitlements to committee chairs has led to some of the most ambitious, enthusiastic and capable backbenchers to chase those positions, when once those same individuals sought to put their energies into the position of committee chair. We must again elevate this position. In New Zealand, many former ministers who are now in opposition are using their expertise to chair committees. It has been a worthwhile career path for them to use their skill and exercise accountability over the government of the day.

When we saw the dedicated committee facilities, with public and press galleries and broadcasting facilities, in every parliament that we visited, we asked ourselves why, after 20 years of a modern committee system in the Queensland parliament, we do not have even one dedicated committee room? We realised that we have all taken our eye off the ball when it comes to this important part of parliament’s work. Other parliaments have gone paperless. Other parliaments broadcast all committee proceedings. Other parliaments have dedicated rooms for the exclusive use of each committee. The fact that we do not have videoconferencing facilities is a sad indictment on our present state of affairs. On parliamentary sitting days my own committee often had trouble finding a satisfactory meeting room.

I do not know what the opposition’s present position is on the creation of an upper house, but I believe that the blueprint we are offering is superior to an upper house in every aspect. Our system will mean that every piece of legislation is explained in detail to a committee. Every piece of legislation will have the possibility of having public input and that input will be publicly broadcast. For the first time, every Queenslander can have a say in the laws that we make in this state. The committee will have to listen to those views before that legislation is debated and voted on in the parliament. This is unprecedented for an Australian parliament.

In addition, the committees will be able to examine petitions, initiate their own inquiries and take up matters on behalf of ordinary Queenslanders. I think in our honest moments we would all acknowledge that--and, let us face it, we are all directly elected--the most important role we perform is as our community’s ombudsman and our role as legislator comes a poor second. Consequently, we all speak and vote on legislation without a good understanding of its detail. That is why, in future, it is important that members of parliament, through this committee system, examine the detail of the legislation. I am concerned that the parliament’s role as a check and balance on the executive is not as strong as it could be, because we have not been paying attention to the detail. The system we propose will mean members of parliament will scrutinise and understand legislation, and restore the balance to their role as legislators and representatives of the people.

It is human nature to resist change, but change is an irreversible feature of our modern world. I am aware that in this report we have put forward far-reaching and bold reforms that will give anxiety to some public servants who will, for the first time, have to appear before committees; to some ministers, who may not want every detail of their work examined; to some members of parliament, who will be challenged by the workload that we will put in front of them in the future; and, indeed, to some officers of this parliament who will not want to see change.

There has been some commentary on our report and I feel that a lot of that commentary has been misguided. Late last year, a Courier-Mail columnist described the changes that we are proposing as ‘a canny plan that would result in the most opposition friendly parliament we have ever known.’ This is hardly consistent with the claims of a former Speaker, Jim Fouras, who has said that the changes will place parliament under even greater executive control. In Tuesday’s Courier-Mail , Mr Fouras also incorrectly stated that nowhere in the world is there a standing orders committee that does not include the Speaker. One only has to look at the House of Representatives where the Standing Committee on Procedure, the equivalent of Queensland’s Standing Orders Committee, does not have the Speaker as a member. After last year’s cliffhanger election, Julia Gillard’s government proposed changes to the standing orders after negotiations with Independents and other members of parliament. Those changes were accepted by the House of Representatives without reference to the procedures committee.

There is no reason why the Queensland parliament should resist evolution when other parliaments around the world are moving to make the most of society’s changes in the 21st century. As I have indicated, the nine members of our committee had to make compromises to reach unanimity on many matters and I think we are all mature enough to consider other points of view. Since the report was tabled, I have spent considerable time talking to the Premier and my colleagues, the Speaker, the Clerk of the Parliament, the Integrity Commissioner, journalists and academics about our proposals.
