I am prepared to accept advice that having the Committee of the Legislative Assembly, the proposed committee, undertake all the functions of the ethics and privileges committee would not represent best practice and that the consideration of members’ breaches should be retained by a back bench committee formed specifically for this purpose. I know that the government will indicate this direction in its response to our report. I also note that in the past 50 reports on ethics and privileges complaints, only one has not been unanimous. Therefore, I accept retaining an IEPPC in some form to hear breaches of privilege matters.

I also accept that it would be preferable for the Committee of the Legislative Assembly to take responsibility for the management, construction and maintenance of the parliamentary buildings and electorate offices, rather than the Department of Public Works. I remind members that for over a century members of parliament had committees such as a parliamentary buildings committee, a library committee, a refreshments committee and a printing committee, which undertook those kinds of responsibilities. Clearly, it is preferable to have a group of parliamentarians continue that function.

Other recommendations that have caused consternation in some quarters include our proposal to have an opposition member chair the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee. I am pleased that the government is intending to support that recommendation. There are a number of precedents in other Westminster parliaments for having opposition members chair committees. When I was in the UK I spoke to members of parliament who were genuinely surprised that we did not have that tradition in Australia.

We are asking the government to also consider putting laypeople on the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee. I note that the House of Commons in the United Kingdom is working to appoint lay members to its Standards and Privileges Committee. The committee chair, Kevin Barron, stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... I am confident that lay members will bring to the Committee an external perspective that it currently lacks, as well as providing it with greater credibility outside Parliament.
XML.Hansard-Body: The report which led to the recommendation of appointing lay members to two parliamentary committees, which is called the Twelfth Report from the Committee on Standards in Public Life , viewed lay membership as a way to widen the committees’ horizons, increase their experience base and strengthen their legitimacy with the public. Indeed, they were the sentiments behind my committee’s recommendations.

The proposal by the review committee was that the Committee of the Legislative Assembly comprise the Premier, Deputy Premier, Leader of the Opposition, Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Leader of the House and Leader of Opposition Business. We expect that the Premier, Deputy Premier and, indeed, the two leaders of the opposition may wish to appoint permanent alternates, but we believe that they have the right to attend the meetings if there are discussions in which they want to participate. The review committee, which included the Independent member for Nanango, did not recommend that there be an Independent member on that committee, nor did it recommend that the Speaker be a member.

Checks and balances in a Westminster system are designed to avoid undue concentration of authority in a single set of hands. The proposed Committee of the Legislative Assembly shares responsibility for the oversight of the parliamentary buildings and the setting of policies for managing the parliament. We do believe that in the future those decisions should be made by a committee of our peers.

Queensland is probably one of the few places in the world that has adherence to fundamental legislative principles embodied in legislation. These FLPs are important principles, but they are not complex. They are simply a short, non-exhaustive list of rights and liberties which should not be breached in laws. These include things such as ensuring legislation does not reverse the onus of proof without adequate justification, does not confer immunity from prosecution without adequate justification and does not impose obligations retrospectively. These are principles with which every legislator should be familiar.

Firstly, there is a number of layers already acting as safeguards on FLPs. There is an independent examination from the Office of the Queensland Parliamentary Counsel, acting in an independent capacity, which is required to advise ministers and cabinet on a bill’s consistency with fundamental legislative principles. Secondly, there is the executive, where the Attorney-General advises on all FLP matters on proposed legislation brought before cabinet. Thirdly, we have parliamentary scrutiny. Explanatory notes for bills and significant subordinate legislation are required to be assessed as to their consistency with fundamental legislative principles and, if inconsistent, to state the reasons for it.

The changes that we are proposing will strengthen the level of parliamentary scrutiny of bills. Portfolio committees will be required to undertake the role currently performed by the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee. I would expect that the portfolio committees will produce Legislation Alerts for their examination of legislation. These committees will be assisted by the staff who currently assist the scrutiny committee and the panel of legal experts.

By having portfolio committees examine any potential breaches of FLPs, those committees can examine in detail the government’s justification for any potential breaches of FLPs. Portfolio committees will also be able to follow up on matters raised in the Legislation Alerts and justification for any potential breaches of FLPs by allowing them to question the minister or departmental officials directly.

One of the strong recommendations in our report is that in future committee reports which are not about legislation should receive some attention and debate in this parliament. I am pleased that we have followed through with that strong recommendation today. I note that there is a rather long list of people who would like to contribute to this debate. I am pleased that all members of parliament are showing such interest in this report and our recommendations. I look forward to hearing the views of my colleagues over the hours ahead.

Hansard-Body.A: (Southern Downs--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (12.24 pm): This is the most significant change to the Legislative Assembly since the upper house was abolished in 1922 and I believe it is the most positive change. It is a change that is going to benefit all Queenslanders. Indeed, I think it will make the executive more accountable to this parliament and it will make members more focused on the role of legislator. It will also allow them to be more understanding of their briefs.

XML.Hansard-Body: I start by thanking the chair of the committee, the member for Sunnybank, who did a very good job. Her enthusiasm for the task at hand was without question. Her passion and commitment to bring about this reform deserves to be acknowledged. I say the same with regard to the other members of the committee--opposition, government and Independent--who approached this particular process in an extremely bipartisan way. They took off their partisan hats, looked at the reference given to them by the Premier and set about making significant reforms and recommendations for this parliament for the long term.

Indeed, the people of Queensland will be the big winners because they will get more from this process. They will have the opportunity to participate in the scrutiny of legislation, to give their views and to provide their expertise. The committee examination process will provide them with a practical overview of the way legislation may affect them and it will allow members of parliament to judge this better. This will result in better legislation coming through this parliament.

I do not think we necessarily always get good legislation through this parliament. Sometimes legislation is rushed through this parliament. Sometimes, as we have all witnessed, legislation is introduced into this parliament and by the time we debate it a raft of amendments almost as significant as the original bill has been placed on the table. That occurs because the work was not done in the first instance. These reforms will result in increased responsibility for the executive to get it right in the first place. We will see ministers hastening cautiously. Bills, particularly contentious bills or those that relate to major policy matters, will go out for consultation and will be deliberated on by committee members who will have more expertise. They will look at this and feel their worth as members of parliament engaging their communities. This will result in amendments--changes to those bills--which will address many of their concerns. Sometimes governments have been embarrassed to bring back bills to this place for amendment because they did not get it right in the first place.

That is not to say that some sort of bipartisan utopia will be automatically created through this process. There will still be a place for the normal argy-bargy of politics. Everyone understands that we live in an extremely partisan world. Despite the fact that 80 per cent of the legislation and the decisions of this place have unanimous support in this House, in the future there will be issues of contention which will be pursued through that process--and so there should be.

When the committee as a whole travelled to New Zealand and the chair of the committee and I travelled to Canada, members of parliament, whether they were government, opposition or independent, and members of the community said that this process brought about better legislation and better decision making. Those in opposition did not always agree with the outcome, but they had a better chance to scrutinise it and sometimes achieve amendments which enhanced the operation of the bill around its intent. Whilst we might not necessarily agree with something, sometimes it can be wrong not only in principle--and that can be subjective--but also in its implementation or mechanics. This process allows debate about the principles, which may result in significant change, enhancing the application. That is extremely important as well.

I want to thank all of those people involved. I want to thank the people who saw us with such openness and enthusiasm in New Zealand and in the various Canadian jurisdictions. I want to thank all of those people who actually bothered to take the time to put in a submission and to give us their views on how we could make this parliament better for them. I want to also thank the committee staff for the role they played.

We know about the establishment of the committee and how it came about last year. We operated within our charter. Maybe sometimes we could be accused of going a little broader than that. But we felt that it was important to achieve this once in a lifetime reform--it is not once in a lifetime; it is actually the most significant reform, I believe, since 1922 and possibly one of the most significant reforms going back to when this parliament was established in 1859.

It is going to completely change the way that we operate. This is going to make members of parliament not only ombudsmen for their electorates but also legislators who are going to be across their brief. If anyone is worried about what this will mean for ministers, if you are a shadow minister you will need to be on your toes as well, because when you go into a parliamentary estimates process you are going to be there for a much longer period of time and so you will need to make sure that you are across your issues as much as the government ministers. I would say that there is justifiably a level of nervousness that will permeate across not only the government but also the opposition about this, and I think that is a very good thing as well.

As the chair of the committee said, and I think this is one of the most intriguing things, when we went into the process--and we have to be very careful about talking about the happenings and discussions within the committee, so I am not going to individualise it--we took off our partisan hats and we looked at this with a view to how it could be improved. Ironically, when it came to the issue of establishing the committee, we had opposition members arguing about needing to recognise that a government has a mandate and needs to be able to implement that mandate and we had government members arguing probably more vociferously than opposition members for opposition chairs. That shows the way we approached this particular process. I am probably overstepping--
Ms Spence: We are trying to be kind to you.
Mr Seeney: Why is everyone looking at me?

Mr SPRINGBORG: No-one should think that that reflects on anyone--on the member for Callide or anyone else. I use it as an illustration of the way members of the committee approached this process. They analysed every particular facet--the pros and the cons. I think it is of great credit to the committee that it was able to do that. On that committee we had three former opposition leaders; we had a long-term former minister of the government; we had somebody who is a current serving and very senior minister of the government; we had other very intelligent new members of the government who were enthusiastic about this particular process; and we also had a long-term Independent member. So we had a lot of people on that committee who had an enormous amount of parliamentary experience, and that was alluded to by the chair of the committee.

The important thing again is that we have had to overlay this on a unicameral parliamentary system. We have heard a lot of people over the years say, ‘The upper house was abolished in 1922. Wouldn’t it be great to bring back an upper house in Queensland?’ That was 1922. It was a long time ago. It was a very, very, very long time ago. We also looked at the issues of the expenses of upper houses in other jurisdictions which could variously be up to $30 million or $40 million. We made a judgement when we were looking at this that, if we have a proper, functioning committee system which is well resourced and takes its role seriously, then this could be an extremely cost-effective way of delivering the scrutiny of legislation and the oversight of the executive which would otherwise be provided by an upper house. I think we can do that far more cost-effectively and we can get a better outcome when it comes to this.

This will be a paradigm shift to the way we approach our operations. I note that in some of the other jurisdictions that we visited--and also the chair of the committee said this a moment ago--in many ways a member of parliament has become little more than a glorified ombudsman. They come in here and ventilate their particular views in this parliament. They look for a piece of legislation on which they can ventilate some sort of community view without necessarily understanding completely what the legislation is about. Certainly from an opposition perspective we look at legislation and think, ‘Gee whiz, we don’t have much time to debate certain things in this place, so what’s this bill? Okay, there is a chance to come in here and raise those things while speaking on that bill.’ Government members stand up and praise the minister and all of those sorts of things, and that is their role. But have any members of the government or the opposition had a practical role in making sure that it is good legislation? No, they have not. I know we have a Scrutiny of Legislation Committee, but a lot of legislation just goes down the line and that is what we get.

This reform will provide an opportunity for the community and their expertise to come to the fore and will provide an opportunity for non-executive members of the parliament to do what they should do--and that is scrutinise and hold the executive to account. I think it is somewhat ironic that since the 1688 Bill of Rights, which has underpinned the Westminster system of parliament, and the way that it was fought for to engage and to establish the supremacy of the parliament, we have probably seen a watering down of the role of the parliament vis-a-vis the executive. I am not pointing at any one particular party, but that is what has basically happened.

If we look at the history of the Westminster system and the way our democracy has developed, there were extremely strong checks and balances on the executive through that parliamentary process. Indeed, the role of the parliament has become subordinate and has been subjugated to the interests and what has been the growing power and supremacy of the executive. I am not idealistic enough to say that we can roll all of that back, but this reform provides an opportunity to be able to recapture some of that so that the parliament has a greater role--that is, the non-executive members of the parliament--in ensuring better outcomes with regard to legislation and better checks and balances on the executive of the day.

So what is the role of an MP? We have the role of being an ombudsman in our community. Maybe that is not a bad thing but, more or less, that has become the main role of members in this place. We are an advocate on behalf of our communities. We are a representative and we are a legislator. But how many members in this place could go out there and honestly say, ‘I’m a legislator’? We are members of the Legislative Assembly. The Legislative Assembly makes legislation. The Legislative Assembly makes the laws. The Legislative Assembly lays down the rules and regulations by which our society must function. Yet, if we look at the way things happen, this chamber is a chamber which more or less consents absolutely to what the executive is seeking to do. But this reform will make sure that we get back to the role of being legislators. I will touch on some of those points a little more in a moment.

This committee has recommended the establishment of a Committee of the Legislative Assembly. I know there has been some debate around that, whether that impugns the role of the Speaker and all of those sorts of things. I think the role of the Speaker can be extremely complementary to this committee. I understand--and I will not go there because the chair of the committee has not gone there--that there may be some other considerations around that issue and that the Speaker has concerns in regard to the standing orders. But it is a matter for the government to decide how it will respond to that.

Members of parliament should be in charge of their parliament. The Speaker is a person who makes sure that he or she maintains the order of the parliament and makes sure that the parliament is appropriately refereed without fear or favour. I think we are privileged to have a truly excellent Speaker who does that very well. It is also very important to understand that the Committee of the Legislative Assembly will be involved in laying down and setting the business for the parliament. We understand and we respect--and non-government members of this committee respect--that at the end of the day the government has the numbers. The government can decide. If there is a matter which cannot be resolved through negotiation, the government members have the right to resolve that issue because they are the ones who have been elected to govern. They are the ones who argue that they have a mandate, and they genuinely do have a mandate. Sometimes the term ‘mandate’ is bandied about, but the members opposite have the responsibility of forming the government in this place, and we understand that.

A Committee of the Legislative Assembly will provide an opportunity for a lot of the day-to-day concerns and considerations of members of this House to be properly dealt with. There is a whole range of issues with regard to broad entitlement concerns that members have--the rules by we which we operate with regard to conflicts of interest, our pecuniary interests and all of those sorts of things--and a whole range of other matters that go to the day-to-day running of the House. That is what a Committee of the Legislative Assembly should do. The jurisdictions that we looked at in Canada all variously had a part of that model. It was called a bureau in some places. It was called a house committee in some places. But it was about making sure that the interests of the members were looked after in the parliament.

Regardless of the hat we wear in this place, we have many common concerns about the way our electorates need to be looked after, how our electorate staff need to be resourced and those sorts of things. There are fundamental things that we all seek to do. There is very little contention when it comes to those things.

Another recommendation of the committee is the establishment of nine portfolio committees. It will ultimately be up to the government to decide how many portfolio committees it establishes. The only rider I would place is that if there are going to be fewer than nine committees--and I believe there should be nine--we need to make sure that those committees that will have a lot of work to do, particularly those in the areas of health and justice where there is a lot of legislation, do not get loaded up disproportionately. Ultimately that needs to be decided by debate and resolution of this parliament.

The committee has also made the recommendation that we retain the role of the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee. We think that is very important. It has an oversight role. That oversight role, given the nature of the CMC, should be handled by a stand-alone committee. There were certain recommendations made about the involvement of lay members on that committee. There were strong reasons given for that. A lay member could provide external expertise from time to time to assist the committee in its deliberations. I certainly hope that is something the government considers, either as part of the adoption of this committee report or in any subsequent introduction of a statutory instrument into this parliament.

The role of those portfolio committees would be to scrutinise legislation, to scrutinise the expenditure of government and, through the estimates committees, to scrutinise the proposed expenditure for the year. They would also ensure that when it comes to the appointment of statutory officers of this parliament there is greater bipartisanship than exists at the moment. Given the importance of the role of the Ombudsman, the Information Commissioner, the Auditor-General and various other office holders there should be bipartisan support for the selection, approval and appointment of people to those positions. That happens in many jurisdictions overseas. It may indeed happen interstate, but we were given the charter to look at unicameral parliaments, which we have done.

The estimates process is going to be a different process and it should be a different process. The member for Rockhampton would remember a notable quote in this place by a former member for Crows Nest, Russell Cooper, who described the estimates process some years ago--and I will not repeat it. I think we need to reform the estimates process. This recommendation would actually allow the committees to drill down, deal with a lot more of the issues without strict time frames and, ultimately, question senior public servants in Queensland. We are not suggesting that junior public servants be questioned but that senior public servants be questioned. We have made the suggestion that it be DG level and associate DG level.

At the moment in Queensland we have associate DGs who are in effect DGs because of the superdepartment structure. Within DEEDI, for example, there is an associate DG who is in effect the DG for the primary industries section. Under them we have the SES level. We do not believe that we need to go below the associate DG level, but it is important that we have the ability to question senior public servants in Queensland. I have seen ministers who were prepared and open enough and comfortable enough to allow that in the past, but that has not been readily available to all estimates committees. It should be. I think it is of no detriment to the government if that actually happens.

If we do this right and bring in the other things that the proposed CLA should look at recommending, it would truncate the time of the House debating things that committees could consider. It would free up more time for members to air issues in parliament on behalf of their constituents. There should be more private members’ time. This proposal would allow more private members’ time.

The other part of the paradigm shift, if these recommendations are formally adopted, would be that committee work would become a main function of this House. Wednesday mornings would be set aside for committee work, as well as Fridays or whenever committees need to meet. I think that is extremely important.

In order for these committees to function appropriately it will be extremely important to make sure they are well resourced. That is the point that is made over and over again. Let us not squib on that. Let us not be concerned about that, because we do not have an upper house costing us $40 million. If our committees are going to cost us $3 million or $4 million and we get better democracy, better outcomes, better solutions for our communities, then it is worth it and it is value for money.

Hansard-Body.A: (Rockhampton--ALP) (12.44 pm): This is a unique moment because we are actually carrying out one of the recommendations of the Committee System Review Committee--that is, properly debate reports that parliamentary committees bring forward. In my time in this parliament they have never been given a proper airing. I think this is a unique part of the process.

XML.Hansard-Body: At the outset I join with the two previous speakers in stating that I have served on a number of committees of this parliament--a long time ago, I guess--but I have never served on a committee with greater intent and integrity than this one. I thank the opposition for putting forward three very senior people--capable people, experienced people who have been around this place for a long time in different roles. Two of them have been ministers. The other is the Leader of Opposition Business. They are very experienced parliamentarians who were able to bring a great deal of wisdom and thought to the process. The Independent member also brought a significant body of strength to the committee. Then there were my Labor colleagues.

We did not always agree, as has been said, but that is the way a committee should work. In my experience, that is how they have worked in the past. When I chaired the public works committee the members did not always agree. Back in those days, the executive government seemed to take a bit more notice than has been the case in the intervening years. I think this report does take us a fair distance down the path of ameliorating the situation.

Can I say that I was most surprised that, when the committee report came down, the Speaker actually went public and registered his disapproval with it. I think that was improper. I think it was intemperate. I think it was a discourtesy to the members of the committee. I think we were at least owed the courtesy of putting our case in the parliament rather than have it almost vetoed at the outset by the Speaker.

As for former Speaker Mr Fouras, I had no respect for him when he was in the chair. He was, as far as I was concerned, the worst Speaker that I have ever sat with in this place. He could not command authority from the chair. I remember him once standing up there saying, ‘I’m standing on my seat.’ He could barely get the prayer right in the morning.
Ms Spence: They were the days when books got thrown across the chamber at other members.

Mr SCHWARTEN: Yes. I remember the mayhem in here one day when people were throwing things at one another as a result of his incapacity to chair the House. I would discourage anybody from taking seriously anything Mr Fouras had to say, especially when he said that he got rid of the Parliamentary Services Commission. That is in fact not true. Terry Mackenroth was the Leader of the House who got rid of it. That absolute piffle that he wrote for the Courier-Mail the other day is about as good as we will get from Jim Fouras. Remember of course that he was the person who wanted to sell the seat of the Speaker to the opposition of the day. He did not treasure the independence of the Speaker. What he treasured most was the position that it brought with it.

I know that people have seen this as an attack on the Speaker, but it actually is none of that. This whole business is, in my view, a result of many years of collective change over this parliament. We have almost found ourselves back where we started in 1860. Back then there were committees of members of parliament who ran the functions of the parliament. There was the building committee and the refreshment rooms committee--all those sorts of things that everybody pooh-poohs now. The fact is that the CLA would take over those responsibilities. It would ensure that the management of the parliament is the business of the members of parliament rather than it being the unilateral decision-making process that we have seen with various Speakers over the years which cannot be questioned.

I hold the very strong view that this building, a heritage building, ought to be maintained by the executive, just the same as every other building in the state. The Department of Public Works has an excellent record at maintaining Government House, for example. The suggestion that somehow or other the Speaker’s independence is compromised by this building being managed by somebody else is a lot of rot actually.

If you look at the mother of all parliaments, you will see that the land on which the mother of all parliaments stands is owned by the Duke of Westminster. It is a privately owned piece of land for which the Crown has paid rent to the Duke of Westminster since Henry VIII’s time. The Lord Chancellor was, until the 1960s, responsible for that building. So even if you look at the mother of all parliaments, you will find that over its long history for the most part the Crown has had to maintain that building, and so it should here now.

I can understand that people may have a different view about that, but it has nothing to do whatsoever with the independence of the Speaker and everything to do with ensuring that the responsibility rests squarely with the executive to maintain this building to a standard that meets the current legislation. The public works department has done that. It built it in the first place and there is no reason the public works department cannot continue to do that. I do not believe that having another set of management here for a heritage building, while you do not have that at Government House, is appropriate.

I also want to talk a bit about the estimates processes. I have been through more estimates as a minister than most people in this parliament. I have always from day one viewed the estimates as departmental estimates and I have always encouraged the department to take them very seriously because I did not see them as necessarily my whole responsibility. I saw them as a bit of a spring-cleaning exercise to get people sharpened on their focus of what they were supposed to be doing.

I always welcomed the estimates and I never hesitated to refer questions to public servants, especially those who got paid twice as much as I got paid. I did not see it as a responsibility necessarily that I should bear on my own. I was criticised by the member for Currumbin for doing that but I did it every time and I would still do it if I was a minister because I firmly believe that the bureaucrats in departments have got to take responsibility equally with the minister of the day for some of those estimates that are put forward and for the expenditure of the department. I do not see anything wrong with that at all. In fact, when the report came out, Mal Grierson, the director-general of the public works department, said to me that he had no problem with it because it was the system we had always used and it was a system which the department was very comfortable with. I do not think anybody needs to be concerned about that. As I said, I went through more estimates as a minister than most people in this parliament and I never, ever saw them as anything other than an accountability to this parliament.

In relation to the committee inquiries, I think I am the only minister who ever referred a matter to the public works committee. I referred two matters actually--one was for housing for aged people and the other was for backflow. Unfortunately, with the backflow one, my own side let me down when two of the Labor members of parliament did not bother showing up for the committee hearing and Kevin Lingard had a field day with me. It was a totally political exercise and I was accused of trying to hide something in the committee system to try to get away from backflow.

What I was actually trying to do was to get the public servants who had been there previous to me cross-examined to find out exactly what their role was in this backflow, which has now been proved to be fatally flawed and disgracefully executed and something that the public works department should never have been involved in. The people involved in this have since been called down to the courts to give evidence in trials on the basis of them paying money to politicians. The committee did not get to the bottom of that and I think it was a chance lost.

The housing one was very successful. It actually proved that the previous model used in funding aged pensioner housing, seniors housing, was flawed. I welcomed that report, but I do not know of anybody else who has done it. So as a minister I see nothing to be afraid of in that regard. In fact, I see a lot of things to be gained out of a committee investigating matters that the government is considering. Let us take the snapper review at the moment, for example. I think the parliament would be better informed if scientists came before a parliamentary committee and actually put their case. At the moment, people are questioned about whether the science is right, wrong or indifferent. I think the parliament would be able to form a much better view on this very touchy issue that has aroused so much concern in the community if the committee system looked at this in a proper way. If that happened, the public might better understand the need to protect this species. That is just one example. There are plenty of others.

I would have liked to have forwarded the whole health payroll issue to a parliamentary committee because I do not believe the people who sat around that table and made those decisions to send it up and go live put the right attention into it. I do not believe the contract was right. There are a whole host of things that could have been looked into in that regard. That could have been a due process of the parliament, rather than it being politicised through question time each morning. I do not think the parliament was well served by that process at all.

This is going to cost money--there is no risk about that--and the public needs to understand that if they want a greater democracy. They have got out of it on the cheap because we have not had an upper house since 1922. I doubt they could ever be convinced that they need another heap of politicians in an upper house up the road here scrutinising this place just because of the cost alone. This is going to cost a lot of money over a long period of time, and so it should. That is one of the reasons that I do not believe the Speaker has the role in advocating for funds for this parliament. I think it is far too easy for the executive government to ignore the Speaker, and I have seen that happen from both sides. I remember Speaker Turner picking up rocks over here that were falling off the annexe and taking them up to plead for money with Treasury.
Mr Shine: He was throwing them.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I think he might have been throwing them by the time he got up there; he was pretty angry about it. He was reduced to that indignity. The CBRC is a place where ministers go, and I believe that the ministers who will sit at the helm of the CLA will have some accountability in that regard. I think that is part of the process that we need to explain to people. Everyone is terrified of spending a dollar on this place lest the public out there think we have got our snouts in the trough. The public have got to understand that this place is their place and that any move to diminish this place by a lack of expenditure is at their expense.
Ms Spence: And it is our most important heritage building.

Mr SCHWARTEN: It is our most important heritage building for a start. I think we have been too timid in putting forward what we really need to do in terms of restructuring this place. In relation to committee rooms, I am sure the reason we do not have committee rooms is that we are frightened of what people will say when we have the expense of more committee rooms, even though it would allow them to come in and use this parliament. I think we can get that message out to people.

At the moment, this could not come at a worse time because of the financial strain on the public purse, but over a period of years we need to make this commitment and in the meantime we need to find alternatives. There are plenty of alternatives for committee rooms and so on in public buildings that are near this place. I see no reason why we should not go down that whole process of determining the proper priority that this place will have.

Parliament House is a function centre. You can barely get around parliament sometimes because of the number of people who are using rooms that used to be for the media or the room that once held a large temporary chamber that was an ideal committee room. That has vanished and it has become a function room. That decision was made with no consultation whatsoever with members of this parliament. The renaming of those rooms was made with no consultation with any member of this parliament. The destruction of the media room, as I understand it, was not made with any consultation with the media or with members of this House. Those decisions have been unilaterally made.

The fundamentals of this place are quite simple--that is, it is supposed to be the people’s place, it is supposed to be the parliament, but we shy away from ever wanting to spend any money on making it a place which the public will get more benefit from. This system will give the public and the executive government, in my view, greater transparency and as a result greater strength.

As I sat around that table with all of the people I mentioned, I saw nothing in any of this that did not create a better outcome for government, for the parliament and for the members of parliament who serve in it. I saw nothing that did not have a greater vision of legislation that comes before this place. As a former minister I have not put through as much legislation as the member for Sunnybank, but I have put a fair bit through over a lengthy period of time. Some of it was profound stuff in the building industry. I know that that legislation would have been served better by having stakeholders in this parliament going through it. Through people having an opportunity to have had their say on the legislation, it would have benefited me greatly--and all of that legislation on building that has gone through this parliament unanimously I might add. But it would have been done better, especially in recent times, to have had a process that helped elevate that legislation in the minds of the public through a process like this.

When I overhauled the Housing Act--I totally revised the Housing Act after 60 years--it was a dramatic piece of legislation. Again, I relied on stakeholders that I knew about to consult with, but there really was not a public process for it and I am sure we could have done that better. So there is nothing to be frightened of from a minister’s point of view in terms of legislation, because it is of great embarrassment to a minister when they have to bring legislation back into the parliament and have it amended. I have had to do that. I think most ministers have had to do that. That is not a minister’s fault. That is simply a process that goes through Parliamentary Counsel. In fact, the Housing Act was so complicated that it was bound to happen. But it might have happened to a lesser degree by having some better scrutiny throughout the process.

I see this as a red-letter day today. I urge the commentators out there to look a bit further into this than simply dismiss it, as I have seen some of the academics do. I noticed Fouras referring to it as a Trojan horse and how it would give the executive more power. I do not know how putting the most senior people in opposition in a management committee of this parliament gives the executive more power! I fail to understand that and it shows how out of touch Fouras really is.
A government member: He never understood it.

Mr SCHWARTEN: He never understood and he never respected the parliament in my view. He just saw it as a creature or a plaything for himself. I actually believe that the CLA is a way forward. It should not be confused with the Parliamentary Service Commission. That did not work because the Speaker and the Leader of the House were on it, so there was an immediate conflict. This way will provide absolute clarity between what the role of the Speaker is and what the role of the management of the business of the parliament is.

For my last little effort, I think it is time we looked at the independence of the Speaker. I think the people whose electorate elects a Speaker are pretty well denied a voice in this parliament. The Westminster system is worse because it disempowers people because they do not get an opposition person to run against them, so their vote is worthless. I think that in the next 10 years we ought to be talking about how you get an independent person who is not a member of parliament to be the Speaker. There would be a howl if the Broncos suddenly put on the ref as one of their own, and that is effectively what the government of the day does. It is always hard for a Speaker to sit in that chair, but I congratulate the current Speaker on the way he manages this parliament. It is excellent. He gives everybody a fair go. Nobody could complain about that at all. With regard to every member of parliament who is ever going to be a Speaker--and I do not suggest for a moment it should be an Independent person because they are no more impartial than anybody else; they are an elected member--I think it is time that we looked at other possibilities and be the first parliament in the world to have a non-elected Speaker. You could have a former member. You would not have Fouras of course. There might be former members who have nothing better to do with their time who want to do it.

I would happily have Turner there. He was a very good Speaker I thought, and the current one also. I really think it is worth the debate and I think it is something we should turn our attention to. This is groundbreaking stuff. I will not be here to see the effects of this, but I will certainly be looking very carefully at it over the next few years.
Sitting suspended from 1.04 pm to 2.30 pm.
Debate, on motion of Mr Moorhead, adjourned.

Hansard-Body.A: (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Attorney-General, Minister for Local Government and Special Minister of State) (2.30 pm), by leave: I wish to provide further information to the House in relation to a question without notice I was asked this morning by the member for Lockyer. State Planning Policy 1/03--Mitigating the Adverse Impacts of Flood, Bushfire and Landslide--sets out the state’s interest in ensuring that natural hazards of flood, bushfire and landslide are adequately considered when making decisions about development.

XML.Hansard-Body: Like all state planning policies, the SPP has effect when development applications are assessed and when planning schemes are made or amended by local governments. SPP 1/03 states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A natural hazard management area (flood) is land inundated by a Defined Flood Event (DFE) and identified in a planning scheme.
XML.Hansard-Body: I refer to page 8 of that document. Let me say that again to be clear: SPP 1/03 requires that local governments identify natural hazard flood areas in their planning schemes and put in place mitigation strategies. That is at page 9.

A 10-year review of SPP 1/03, which, of course, is due to be done by 2013, is now underway and is being led by the Department of Community Safety. The timetable for this review is to be aligned to benefit from the work of the floods commission of inquiry. The associated guidelines for SPP 1/03 include procedural advice for local governments in identifying natural hazard management areas--flood. I table copies of both the SPP and the associated guideline.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copy of State Planning Policy Guideline, dated June 2003, titled ‘Mitigating the Adverse Impacts of Flood, Bushfire and Landslide’ [ 4051 ].
Tabled paper: Copy of State Planning Policy titled ‘Mitigating the Adverse Impacts of Flood, Bushfire and Landslide’ [ 4052 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: According to these guidelines, natural hazard areas should be determined from a comprehensive flood plain management study based on--and I quote from page 33 of the guideline--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the process outlined in Floodplain Management in Australia: Best Practice Principles and Guidelines (the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management (SCARM) Report).
XML.Hansard-Body: The standing committee guideline does suggest the establishment of a local flood plain advisory committee as one step in the process, but it also notes that the full SCARM process can be time consuming and expensive and it may be beyond the capacity or needs of some local governments, particularly those with low growth and a low rate base. It says that at page 33 of the guideline.

The guidelines also outline the process for local governments when they are undertaking flood studies to inform the identification of a natural hazard management area--flood. So it is a local government matter.

As I said in my earlier response, this is the key point. Defining the flood line is properly the role of local government and this is, for example, exactly what the Brisbane City Council has done. As members would be aware, the BCC has now, in fact, also commenced a process to increase the height of their planning flood line. The Lord Mayor’s joint flood task force’s report, released yesterday, highlighted the fact that local government has responsibility for these matters. The report states at page 17--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The State Planning Policy 1/03 states the Queensland Government’s default position is that the 1% Annual Exceedance Probability ... flood or Q100 is generally suitable as the DFE--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: that is, defined flood event--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: for a Local Government. However, there is a provision to allow a Local Government to define the DFE as higher than the Q100.
XML.Hansard-Body: If local government wishes to establish a local flood advisory committee, as suggested by the SCARM guidelines, that is its prerogative. If it wishes to define a higher DFE, that is its prerogative. But SPP 1/03 places a clear obligation on local government to ensure that planning schemes appropriately manage and mitigate the risk of flood hazards.

The LNP has traditionally opposed state intervention in local government planning matters, but clearly the member for Lockyer seems to be supporting a greater role for the state in overriding councils. I look forward with interest to the views of local governments and the LGAQ and, most importantly, the findings of the royal commission in this matter.
Resumed from p. 457, on motion of Ms Spence--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the report of the Committee System Review Committee, titled Review of the Queensland parliamentary committee system , tabled on 15 December 2010, be noted.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (2.34 pm): It is a pleasure to have an opportunity to speak in this debate on the consideration of the review by the committee that was established by this parliament last year to consider the operation of our committee system. This process was born out of our government’s determination to ensure that we have the highest standards of accountability and integrity.

XML.Hansard-Body: There was a substantial debate about these issues during mid-2009, during which time there was some discussion about whether or not Queensland should reconsider the establishment of an upper house, as prevails in the other state parliaments of Australia. At that time a public discussion paper was issued and there was no real substantial support for the idea of the reinstitution of an upper house in Queensland. Nevertheless, a number of commentators made the astute observation that in a unicameral system there is an even higher obligation on the parliament to ensure it has the appropriate checks and balances in place to ensure checks and balances on the executive of government and to ensure the rigorous processes of the legislature.

There was a recognition by the government that our committee system had become perhaps less than it could be in relation to modern parliamentary processes, so we charged a bipartisan committee of this parliament with the task of going and having a look at other parliaments in the Westminster system--in Australia, in New Zealand, which is a unicameral system, and in other relevant jurisdictions. I am conscious that systems in both the UK and Canada were visited and were part of what informed this committee’s report.

I would like to congratulate every member of the committee and thank them for not only the hard work that they did--and I think we expect them to do that when we appoint them to these jobs--but also particularly two things: the truly bipartisan attitude that they brought to the task and a recognition that what we were doing was a root-and-branch reform that should stand the test of time, that should withstand changes of government and, therefore, should only be put forward if it enjoyed some bipartisan endorsement. I understand that there was a great deal of genuine debate in the committee meetings that were not conducted along party lines but were genuine attempts to find the appropriate way forward for our parliament and its unique circumstances. So I thank the committee members for that.

I also thank them for rising to what I think was a challenge that I set for them. I did not want a report of a review that recommended simply tinkering around the edges. I challenged the committee to think big, to see this as an opportunity. In the same way as this parliament a century ago was having spirited debates about whether or not an upper house was necessary, we should be having an equally challenging debate about how we can best ensure an appropriate system of committees in our parliament--not as a replacement of an upper house but to play some of those roles in a very effective way.

So we have before us this report of the committee, very ably led by the chair, the Leader of the House, Judy Spence. I thank Judy for the work she has done and I thank each and every member of the committee, because I do believe that there has been a very genuine effort made. I have seen a lot of committee reports in my time and they have all had varying degrees of merit, but I would have to say that I think this is one of the best reports of any committee that I have seen in a very long time. I think that speaks to the diligence with which people applied themselves.

I would like to turn now to some of the major components and recommendations. I hope to be able to table the interim government response during my contribution, but at this stage I will refer to the major architectural changes that have been recommended and outline the government’s view in relation to them.

Firstly, the report proposes to establish a Committee of the Legislative Assembly. This would be an all-party bipartisan committee that would provide for a number of new roles to be undertaken by the parliament itself. They are not new roles, but new roles for this committee to undertake. It would be a committee that would have oversight and responsibility for the governance of the parliament, not just when the parliament is sitting but the running of certain components of the parliament. So it is proposed, and the government supports, that this committee would have responsibility to determine the business of the House, the weekly business of debate times et cetera, and it would also have oversight of the standing orders of the parliament. It is not proposed by the committee, and nor does the government support, that the Speaker should be a member of the committee, although the government’s view is that the Speaker should be identified as an ex-officio member of the committee whenever it considers standing orders. I understand that everyone would be in agreement with that. It is also proposed that the committee would have responsibility for overseeing the operation of all of the committees, their resourcing and the facilities that might be made available to them. The government supports that as well.

Finally, it is proposed by the committee that this Committee of the Legislative Assembly should also take on the role of overseeing the matters that are currently undertaken by the committee for integrity, ethics and privileges. That committee undertakes a variety of functions. One very clear function is to consider complaints of a breach of privilege against a member of the House. The other major function of that committee is to consider broader matters of parliamentary entitlements and integrity related issues such as the register of interests and matters pertaining to it. It is the government’s view that that broader role can amply be undertaken by the Committee of the Legislative Assembly, but that the specific role of hearing and determining complaints of a matter of breach of privilege would not appropriately sit with this committee largely because many of the people on it are likely to be the ones most often referred for these matters given that there is a little bit of politics on these issues.

The government does not have a firm view on how that could be managed adequately and is referring to the Committee of the Legislative Assembly for further consideration the issue of how we can best ensure that we have a very robust system by which we can determine complaints against a member in relation to a breach of privilege. Having indicated that sometimes those things can be done for political purposes and have from time to time been frivolous, I think we would all acknowledge that when they are serious they are very, very serious. We have had a couple of those in recent years. I do think we have a long and well-established tradition that that committee hears those matters on a very strict bipartisan basis and the reports of those committees by and large enjoy the confidence of the House and we would want that to continue. The government will be referring that question back to the Committee of the Legislative Assembly for some further consideration.

Secondly, the committee basically recommends the abolition of almost all of the other committees of the parliament and their replacement with a series of portfolio committees, although it does recommend, and the government supports the recommendation, that we retain the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee. In relation to portfolio committees, the government endorses the recommendations that we should have a series of portfolio committees. The recommendations from the review indicate their view that there should be nine. The government has reserved its position on the number and the areas of responsibility while we look through the whole of the budget implications of that.

But in terms of the intent of the committee’s recommendations, the government supports the view that we should replace our existing committees with portfolio committees and that those portfolio committees should have three major functions: firstly, they should examine legislation within the portfolios for which they have responsibility, they should examine that legislation thoroughly between the introduction of a bill and prior to its second reading and they should not just be examining it in depth in relation to scrutiny of legislation matters and fundamental legislative principles. The government’s view is that these committees should be required by the standing orders in every bill that they examine to report on FLPs but, secondly, they should look beyond FLPs and examine the merits, the impacts and the public issues surrounding the bill. It is proposed that the committees will be entitled to have public hearings on legislation and that members of the public can make submissions to these committees about the legislation. It is my view that this will lead to better legislation being considered in the parliament and that will be a good thing for the people of Queensland. I will come back to that.

Secondly, it is proposed that these committees should take over, for the portfolios for which they are responsible, the current role of the Public Accounts and Public Works Committee--that is, they should examine projects of public works and public accounts within whatever portfolio they have, and the government supports that proposal.

Thirdly, it is proposed that these committees be charged with the responsibility of conducting estimates hearings in the portfolio areas for which they are responsible, and the government supports that proposal as well. The government also supports the proposal that during estimates committee hearings senior public servants should be able to be questioned directly by all members of the committee. However, we do acknowledge that this is a significant change for our Public Service, and we propose that in the first instance that be restricted to the right to directly question CEOs and statutory office holders within the portfolio. That is something that the government would be prepared to consider further after this year’s estimates. I am not saying we would not consider going further down the line, if you like; it is just that, given that this is a significant shift, we think it is better to stage its introduction. The CEOs and statutory officers are the accountable officers for the budgets of the portfolios for which they are responsible, so it is only reasonable that the committee should have some opportunity to question them directly. We do make the point, however, and I understand this would be accepted by the committee, that in all jurisdictions where this occurs there are very strict provisions that it is not the role of a public servant to make comment on the merits or otherwise of a policy or a program. That is a matter for a minister. Any public servant should be able to decline to answer something that is seeking an opinion from them on the merits or otherwise of a government policy. They are there to answer factual questions related to the budget papers and the operation of the organisation.

They are the three main roles that the government believes are being proposed for the portfolio committees, and we endorse that. There is a fourth proposition in the committee report that indicates these committees should also be able to undertake investigations within their portfolio areas of any events, incidents et cetera. The government has indicated in its interim response that we accept this in principle, but we do think there are issues that we will be referring to the Committee of the Legislative Assembly for further consideration before we move to implement it. I am referring to broader questions about how we would ensure that people, for example, cannot go forum shopping--that is, they have a matter considered by the CMC, they have it considered by the health complaints tribunal or the ombudsman and at the same time they want a parliamentary committee to consider it. There are a range of statutory provisions that this parliament has put in place over a long period of time under different sides of politics that establish appropriate complaint mechanisms. The parliamentary committee should not be seen as an alternative or a duplication of those. We would want to see how we might ensure that.

Equally, I think further consideration needs to be given to whether or not these committees would ever look into individual or personal cases, for example, and what sort of privacy issues there are and how we would protect the privacy of individuals in those circumstances. I think there is some more thinking and work to be done and we will refer that to the committee but, as I say, we are supporting it in principle.

It is proposed that the committees will have a significantly bigger role than they have now in the day-to-day operations of this House. If the committees are not doing their work and doing it on time, then the legislation will not be coming back into the House. So we need to recognise and accommodate the time that it will take for committees to do their job properly. To that end, it is proposed to change the standing orders to allow for a specific session on Wednesday mornings for committees to meet, to have public hearings and to do their work. The government will be supporting those proposed changes.

Equally, given that bills will now be considered in much more detail and in a much more public way prior to coming back to the House for second reading debate, it is proposed by the committee that there be some constraints put on the speaking times of members of all sides of the chamber in the second reading debate. The government supports that recommendation as well. There are a number of other recommendations that I will not go through in detail. I think they are the major ones that the government either supports or where we are proposing a change or further work that I have tried to outline.

I will conclude by making some broader comments. What this report is asking of us, as legislators and parliamentarians, goes far beyond making changes to the legislation that governs the parliament, or the standing or sessional orders. It is asking for a significant cultural shift. It is asking us to do things in a very different way. I will be honest and say that for those of us in government that is a very confronting challenge. However, when I look at the recommendations, even those that give me cause for nervousness, I see that they operate very functionally in other parliaments, that this is considered the norm in other parliaments, and that other parliaments would be surprised that significant pieces of legislation are not the subject of public hearings or public debate. We need challenge ourselves to rise to that and to meet it.

However, this system will stand or fall on the ability of people on all sides of the chamber to move to that different culture. For example, a bill goes to one of the committees. It passes through the process of a public hearing and debate within the committee. Amendments are proposed and the government agrees to accept those amendments--and I am talking about any government. If that process comes to be seen as a huge political point-scoring exercise rather than a value-adding improvement to something that matters to the people we represent, I predict that over time any government would start to walk away from accepting such amendments. I do not believe that that is the intention of the committee. Therefore, some of this is about changes to the standing orders and some of it is about changes to the legislation, but beyond all of that it is about changing us. It is about changing the culture of how we think bills should proceed.

In every parliament it is inevitable that things will get adversarial a lot of the time. It is inevitable that there will be robust debate. However, it is fair to observe that other parliaments in Australia manage legislation in a much more collegial way. Some of the adversarial nature is exacerbated in a unicameral system where the government and the Leader of the Opposition inevitably go head to head every day at times like question time. In contrast, in the Senate, for example, a lot of the work is much more likely to be done through committees and long-term political relationships develop around a legislative process. This gives us the opportunity to do some of that. I would hate to think that we could put all of the structures in place without taking the opportunity to change culture. If that were to happen, all of the hard work of this committee will have been for nothing.

We saw exactly the same zeal for reform when our current committee system was put in place in the late 1980s and early 1990s as a result of Fitzgerald, the reforms of EARC and the Goss government, and other political processes. They were equally motivated by a desire to ensure a parliamentary system that had a thriving and robust committee system that involved members of parliament from all sides of politics in a very rigorous legislative process, resulting in legislation that better matched the needs of the people who are represented in this chamber. It is also fair to say--and I think the committee report says this between the lines, if not explicitly--that some of the early hopes for our current committee system have not always been realised. This is another opportunity for us to realise them.

I conclude my remarks by again thanking all members of the committee. I particularly acknowledge the work of the chair, Judy Spence. This would not have been the report that it is if all members had not applied themselves with their considerable experience. I was not able to listen to the contribution of the Leader of the House--
Ms Spence: Over 130 years experience.

Ms BLIGH: I would have been surprised if she did not take another opportunity to mention that between them they had 130 years of parliamentary experience. That is important and I think it shows through in this report. It is a thoughtful and careful report. A good functioning and rigorous committee system, as we see in other parliaments of Australia and other jurisdictions of the Westminster system, will only survive if it is actively engaged in by both the government and the opposition. They do not change every time there is a change of government. They persist and they last the test of time, regardless of who is on what side of the chamber. That will be the test of these reforms. Now we are looking back on the reforms of EARC. In two decades time when we look back on these reforms, if they meet the test that the committee is setting for all of us, they will still be operational and they will still be regarded as strong and robust checks and balances on the government of the day.

With those few words, I commend the report. For the benefit of the House, I table the interim government response. As I have indicated, there are a number of parts of this that the government is giving further consideration to. As members would expect, those are matters of a budgetary nature and some issues that we are referring back to the CLA.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Committee System Review Committee: Review of the Queensland Parliamentary Committee System, December 2010: Interim Government Response [ 4053 ].

Hansard-Body.A: (Waterford--ALP) (2.54 pm): It was a great privilege, throughout much of 2010, to join the chair of this committee, Judy Spence, and my fellow members in exploring the opportunities to improve the democratic processes of government in Queensland. Unfortunately, democracy has a sad history in Queensland. When this parliament first began, obviously there was limited franchise with no votes for women and no votes for the first Queenslanders, the Indigenous Australians. I think that we should be careful about suggesting that the legislative council, which was abolished in 1922, was some sort of bastion of democracy and accountability. It was of a very limited franchise and did a great deal to frustrate a reformist government, which had majority support in the lower house. Since the 1922 reforms, the state has taken on a winner-takes-all approach. Between elections, this place and our committee processes have not been as good as they could have been in ensuring robust debate and strong accountability of government.

XML.Hansard-Body: When I was looking at the history of Queensland, I found a great quote about what parliament should be. With the indulgence of members, I will take a little time to read it. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Parliament is meant to be the forum in which the necessity and worth of proposed laws, including those raising revenue and appropriating funds, can be debated. It should also serve as an inquest in which all or any aspects of public administration can be raised.

The effect of modern practice is that the law is shaped outside Parliament. Ministers present bills to the Parliament which are the products of resolution in Cabinet and sometimes the Government party room (or both). Similarly, policy on executive and administrative matters is largely formed and developed outside Parliament.
Laws and policies often address highly complex matters. Formulating them requires expertise.

No Government will have all the ideas, expertise and insight on any particular topic. As well, Governments are not the only bodies which have these attributes. Whatever the expertise required, the solution to any problem is something about which people can and do reasonably differ. The best result will be produced from rational debate by those with opposing views. The community is entitled to such a result.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is a quote from the 1989 Fitzgerald report, commenting on what the parliament should be. Unfortunately, that report also commented on how parlous the state of parliamentary democracy was in Queensland, as the state was run by the executive with limited accountability to the parliament. This committee report is based on much hard work by its members. I believe that that concise statement from Fitzgerald is the underlying principle of the final committee report.
XML.Hansard-Body: The committee’s report is based on the principle that the openness of debate and the opportunity for public participation provide not only a democratic process but also good outcomes. They provide good government for the people of Queensland. Like many other parliaments, for decades we have struggled with the issue of executive dominance of the legislature. This proposal empowers the parliament, particularly those members who are not part of the government front bench--the government and non-government backbenchers, including the Independents--to examine the government, its budgets and its legislation. It also gives backbenchers the chance to contribute their expertise. To think that government is a repository of all knowledge is short-sighted. We should be taking advantage of the vast experience and diverse backgrounds of the people who are elected to this place. That is what the reforms in this report will do.

However, that of itself is not enough. We should be very careful that we do not get caught up in thinking that changing the structure is enough. Democracy will only be improved, and good government will only result, when people care about the parliamentary process. We need the people who elect us to care about the debates we have in this place and we need to ensure that what we are discussing is relevant to them. I do not think the answer is to install more politicians to oversee other politicians. The answer is to create a right of participation for Queenslanders through a committee process. This process gives every Queenslander the right to make a submission to the parliamentary process and contribute to the legislation of this state. It also brings issues into the public domain and ensures they are discussed in a transparent way.

When the committee travelled to New Zealand, what struck me more than anything else was the fact that the political culture in New Zealand accepted that parliamentary committees would provide the public with a right to participate in these processes. The members of parliament to whom we spoke said that, even though they have a unicameral legislature, the people of New Zealand would be outraged if their right to participate in the process was taken away. We in Queensland need to have that culture whereby the people are outraged when the debate in this place is shut down. Unfortunately, the history of our state has not shown that to be the case. We do need to make sure we can harness the ideas and expertise of all Queenslanders, but that requires a culture in which that input is valued.

These reforms require a brave government to implement them. For years executive governments have avoided a process such as this because, in essence, it provides a higher bar for government in this state, particularly when it comes to the question of whether committees should be able to investigate events and incidents. In the long run, we must put our short-term political ambitions aside and say that this process will deliver better government for Queensland and will mean that we can continue to ensure that people have faith in our parliamentary process.

Of course, when we talk about issues like the investigation of events and incidents, we do need to realise that these processes do not occur in a vacuum and there must be balance--a balance with the resources of committees and a balance between the competing priorities of committees. I am sure some people will ask the committees to examine their individual circumstances. The committees that I have been involved in have seen that situation occur on a number of occasions. If there are more appropriate processes, they should be followed. If committee processes and investigations can shine light where light has not been shone previously, that is something they should do.

The Leader of the House described this reform as evolutionary, and I think that is true. This is the next stage of what Fitzgerald envisioned about an empowered parliament. We even saw a process such as this proposed by EARC in the early 1990s. At the time the Queensland parliament was not ready for a committee system that provided such a robust debate as we have now. I am glad to see that our parliamentary process and government have matured since the days of Bjelke-Petersen and Fitzgerald and we are now in a position to deliver Fitzgerald’s vision.

I do want to address some of the concerns raised in the public debate about the proposal that the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee no longer be a stand-alone committee. I participated in the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee in my first term of parliament. It was something I thoroughly enjoyed and thought made a very important contribution to this place. The Scrutiny of Legislation Committee has always been restrained by the fact that its consideration of fundamental legislative principles has been divorced from the policy consideration of the bill. This process will make every committee responsible for those scrutiny of legislation responsibilities. It will ensure that those fundamental legislative principles are considered in the light of the actual policy outcomes proposed by the bill rather than this process that we have had for many years with scrutiny reports where the committee decision was that the matter be referred to the parliament for consideration. The allegation was always, yes, the fundamental legislative principle has been breached but it is justified in the circumstances. In the past it has been only parliament that could consider whether those FLP breaches were justified. Now, putting the two processes together gives more weight to those fundamental legislative principles, not less.

The other particular matter I would like to raise is an opportunity for reform in the future, and that is in relation to the estimates process. In the New Zealand parliament the estimates process has two distinct parts: a process of examining budgetary estimates to consider how budgetary priorities have been determined and how the expenditure for the coming year was considered; and a separate process of examining the annual reports of departments and going over with a fine toothcomb what happened over the previous year, how the money was spent and what the outcomes were.

At the moment, both of those functions are rolled into one process. That has meant that the estimates debate has revolved entirely around exploring the past actions in minute detail and there has been no consideration of the expenditure for the year going forward. The process should be that we come to the estimates process in July and say, ‘Minister, why did you decide to fund the road upgrade in my electorate rather than the road upgrade in the neighbouring electorate?’ and determine those priorities. Then we can come back later and say, ‘You said you would deliver this but you did not.’ At the moment we only undertake that latter consideration and not the former. I hope that is something that can be considered once this process is in train and we have developed that stronger culture of estimates processes. It is an important role.

The other specific element that I want to consider is the recommendation from the committee that the Auditor-General be given an opportunity to assist the committees in their consideration of estimates. I think that is an important one. The Queensland Audit Office does take the fine toothcomb approach. Its officers are the people who can advise committees where to start their examination of what are quite detailed budget estimates. I understand that the government response would be to support that where there is an Auditor-General report in place. I think that is a great move, and I think the Audit Office has the ability to get that detail so that members have the resources at their fingertips to ensure government is held accountable.

I thank the other members of the committee, particularly the chair and those members on that committee who have been able to put aside the political machinations of this place and put in its place a consideration of what is good for democracy in Queensland but what is also good for better government of the people we represent.

Hansard-Body.A: (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (3.07 pm): It is my pleasure to rise to speak to this committee report on the review of the parliamentary committee system. I note the contribution of the member for Waterford and all the contributions of members of the committee.
