I understand that this process was conducted in great spirit, with a genuine interest in reforming the parliamentary committee system, which is something that is certainly long overdue and which should hold the executive to account.

XML.Hansard-Body: Looking at the experience of the three members of the opposition who served on this committee, I note that we put very experienced members on it. The members for Toowoomba South, Callide and Southern Downs have contributed over 50 years in combined parliamentary service. I know that, on the government side, the Leader of the House, the former Minister for Public Works and the member for Yeerongpilly--and the Independent member for Nanango--also contribute a significant amount of experience. There was a genuine attempt, which has obviously been achieved, to come up with a better system to show that we do believe in open and transparent government--the LNP certainly does--that is accountable to the parliament and the people.

We welcome the review. I know that since it was first put into the public arena there have been significant issues that have been publicly aired. We support the recommendations. I know that there have been issues with the present Speaker, who has raised his concerns. Whilst he was criticised today in the contribution of the member for Rockhampton, I think it is interesting that consideration is being given to changing some of the recommendations in relation to which the Speaker has expressed concern. I think it is only fair that the Speaker should have been able to express those concerns and issues about the standing orders and their application and whether he should have some sort of input in that respect and also the issue of the maintenance of the parliamentary precinct. It was disappointing to hear the contribution of the member for Rockhampton--one of the most experienced members in this place. I see him scuttling back to his chair now.
Mr Schwarten: Absolutely.

Mr LANGBROEK: Here he comes. I am happy to take it, because let us have a look at some of the things the member for Rockhampton had to say in that charming contribution just before lunch. The former member for Ashgrove was in his last term when I came here. You can only take people as you find them. All I know is that when I expressed an interest in the standing orders the former Speaker, the then member for Ashgrove, was happy to impart some of his knowledge to me. The point is that when Jim Fouras made his contribution in the paper the other day it certainly led to some issues that have been addressed or will be addressed by the government in considering what they are going to do with the recommendations.

It does not add anything to the debate to have a former minister of the Crown now on the back bench carrying on like that and making reflections on the current Speaker. It needs to be said that the former minister’s contribution, the member for Rockhampton’s contribution, before lunch was a disgrace. It was a disgrace from a long-serving member of this parliament. Someone should tell the member for Rockhampton that Sir Les Patterson was a caricature, not a model for how you conduct yourself in public life. In his contribution he was having a go at the present Speaker and former Speakers because of some sort of bias and anger he has about things that happened in times long gone. He should put that behind him when we are looking at a committee like this that has made recommendations for the future of our parliament--long after he and I will be gone.

We saw contempt of the parliament shown by this former minister just last sitting week when the business of the House was suspended so that the then minister could come in here and give a valedictory. We have seen the erosion of parliamentary powers, and it is important that parliamentary committees are given authority in this place and have more powers, as we are going to see, so that members can appreciate their importance in our parliamentary system.

I note that committee members were unanimous in stating that ‘our present committee structure is under resourced, does not have sufficient influence over the executive of government, does not receive sufficient attention in the parliament and is largely unknown to the majority of Queenslanders’. That is a damning indictment from a bipartisan committee. In a unicameral system--one of course given to us by the Labor Party as a result of it having abolished the upper house--a strong parliamentary committee system provides a much needed check on unilateral actions by the executive. I think that many people are concerned at the number of MPs who are part of the executive and that leaves fewer to independently represent the community. This community has doubled in number since the last increase in the number of MPs.

Let us have a look at Labor’s track record. It does seem that the Beattie and Bligh Labor governments have set out to deliberately dilute committee powers. In the process they have effectively eroded the integrity of the committee system. I have served on the public accounts committee and it was a privilege to do so. It gave me an insight into many of the issues of the Auditor-General, but the democratic process has not been accorded the respect that it should have been in Queensland. Members have spoken in here before about the estimates committees, which have been described as a farce. Even the member for Waterford in his contribution just now acknowledged that they could be improved. We know that estimates committees have provided only a token opportunity for investigation. I have sat on those estimates committees and have seen that those reports and proceedings are soaked in layers of government self-justification and back patting.

The former member for Waterford, who was the minister for industrial relations at my first estimates committee, did not answer questions. We had very little ability to cross-examine or none at all, and half of the time available was allocated to government Dorothy Dixers. A great example of that is following the sale of Queensland Rail only 15 minutes were allocated to opposition members for questioning the Minister for Transport on this matter. In reality, even less was available as the shadow minister was thrown out by the committee chair. The reason was that she dared to try to press the minister to actually answer her questions. It was a disgrace that such a major government decision--
Mr O’BRIEN: Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise to a point of order. I was the chair of that committee. I find the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition offensive and I ask that he withdraw them.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms van Litsenburg): Order! Will the member withdraw.
Mr LANGBROEK: Madam Deputy Speaker, I ask for your ruling as to whether that is a personal reflection. I made no reflection on the chair of that committee.
Mr O’BRIEN: Madam Deputy Speaker--
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Will the member resume his seat. I ask the member to withdraw his statement.

Mr LANGBROEK: I withdraw. It is a disgrace that such a major government decision--one which the current government deliberately did not disclose during the last election--was not subject to cross-examination.

Time and time again we have seen major legislation introduced into this House and debated without in-depth consideration by an appropriately resourced committee. The Scrutiny of Legislation Committee has attempted to perform a difficult job well, but the limited time and powers to properly consider complex legislation has hampered its performance. Those on the other side of the House should hang their heads in shame. They should hang their heads in shame for their continued trampling of open and accountable government. This review has shown that the committee system is not just failing; it has failed. It has become too dominated by the government, too remote from the public and representative groups, too limited in their use and too restricted in reference and powers. The time is long overdue for reform.

So let us have a look at some of the committee recommendations. The LNP is committed to real transparency in our democratic system. We welcome the recommendations of the Committee System Review Committee. It is a pity that the government has only moved to restored the parliamentary committee system now, but we support a rejuvenated committee system. I know that the former leader has always asked for more rigorous estimates processes and other reforms that until now have never been considered.

We also need a committee system that has the ability and powers to investigate issues in more detail than can be accommodated here in the House. Committees should allow the opening up of important topics to wider consultation and input through submissions and hearings. I know committee members found that when they went to New Zealand. That is a significant matter that I have heard about from New Zealand members of parliament through their processes and through the way they look at legislation before it comes to the House.

These committees should provide a link to the people most affected by the issues in the formulation and consideration of legislation. By working in a bipartisan manner--and that is what has come out of this review--the issues can be examined more fully, tested more strenuously and the result can better reflect the needs of the community. I welcome the expansion of the committee system to include a number of statutory portfolio based committees. I heard the contribution of the honourable member for Southern Downs before lunch and I understand that is still to be finally clarified.

The review recommends the portfolio committee being able to report on ‘all aspects of government activities, including investigating and reporting on events, incidents and operational matters’. Queenslanders deserve best practice in parliament just as we do in fields such as science and manufacturing, agriculture, tourism, education and health in the 21st century. For example, the health committee would be able to investigate the management of our hospitals and the pay debacle. The LNP also supports the expanded consideration of legislation with opportunities for public input from stakeholders and citizens. I hope the government will take on board the recommendation that any exceptions to referring legislation be transparent, narrowly defined and extraordinary in nature.

In addition, I welcome the proposal to refer budget estimates to the relevant portfolio committee. This will allow committee members to develop a depth of understanding for complex matters--something that I have already pointed out does happen under the current committee system but certainly could be extended so that MPs from both sides and/or Independents could understand many of these matters better than they currently do.

I welcome the proposal that appointments to key statutory roles will require bipartisan support, including the roles of the Auditor-General, the Crime and Misconduct Commission chairperson and commissioners, the Criminal Organisation Public Interest Monitor, the Electoral Commissioner, the Information Commissioner, the Right to Information Commissioner and the Privacy Commissioner, the Integrity Commissioner and the Ombudsman. These are positions that over the years, including in the years that I have been in this place, have been subject to questions. When members have asked about particular positions they have just been told who is going to be appointed as opposed to there being proper bipartisan consultation.

I support the establishment of the Committee of the Legislative Assembly. I understand the concerns of the Speaker about his exclusion from this committee. There is conflict when it comes to the honourable Speaker’s role in referring matters and his possible inclusion. This may be an issue that deserves further consideration. I understand that is happening when it comes to standing orders matters.

The LNP welcomes the recommendation that the time allocated for ministerial statements be reduced to allow for more consideration of committee reports. The opposition understood that we had to give as well in order to make these reforms possible. As a result, for legislation considered by a committee the recommendation is that members of parliament who are not on the committee have a reduced time to speak on the bill. In addition, the review calls for Wednesday parliamentary sittings to be delayed to allow committee business from 9 am to 1 pm.

I am disappointed to see that one of the important issues of reform for this parliament was expressly excluded from consideration in this review. That is the issue of truth in parliament. I want to reiterate that the LNP is committed to reinstating section 57 of the Criminal Code to make it an offence for any person to tell a nontruth to a parliamentary committee.

Queenslanders deserve their parliament and its committees to deliver real scrutiny of the executive government. The LNP welcomes this report. However, these proposals should just be the start of bringing back honesty, transparency and accountability to the management of this state. I am committed to providing Queenslanders with a real choice at the next election--a choice for them to get their Queensland back.

Hansard-Body.A: (Callide--LNP) (3.21 pm): I am pleased to make a contribution to the consideration of the report of the Committee System Review Committee that is before us this afternoon. I was a member of that committee. I would have to say at the outset that I probably found my membership of that committee one of the more rewarding roles that I have had since I have been in this parliament. It was a rewarding experience to work with a group of senior parliamentarians, all of whom had the same aim, all of whom had the same commitment--that was a commitment to making this parliament better.

XML.Hansard-Body: I endorse the comments that have been made by the members of the committee who have already spoken--the Leader of the House, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the member for Rockhampton.
Mr Wellington: The member for Nanango.
Mr SEENEY: The member for Nanango has not spoken yet. I am sure she will endorse the comments that the members of the committee who have spoken have made.

Everybody approached the job that was given to us in a way that was about getting a better result for this parliament. We all sat on that committee as parliamentarians rather than members of particular parties or members coming from particular political philosophies. It was a gratifying thing to be part of. I cannot remember any instance where I would suggest that any member was jockeying for political advantage. I think the parliament will be better for that.

I have seen some comment in the media from people who want to express a view about the committee’s report. I wonder whether those people who seek to express a view fully appreciate the parliamentary experience of the people who made up that committee, not just in terms of years served in this place but in terms of understanding how this place works. When one gets a group of senior parliamentarians--some of them were relatively newcomers to the parliament--like the ones we had on that committee, I wonder about people who have never been a parliamentarian, who have a job as a journalist, for example, and then seem to think that they know better than the collective wisdom of that group of parliamentarians, that group of senior people who have a wealth of experience and all of whom demonstrated a commitment to making this parliament better.

I say at the beginning of my contribution to those who will inevitably criticise whatever this parliament decides to do with the report of this committee to temper that criticism with a realisation that there was a group of people involved, a group of people who have a wealth of experience in the parliament but all of whom shared a common desire, a common motivation, to make this place better, and not just for those of us who sit in here now. I do not think members would take offence at me saying that some of the members on that committee probably will not be here for too much longer; there are people who are reaching the end of their careers. We did not do it for the benefit of the members of the committee. I think the reforms that this committee recommended, if they are put in place the way they were recommended, will be reforms that the next generation of parliamentarians will come to fully appreciate. I think it is a generational change. It is without doubt a fundamental change.

I think we almost need to stop referring to it as a reform of the committee system because it is a reform of the legislative system. It is a reform of the legislative process. The way that legislation is processed through this House will fundamentally and absolutely change. That is something that is not fully encapsulated by the terminology ‘a review of the committee system’. This really is a review of the legislative process.

It will produce a process that will provide a great deal more scrutiny of the legislation that comes into the House. It will provide a great deal more involvement from members of this parliament. It will provide long awaited opportunities for members of the public to have an input into that legislation. Those three things will certainly contribute to some better outcomes and some better legislation, I think.

I reflect on the years that I have spent here in the parliament. I have often been frustrated by the legislative process. It is a frustration that I think has been shared by members on both sides of the House. I have shadowed a number of different ministers over the years and dealt with a number of different pieces of legislation. We get into what we call the consideration in detail stage where we start to consider the clauses and any number of times I have heard from the minister’s response that they realise that the debate has produced an alternative outcome that I understand they cannot accept. Once a minister gets in here with a piece of legislation that has been provided to them by their department they are locked into defending that piece of legislation.

I have seen a number of examples of ministers sent in here with pieces of legislation that they have had difficulty defending. That is just the way the system works. In saying that I am not criticising the particular ministers. It is an outcome of the way the system works. Once the legislation comes into the House the minister who is responsible for it has the job of defending it and the shadow minister--
Mr Schwarten interjected.
Mr SEENEY: It certainly is a system that is all about--
Mr Schwarten: No compromise.

Mr SEENEY: There is absolutely no room for compromise, irrespective of how obvious it is that compromise should happen and compromise is warranted. I have seen the farce here on numerous occasions where the minister wears out the carpet running backwards and forwards to get advice from the advisers who sit over there to try to explain what the legislation means and to try to answer questions that are being raised, and the inability of those often junior bureaucrats who sit there and are given the job of providing that advice to the minister.

It is a legislative process that does not produce the sorts of outcomes that we saw from the process that has been adopted in the New Zealand parliament. One of the things I was saying to some of my colleagues at lunchtime is that it is a great shame that every member of this parliament who gets to consider the report of this committee cannot go to New Zealand and watch their committee system in progress. I think that was a great experience. It was a transformation, if you like, in terms of understanding how a legislative process should work. It is certainly impossible for everybody to go to New Zealand to see that committee work in operation, but I would commend it to any member of this parliament. If you have the opportunity to go, you should take that opportunity and appreciate how the New Zealand system works.

As the Premier said in her contribution--and I agree 100 per cent with what she said--this is proposing a new process that will require a cultural change. It will require a change in culture on the part of members of this parliament irrespective of where they sit in the parliament. It will be a challenge for the people who are appointed to the legislative committees, especially the chairs of those committees, to ensure that the culture of the old committees is left behind. The culture of the old committee system that we have known will have no place in the new legislative process that we are seeking to put in place.

As the member for Southern Downs indicated, the new legislative process will certainly put a whole lot more pressure on all of us. It will mean that all of us will work a lot harder. Ministers will have to work a lot harder; shadow ministers will have to work a lot harder. I often criticise ministers, but I will also say that I have seen shadow ministers sent down here to read a speech that they know nothing about and stumble over words. They will read a speech that has been written by somebody else. I have seen plenty of government members do it, too; don’t you worry. That sort of thing will no longer be possible in the legislative process that we are putting in place.

A minister who does not have some knowledge of the legislation that they are responsible for will very quickly be exposed before a committee. Similarly, a shadow minister who sits on a committee and who does not have knowledge of the legislation that they are supposed to be shadowing will very quickly be exposed. So it goes for individual members of that committee. The legislative process will put a lot more pressure on members of parliament. It will require members of parliament to work a lot harder, and so it should be.

The other side of that is that it will provide members of parliament with a great deal more input into the legislation. It will mean that members of parliament will have input into making the laws. That is something that people out there in the community think we have under the current system but, after being here for almost 13 years, let me tell you that I have not seen too many opportunities to do that. Some of the government backbenchers have indicated to me that even they do not get a heck of a lot of opportunity to have that input. The opportunity to have input will be guaranteed under the new legislative process that this puts in place. It will give all of us as members of parliament more opportunity to be law-makers and to influence the legislation that passes through this parliament. The extra workload will well and truly be worth the rewards that can be gained from those types of opportunities.

The other people that this new legislative process will put more pressure on are the public servants. It did not surprise me one bit to hear on the grapevine that the public servants down on George Street really do not want this change to happen. It did not surprise me one bit to hear over the Christmas break that there was a degree of panic in some of the offices on George Street. The public servants were shooting memos around, recommending ways to try to stop this from happening because they, too, will come under a lot more scrutiny. The instigators of legislation down in the bowels of whichever department it is will be subject to a heck of a lot more scrutiny and will have to answer questions and justify the legislation that they have put together and given to the minister and sent into the House.

I note the Premier’s comments that the ability to examine public servants will be limited in the first instance. I accept somewhat reluctantly the Premier’s justification for that. I am reluctant to water down the ability of committees to examine the public servants and the people who are responsible for putting legislation together. I really think everyone who is responsible for a piece of legislation should be answerable to the committee. I do not mean in an aggressive way, but they should be there to explain why that legislation was put together in the way that it was. They should be there to explain the concepts that have been encapsulated in that legislation and why the legislation was written in the way it was. That is an important part of the process. While I note the Premier’s comments that the limitation that is being placed on the committees to examine public servants will be a temporary thing, I certainly hope that it is a very temporary thing. From my perspective, that change in the legislative process is the most important and the most valuable change that is being proposed by the report of this committee. It is a fundamental change to the legislative process. It is a fundamental change to the way legislation is passed--a change to the process that takes an idea and causes it to become a law.

This process will allow another set of people to have an input, and that is the general public and the interest groups. The importance of that should not be underestimated. Once again, the New Zealand experience was a valuable one. We went to New Zealand and met with interest groups who regularly prepared inputs into the legislative process. They understood the value of that opportunity to them. It reinforced to me the need for this sort of process to allow that type of input by interest groups and individuals here in Queensland.

Once again, reflecting on my experience in this place, I can think of a number of examples where that opportunity for public input would have made for much better legislation. I understand, and everyone who has been in politics for a while understands, that governments have agendas and philosophically driven programs that they need to engage. However, this process will provide interest groups with an input and influence on a government’s program and agenda at that informative stage, and that is an incredibly valuable thing. It is an incredibly valuable thing when you see it in operation. In Queensland, the general public and the interest groups will come to understand in time how valuable that opportunity is. That in itself will provide a huge incentive for us as parliamentarians to make the process work properly and make the legislative process so much better.

I also want to reinforce the comments that have been made by other committee members about the role of the CLA, the Committee of the Legislative Assembly. I have listened to alternative points of view that have been expressed since this report was made public and I have read some of the interchanges between a number of players in that debate. Can I say that I think much of the concern that has been expressed is unwarranted--very much unwarranted. The overriding principles in the report are to ensure that the running and the activities of this parliament are directed by us as parliamentarians, and that is the way it should be. All of us in political life are well acquainted with the principle of taking responsibility for our own actions--making our own political decisions and justifying them to the general public whom we represent, and that is the principle that has been carried through in the recommendations within this report. Over the time that I have been here I have seen instances where decisions have been made about this parliament that affect members of parliament by people who I do not believe had the best interests of the parliament at heart and who really did not understand the way that the parliament should work and what the parliament is about.

I conclude by saying that I think that the proposals that are in this report will make this place a better parliament for generations of Queenslanders to come. They are a fundamental change. I would say they are an overdue change. I congratulate the chairman of the committee, the Leader of the House, on the job that she did in guiding this committee to the result that is being considered by the House this afternoon. If this report is adopted--as I hope it will be--I urge every member to engage in the new culture with an open mind and to make the changes in your own mind that are necessary to make this process work for the betterment of this parliament and for all Queenslanders.

Ms MALE (Pine Rivers--ALP) (3.40 pm): I rise this afternoon to speak to the motion. I was privileged to be a member of the Committee System Review Committee and I thank the chair, Judy Spence, and all members of the committee for their dedication to the task and for the bipartisan approach to dealing with the issues that surround the operation of our current committees and the parliament. As has already been stated, the current committee system was established in the post-Fitzgerald reform era and was designed to allow for greater scrutiny of the parliament, the government and related community issues. I have been fortunate to serve on a variety of committees since my election in 2001--from the Travelsafe select committee, public works committee, public accounts committee, select committee on organ and tissue donation, various estimates committees and I am currently serving on the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee.

During this service I think it would be appropriate to say that the importance of committees in their scrutiny and review function is undisputed, but the reality of the curtailment of time, resources and content scope has meant that committees are less effective than they could be. I believe it is imperative in a unicameral legislature that we have a strong and effective committee system to review legislation and government decisions and, importantly, to open up the processes of the parliament to allow the people of Queensland to have effective and timely input into the processes and outcomes of parliament.

By creating portfolio based committees we would be giving members the opportunity to become deeply involved in specific areas of government, hopefully leading to an expertise which would better serve the scrutiny of legislation process as it affects their portfolio, as well as the public works aspect. No government holds the complete collective knowledge and expertise on any particular subject, and by allowing the wider community the opportunity to see legislation before it is presented to the House should ultimately mean better legislation, fewer negative impacts and greater ownership of the outcomes. These committees will also take over the scrutiny of the annual budget through the estimates process. With regard to this last point, we have considered the estimates process and have listened closely to committee chairs, government and non-government members and ministers. It would appear there is a consensus of opinion that the constraints of the strict rules that apply during estimates such as the strict time limits for questions, strict time limits between government and non-government members and lack of ability to question senior public servants means that the process does not flow as effectively as it could. With the opening up of scrutiny of the government through right to information reforms, the role of the information, integrity and privacy commissioners and ongoing publication of information by and about government through websites and other publishing mechanisms, it is time to open up the senior echelon of the Public Service through closer scrutiny of its role in public policy and decision making.

The committee thought carefully about how committees currently operate with regard to composition, timing, general business, openness to the public and the media. In Queensland our committees find their meetings sandwiched in between legislation debate, other meetings and functions at Parliament House. Other countries have dedicated committee time, dedicated meeting rooms and are predominantly open to the public and the media. There is also the ability for other members of parliament to sit in on committee hearings that particularly interest them or are in their area of expertise. Recommending dedicated committee time on a Wednesday morning of a sitting week and opening the process up allows more interaction between interested members and ministers, and it means that committee business is being placed in a position of prominence and will allow members of parliament to make their own submissions on behalf of their constituencies to legislation that will affect them. I expect the new committee system will place an additional workload on committee members and the committee chair in particular, but it will also mean that local members will also have to consider each piece of legislation much more carefully than they do at present. I think the effectiveness and appropriateness of legislation will improve and I also believe that the level of debate in the House will become more effective and useful and hopefully less repetative.

The Committee System Review Committee has made historic recommendations which will impact significantly on the current operation of the Queensland parliament, its committees, its members and its staff. I would encourage all members to embrace this change, be patient and constructive during the process of altering how our committees work and, most importantly, to inform the people of Queensland in their electorates that we value their opinions, we want them to take more interest in the place that makes the laws of the land and we want them to become involved in our democracy. I recall the quote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: When you do nothing, you feel overwhelmed and powerless. But when you get involved, you feel the sense of hope and accomplishment that comes from knowing you are working to make things better.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I hope the people of Queensland and the members of the Legislative Assembly grab this historic opportunity for change--that they get involved and make the parliament work in a much more effective manner. To this effect, I commend the report to the House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Gaven--LNP) (3.46 pm): Change is inevitable. Organisations that do not evolve stagnate, wither, become irrelevant and either die or are bypassed. The central tenet of the discussion today is that we have been asked to embrace a whole new world of parliamentary legislative review and the processes to achieve that. The 55 recommendations have been available for consideration for three months. The government has responded today and largely supports most of the recommendations. In that time some key concerns have been raised by many parties, including the Speaker, and they have been noted. The members of the committee have in 12 months produced a document suggesting quite a radical change to the committee system and what they must do.

XML.Hansard-Body: There are politically greatly expanded roles for both opposition and government members, possibly including all members, inclusive of backbenchers. It would seem that the review panel has decided that the existing committee structure is really as irrelevant as it seems to be, as external and internal parties have consistently stated. Personally, I can vouch for the irrelevance and petulance of existing committees having been on one occasion affected myself when my confidential submission to the economic committee on microfinance options and the GFC locally was treated with contempt here in the House. It was either leaked or my request for confidentiality until formal reporting was ignored. I have seen too many other submissions treated with similar contempt. This may not be the entire fault of the committee members or the committee process itself but, moreover, due to the failing of the design of the current system of those committees and their functions.

These recommendations propose many things, and I want to discuss some which I believe are both significant and possibly ones where I may be able to offer some constructive comment. I say so because I went to New Zealand myself with the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee last year as a guest of the New Zealand parliament for a week. I went with the member for Bundamba and the member for Brisbane Central. They are not in the House here today, but we have discussed this. Our intention was to see those committees functioning, holding public hearings, scrutinising legislation and effectively doing the consideration of legislation in detail step that we presently do as the last step here in the Queensland parliament. Immediately after the ministerial first reading speech is when these committees effectively deal with that. We saw one committee in complete detail over the week and we observed two other committees operating in lesser detail over a full day and into the evening. We spoke to those consultants who give current scrutiny advice, legislative advice and also received a detailed overview from Sir Geoffrey Palmer, the former New Zealand Prime Minister and Deputy Leader of the Labour Party.

Honourable members, we had done this after a most impressive presentation by a New Zealand member and head of their national scrutiny of legislation committee in Canberra 12 months earlier. I was present when that member presented what was an enormously lengthy presentation. I found New Zealand’s process potentially more responsive to the needs of constituents, parliamentarians and the system. They gained greater involvement of members in legislation--also the public--and they probably generated better legislation for all. I congratulate Mr Charles Chauvel, who is the MP for Wellington, for his great efforts in sharing those personal experiences with us and leading us to what were the sort of things we generated out of that experience.

I think the New Zealand system should be trialled here in full. It is important to say that I believe there are some messy recommendations and there are some extra ones that we might consider, based on my observation and research, and I would think over time it is possible that they may be included. I acknowledge the cumulative years of experience of those on the review committee and I certainly do not seek to undermine anything that they have said. But I believe that they may have missed a few points when they went to Wellington and were observing those committees in action. I also appreciate that the committee visited Canada and reviewed that country’s processes.

Broadly, the committees need to reflect the major portfolio or policy areas and restrict themselves to those areas. We have nine committees proposed here. Of course, New Zealand has a few more, but that is appropriate. The reduction to seven, which has been considered, and condensing some of the portfolios would seem to be inappropriate. I believe that it could defeat the process and the outcomes that we all wish for.

The specific areas themselves that have been listed--health, education, environment and resource management, finance and administration, legal affairs, police and public safety, social affairs, transport and infrastructure, and the PCMC with the Committee of the Legislative Assembly--all seem appropriate. In New Zealand, of course, they have added the Maori and Pacific Islanders and native title demands, because there is a huge demand for parliamentary consideration of those matters. In some ways we are fortunate not to have to include those considerations to a large extent, but in some ways one might consider that ATSI considerations are probably equally as important in view of what is considered in New Zealand. I would put it to members that ultimately it may be that we should consider ATSI as a separate portfolio.

I see the list submitted in the government’s response, and I think its response is appropriate. My observations are consistent with many of the proposed recommendations. As I have said, committees are part of the parliamentary process. So an agreed in-parliamentary-week time, as has been described clearly by the member for Pine Rivers and others, set aside for committee meetings and hearings is entirely appropriate. That is what is done in New Zealand. All committees, except in circumstances like the PCMC and parts of finance, should be open to the public, broadcast and recorded for public consumption. People actually listen to them. Public hearings are considered a crucial part of the committee process. You get all sorts of people attending and all sorts of results come out of it. To facilitate these committees they use video links for people to make submissions and representations. That should be encouraged as well. It increases public participation. It also facilitates the process whereby local, regional and national experts might also be involved. Similarly, it allows for consultation by key staff who work full time for those committees to provide advice and who will also take back the legislative response and advice from the committees.

The homes of the committees and staff need a permanancy. As has been discussed today, certainly we will require additional space, which is what happens in New Zealand, and certainly hearings need to be held close to the public so that there is public transport and ease of getting in and out--particularly for those who might be from all different types of life, different ages and that sort of stuff--to make it easy for people to attend.

Critically, in New Zealand in many cases the committee chairs are opposition members, with great success and a close cooperative spirit. I repeatedly saw this occurring and it occurs in more than two committees. The recommended proposal is for the government to provide the chair, ostensibly to help facilitate the process of governing. I am not saying that that is not an appropriate step, but in New Zealand what they do seems to work very well. I am not convinced by arguments to date, put forward on the basis of observations other than that of New Zealand, that this may not be the appropriate step. But certainly the issue of the PCMC chair being a non-government member seems entirely appropriate. I say so because, as I say, I sat through multiple committee hearings and I think that when you get to a situation where you may well be disagreeing, sometimes having a person who is trying to be impartial--and that may be an opposition member--means you tend to get a result. Anyway, suck it and see. We might see what happens with our proposal.

I totally agree that the process of the consideration in detail occurring early is the only way forward and that in practice achieves a better result in legislation. Certainly in New Zealand it does. The extra work for us all is considerable. Many members may not always be capable of completing the task. That certainly occurred in New Zealand. So a lot of help is needed and it is appropriate to provide it. It is wide process in that what some people need is different. So you need to get an idea as they go along.

Do not get a shock: I believe that it is going to cost, at a starting price, based on the numbers that were given to us in New Zealand, about $17 million. That comprises $10 million for the committee itself, $4.5 million for capital outlays and $2.5 million to $3 million for consultants--and I think they are needed. I think the figures are probably the best assessment and they are based on the New Zealand information. We had a thorough presentation on that. It is very expensive but, when all is said, you tend to only get what you pay for. The public seemed to like it, but it makes some members, some public servants and certainly some members of the public uncomfortable. In New Zealand’s multiparty system it is even harder, but they still seem to make it work because the key is that people want it to work. They waste less time in parliament itself and, strangely, they have now moved to a process where they vote electronically and not in person. That seems to work, too.

Sir Geoffery Palmer, the ex-deputy Labour leader and former Prime Minister, as I said, certainly gave us a great insight into the downside problems. He felt that a professional group of ex-politicians, legal advisers giving ongoing advice with links in, would fill the gaps that occur. They have a regular process of review of outcomes and so do the consultancies. So in other words, they are both being reviewed and then they review one another as it goes along. Like all others, Sir Geoffrey Palmer felt that the system made them stronger, not weaker. I think those things were said here today, particularly by the members for Rockhampton, Southern Downs and Callide.

New Zealand certainly has two tiers of government, whereas we have three tiers. As a state, we really need to justify the expenditure on a state legislature. Honourable members, the last 10 years may be seen as not justifying much of that cost. I am a federalist and I support the issue of the pre-eminence of the central government, but where states must have that provincial voice, which is needed in Queensland, and that provincial voice must be heard and appropriate outcomes delivered, it is appropriate to have a state legislature that considers legislation in a more compassionate way. In a regional, decentralised state like Queensland, as we have certainly experienced most recently with the floods and the cyclones, we are uniquely better placed to justify that extra need.

There are different eras in parliamentary history: 1859, the separation from New South Wales; 1901, Federation; 1922, the abolition of the upper house and the unicameral parliament; and 1990, Fitzgerald. As stated, in the 19th century committees were very active and had greater legislative input. The 20th century saw states governing almost by decree. Really, the only chance was at the ballot box, where success or failure was determined every three years. Labor was the natural party of government and it saw no need for greater input until the split of 1956. To be fair, at that time Menzies’ style of governing was paternalistic and rhetorically anticommunist, but he was very close to the values that a lot of the Labor Party shares today. In many ways there was the belief that ‘what you don’t know won’t necessarily come back to hurt you’. That was the enduring philosophy.

Committees encourage a diversity of opinion, and that was deemed inappropriate at the time--and that lasted for 100 years. I wonder if 2010 will be another era in Queensland’s parliament in our steps of change and our own history. The fact that a bipartisan group came to these conclusions is testament to the vitality of government here at a time when there is arguably parliamentary decline just south of the border. Remember, we split from New South Wales in 1859. That does not mean that we have done everything right within portfolios and maybe collectively we need this new structure to correct some very serious deficiencies.

The critical three tasks that the new committees have been asked to have under the changes are review, review of the FLPs and wider community consultation. They are the most critical and enduring changes that will come out of these changes. It certainly may well see a far more successful estimates process and may actually allow both government and non-government members to have a more relevant and appropriate system. It may well be just as adversarial but will most likely relate to the real point of debate necessitating clarification, excision or, maybe just occasionally, exposure. I see it as rather fitting that one member of the committee--that is, the member for Rockhampton--has already stated that he is retiring at the next election. The enduring legacy of parliamentary service is not often what one takes away but what one leaves behind. It may be that in time all participating members of this review may be judged very kindly for the production of a series of reforms that both take us back to the aspirations of those who initiated self-government for Queensland and take us all forward in the efficiency and fairness of state legislation in an enduring manner.

Hansard-Body.A: (Nicklin--Ind) (4.00 pm): It gives me a great deal of pleasure to rise to participate in this debate on the report of the parliamentary committee system and especially to follow that contribution from the member for Gaven, who always gives interesting and very informative contributions. More importantly, it gives me a great deal of pleasure to see you, Mr Deputy Speaker Powell, as a member of the opposition in the Speaker’s chair playing an important role in the conduct of this parliament.

XML.Hansard-Body: Today is history in the making. Earlier today students from North Arm Primary School visited me at parliament. They popped in to the chamber and I shared with them what was happening--the fact that we were seeing a significant change in the way our parliament will operate in the future. Perhaps it is as significant as the day the Queensland parliament voted to do away with the upper house.

I congratulate the Leader of the House on the report. I note that all 55 recommendations were unanimous. The committee had representatives from the government, the opposition and the crossbenches. My Independent colleague the member for Nanango was on that committee. Whilst sometimes the media wants to promote the parliament as always fighting, what we saw here was all members of parliament, irrespective of their political persuasions, prepared to sit around the table and look at how we can improve the method of how our parliament operates in Queensland. I have no doubt in my mind whatsoever that after initial teething problems we will see a significant improvement in the way our Queensland parliament will operate in the future.

I note that in the report the Leader of the House referred to how the members of the committee did not just dream up these recommendations; they took time and studied how parliaments around the world operated so that we could learn from their experiences. I think that is what we need to do and always focus on when new laws are coming into parliament. Before we lock ourselves in, let us make sure that there is not another country or state in Australia perhaps doing similar things. Let us see how we can improve what we do in Queensland. I congratulate the Leader of the House on this report. It is great to see how she has come to this House with recommendations after studying how other parliaments operate not only in Australia but also around the world. I note that a number of members in the past have called for--and in this report there is reference to a proposal for--an upper house. I will never support calls for an upper house. I think we are overgoverned in Australia. I see this as a way to respond to calls for better scrutiny and improvement of laws that come through state parliament.

When I reflect on some of the laws that previous parliaments have passed whilst I have been in parliament--in particular the amalgamation of local governments which was a very contentious matter in Queensland--I wonder whether, if we had had a committee system such as the Leader of the House has proposed, the government of the day would have still boxed on with the amalgamation of councils. I know it is still a very contentious issue in Queensland in many areas, particularly on the Sunshine Coast where there continues to be very strong moves to deamalgamate. I suppose much will depend on the outcome of the next election to see if the government changes and, if an alternative government is formed, if there will be that will to allow a referendum for that issue of deamalgamation to be raised. I believe there is a greater capacity under this new proposal for scrutiny of proposed legislation to make sure that we have the best bills possible.

Another matter I want to reflect on is the government’s amendment to the regulations on the issue of taking planning away from the third largest council in Queensland and handing that planning for a new community on the Caloundra South area to the Urban Land Development Authority. I maintain that it was a wrong move. I think it was simply the government exercising and flexing its muscle. I wonder what may have happened if we had had a different committee system operating when the government made that decision. I refer the Leader of the House to recommendation No.15, which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Committee recommends that all committees consist of six members with three members nominated by the Leader of the House and three members nominated by the Leader of the Opposition to reflect the composition of the non-government membership in the House.
XML.Hansard-Body: The current practice is that when committee membership is being canvassed the Leader of the Opposition approaches the Independents and the crossbenches to see what committees we would like to be involved in. I understand that this is simply a continuation of that process, but I would like the Leader of the House in her reply to clarify that. It is intended to ensure that under this new proposal there will be an opportunity for members of the crossbenches--for us the Independents--to have fair representation on these new committees.
Mr Moorhead: You can participate wherever you like.

Mr WELLINGTON: I am aware of that. I think it is very important that it is recorded in Hansard that that is the intention--that is, that the crossbenches will continue to be able to play an important part in committee recommendations. I look forward to this matter proceeding with further debate.

Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP)
(4.06 pm): I rise to speak in this debate in relation to the recommendations of the review of the parliamentary committee system chaired by Leader of the House, the Hon. Judy Spence MP, and committee members from both sides of the House. First of all I commend the committee for its very comprehensive report into the parliament’s structure, which was very much in need of a review. As a modern parliament it is our responsibility to ensure that our work is relevant, accountable and current to the issues of the day and to the lives of Queenslanders. I fully support setting aside a specific time period for committees to meet. When a member is not sitting in the legislative chamber there are always competing demands on their time during the intervals through a variety of meetings and events. As one of the more experienced MPs in the House, I have been involved in and chaired a number of parliamentary committees including estimates, members ethics and parliamentary privileges and environment and resources committees. All of these committees are relevant to the work of the House and the government of the day. In relation to the investigations and reports of all of those committees, a great deal of public consultation and scrutiny of the government and parliament have taken place. Consultation with various stakeholders, interest groups and the general public is so important to make sure that changes to legislation into the future are relevant to our economy, our environment and to the wellbeing of Queenslanders.

Under the proposed system, giving those bipartisan parliamentary committees the opportunity to look in detail at legislation before the House would mean a member’s time in the parliament would be more effective, ensure more relevant debate, a better understanding and engender more agreement on the finer points of the bill before it is passed by the parliament. This would mean that the opposition would be given an opportunity to comprehensively scrutinise and further consult on aspects of a bill. With that, parliamentary committees may also be able to look at various aspects of public concern within government departments, government activities, current and future policy areas and use of service providers and non-government organisations, for example. Topics that could be examined may include alcohol and drug abuse, disaster management, bullying in schools, project management et cetera. During the estimates committee process the same committees would have better knowledge and more experience in relation to a portfolio area when cross-examining ministers and departmental heads.

The proposed Committee of the Legislative Assembly, already endorsed by the Premier, will comprise senior members of both sides of the House and will be responsible for overseeing the new committee system, as well as ensuring that into the future the appropriate facilities and resources are provided to support the wide-ranging work of the committees. However, it is important that two current committees remain for the purposes of maintaining the integrity of government, the parliament and its members: the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee and the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee.

For many years I chaired the former Members’ Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee, so I realise the importance of having a bipartisan committee as a stand-alone committee. In the past many senior members of parliament from both sides of the House have been referred to the committee by opposing parties in relation to their ethical conduct, particularly during the heat of debate during question time. The work of the ethics committee included examining the arrangements for maintaining a register of interests where members are required to detail property, financial interests, membership of parties, bodies and associations and other interests that could foreseeably raise a conflict between members’ private interests and their duties as members. The committee is also responsible for parliamentary privilege, which is the right to speak freely in the House without the risk of defamation, allegations of contempt, citizens’ rights of reply and monitoring the functions of the Integrity Commissioner. Regardless of the right of privilege of members, the committee needs to ensure that members do not attempt to deliberately mislead the House in the course of their debate. These checks and balances are required to ensure that elected members recognise that honesty and morality are standards that are expected of them. This should not be the role of a committee that monitors the overall effectiveness of the entire committee system and provides the facilities and resources for the committee system. The integrity committee has a specific role in relation to an individual member’s behaviour in the House and it is important to maintain that status as a committee of backbenchers for this purpose only.

Likewise, the specific functions of the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee, the PCMC, are to monitor and review the performance of the functions of the CMC. The CMC is unique in that it has overall responsibility in relation to major and organised crime investigations, police and official misconduct investigations, complaint resolution research, corruption prevention and witness protection. The parliamentary committee has a continual role in monitoring and reviewing the CMC, and also conducts specific inquiries in respect of matters pertaining to the CMC. It is through the committee that the CMC is accountable to the parliament and to the people of Queensland. Therefore, it is very important that this function remain independent of other committee processes.

I am concerned that the role of the Speaker and some of the functions undertaken by the Speaker’s office may be unduly modified. I trust that issues will be resolved through further discussions with the Speaker’s office and the Office of the Clerk of the Parliament.

These reforms are certainly visionary, and some aspects of the report and recommendations require examination in relation to the future workings and deliberations of the parliament, and the machinations and effectiveness of the government of the day.

Mr SHINE (Toowoomba North--ALP) (4.13 pm): At the outset I acknowledge the tremendous amount of work that has been done by the members of the committee. I congratulate them for the effort that has gone into the report that we are debating today. This is an historic review and an historic report. It is important to realise that what we adopt of it will apply for generations to come. Therefore, it is important that we consider very carefully the recommendations, because they will apply not just to this parliament, in which the Australian Labor Party is the government, but also to other parliaments. With the passage of time, different parties will be in government and different points of view and different personalities will prevail. Therefore, it is important that we get the principles right. If we look back through history to what parliaments did 50 or 150 years ago, we cannot know what the personalities involved were like. Therefore, it is important that today we concentrate on the principles.

The crux of the recommended reforms is that we adopt a committee system similar to that which operates in New Zealand. I walked to the chamber with an honourable member who will make a contribution later. He told me that this is not quite the same as the New Zealand system as some aspects of that system are missing. I will be interested to hear his contribution later on. Nevertheless, I am somewhat familiar with the New Zealand system as some time ago the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee, which I chair, travelled to New Zealand to look at other aspects for our committee work. Whilst there, we came across the system that operates and were informed about it. As a result of that, I think everyone on our committee has turned out to be a supporter of this type of committee system, which operates similarly to the estimates system in the Senate, et cetera. However, this goes further than that as the committee will deal extensively with every piece of legislation that comes before the House, except urgent pieces of legislation, as I understand it. That is quite significant. As a former minister I wonder how someone in that position will view the world knowing that their legislation is to be examined with great scrutiny by all sorts of experts and will not become law for at least six months. However, I am sure ministers will adjust to that, as they have in New Zealand and elsewhere.
I was pleased that the committee did not recommend the resurrection of the upper house, the Legislative Council. I think that would be most unpopular.
Mr Moorhead interjected.

Mr SHINE: The honourable member mentions a particular party. I recollect in 1967 handing out how-to-vote cards for a referendum. There were two issues: one was the important one that we all remember in relation to Aborigines being counted in the census; the other one related to the nexus between the numbers in the Senate and the House of Representatives. A party, then called the Democratic Labor Party, was the only party that voted against that and urged the no case. Its campaign was, ‘No for no more politicians’. Despite the Liberal and Country parties, the ALP and others, including the Communist Party no doubt, all favouring that referendum, it was defeated notwithstanding that the party opposing it had a small percentage of the vote. Therefore, the idea of having more politicians and another house of parliament is not popular. I am sure the committee did not take too long to work that out as well.

My major concern relates to the role of the Speaker. It is proposed that he be left off the major committee that will oversee all of the other committees. I have concerns about that because the Speaker has played an integral role in the running of this parliament since its inception, which is a model followed by the House of Commons and parliaments in other parts of the Commonwealth and other democratic countries throughout the world. Before we discard that past role, we have to look very carefully at why we are doing so. If there is a defect in the report, it is that it does not give an explanation as to why the role is being discarded. It is pretty light on in relation to that aspect of the matter. That is a mild criticism but, nevertheless, before we toss the baby out with the bathwater it should be explained in great detail why we are casting aside decades, if not centuries, of tradition.

I asked the Parliamentary Library to do a little bit of research. I notice from the appendix provided by the committee that in Queensland, from 1860 to about 1988, we have had various kinds of select committees and committees of that nature. It seems that there has always been a parliamentary building committee. I asked the library to do some research to see whether or not the Speaker or the President was a member of that committee. In the short time I gave them they discovered it is likely that either the Speaker or the President was a member of that committee from its inception in 1860 and certainly until the last one in 1987-88 as well as several in between which were picked at random. It appears to me that it has been our tradition to always include the Speaker or the President as the chair of that committee, no doubt holding both a deliberative and a casting vote. That is something that our forefathers--or foremothers for that matter--were happy with over a long period, in my submission to the House, for no doubt good reason. From the point of view of our own Queensland history, it is important that we are conscious of it and no doubt adhere to it.

I also refer to the committee’s own research, particularly to pages 13 and 14 of the report. The committee itself quotes the example of the parliament of Canada and the National Assembly of Quebec where the presiding officer appears to be the chair of the relevant committee in those two instances. There is no explanation given as to why then he should be dropped from our committee when those two examples were given.
On page vii the foreword from the chair of the committee states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The committee members who worked on this current review of our committee system were unanimous in their concerns that our present committee structure is under-resourced, does not have sufficient influence over the executive of government--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: And it goes on. I think we can all agree that the executive of government does have all power over the legislative functions here, including the committee system, and that is not a desirable thing. In my view of the world, having the Leader of the House--irrespective of the personality and perhaps looking at it in 10 or 15 years time--as chair of that committee instead of the Speaker merely entrenches the executive’s control over that committee. The Leader of the House is primarily in charge of government business to see that it gets through, whereas the Speaker has always had a bipartisan and impartial role. It seems to me that the committee itself, through its own research, should support my contention, as would our own history of Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body: I also have concerns about the lay membership of the PCMC. It sounds like a good idea on the face of it. However, we are a parliament, we are parliamentarians, we are representatives of the people. Therefore, it is inconceivable in that notion that laypeople or people other than parliamentarians should form part of the parliamentary group to oversee this body. That is our duty. That is why we are elected. We are here to represent 30,000-odd people each. We should not escape our responsibilities by appointing other people to do that for us. That is our responsibility. That is our democratic system. We should not pass it on to people who are selected by us as opposed to doing it ourselves--ourselves being people elected, not selected, by the people of Queensland. To my mind, it is contrary to our democratic system that we should do that notwithstanding that the motives in themselves may well be commendable.

Parliamentarians can be dealt with by our integrity committees far more easily than members of the public can. If the integrity committee or the House, on a recommendation of the integrity committee or its own motion, were to deal harshly with a member of the public that would not be perceived well in the public domain. I think it is much easier for us to self-discipline fellow members of parliament. There is a number of reasons why we should proceed with caution in terms of laypeople sitting on parliamentary committees.

Finally, I make some comments in relation to the existence of the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee itself. I note that the thrust of the report--and I do not think it gave too many reasons--is that it be abolished and its function be taken over by the CLA. As I understand it, because of such discussions and considerations, that is unlikely. I hope it is not proceeded with because it is not appropriate. I listened carefully to the comments of the member for Mount Ommaney, who is a former chair of that committee’s predecessor, and I agree with her entirely. Why is that? There is a number of reasons. The Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee and its predecessor the Members’ Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee have operated continuously with differing membership in every parliament since 1995 and they have been most successful. During this time the committee has produced 112 reports, including 50 relating to complaints of an ethical or privileges nature not including a citizen’s right of reply. In all but one instance of those 50 ethical or privileges complaints the report of the committee has been unanimous. The reality is that these committees have worked hard to bring down unanimous reports on often very difficult matters infused with political implications in a very non-partisan manner. In this way the objectives of the parliament have largely been met by the enforcement of a transparent ethical machine without undue politics intruding. Importantly, individual members have not been mistreated by the committees without expense to the ethics regime.

Under the recommendations in the report there lies an inherent, continuing potential conflict of interest with senior party leaders, in particular senior ministers, shadow ministers or their delegates, comprising the membership of the ethics and privileges committee. This is so because it is the conduct of their cabinet or shadow cabinet ministers that they are most often called upon to judge.

The other point of course is that most other Australian lower houses have a standing membership of their ethics and privileges committee. For example, the Commonwealth House of Representatives, the New South Wales and Western Australian lower houses do not have current ministers serving on their ethics and privileges committee. New Zealand, the jurisdiction which the proposed new committee system most closely resembles, has a separate privileges committee along with a separate business committee and a separate standing orders committee. An examination of the reports of the ethics committee over the past three years indicates that all but one of the 15 matters referred to the ethics committee regarding the conduct of members reported on during that period were the result of an allegation by or against a minister, a leader of the opposition or a deputy leader of the opposition. So the main players are the ones most often likely to appear before such a committee. To have them comprise the committee is contrary, in my submission, to common sense. It has been successful. As I indicated, it is not broken and does not need to be fixed. However, it avoids conflict of interest and is consistent with practice in other states and in the Commonwealth. In my humble submission, it should stay the same.

Finally, I place on the record my disappointment in the criticism of the Speaker this morning. To my knowledge, this Speaker has been extremely highly regarded inside this House, on both sides of this House and outside this House since he took over that very responsible position. He is a person of the highest calibre and character. To my mind, he deserves the support of this House, including the people in leadership positions in this House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Indooroopilly--LNP) (4.28 pm): In my maiden speech to this chamber almost two years ago, I referred to one of my predecessors in the seat of Indooroopilly when it was known as Toowong and the MP at the time was Ian Prentice, who was a member in this House from 1980 to 1983. I mention Ian Prentice because he is probably best remembered as being part of that ginger group of Liberal MPs at the time who crossed the floor over the establishment of a public accounts committee. The fact that a public accounts committee was such an important issue in the 1980s indicates how important a strong committee system is to the effective working of this parliament and to good governance of the executive government. Obviously that public accounts committee was not formed at the time. It eventually came in the late eighties, and obviously we had a far more comprehensive committee system established post the Fitzgerald reforms in the nineties. For many years I covered this chamber as a journalist. I can say that the lack of an effective, functioning and inquisitive committee system was a great frustration to me as a journalist because there were many things that obviously were not being disclosed in relation to the functioning of parliament and government.

XML.Hansard-Body: A good committee system is important to ensure that scrutiny of the executive government is appropriate. Good and effective governance does require the power of executive government to be tempered. It needs to be restrained by appropriate democratic processes, procedures and institutions. Through that kind of scrutiny alternative views can be heard. Government decisions can be challenged and there is an ongoing process of evaluation and review of government policies and practices. This is even more important, of course, in Queensland, being the only state in Australia with a unicameral parliament. The absence of an upper house, as we have seen throughout Queensland’s history since it was abolished in 1922, has seen governments that have dominated parliament often with very large majorities.

While there are external bodies that have been established to scrutinise many of the activities of parliament, there are two clear limitations to these bodies. One is that they are established through legislation with clearly limited powers and functions. The other is that who appoints people to those external bodies is often the government that they are appointed to scrutinise. That raises quite legitimate questions in terms of independence. As I said, with the absence of an upper house we do need to have an effective committee system. As Fitzgerald said in his reforms, it is one way to ensure a far better functioning executive government. As I said, while those committees were brought in post Fitzgerald, today what we are seeing are fundamental reforms to beef up that committee system and to improve the failings and inadequacies of that committee system as it exists at the moment.

To demonstrate the reality of how ineffective that current committee system is, I think the majority of Queenslanders would be completely ignorant of the fact that we do have a committee system in this parliament. The fact that it remains underresourced and limited in its powers may be a consequence of having such little notoriety amongst the public.

So today we are taking note of the report, the Review of the Queensland parliamentary committee system . As I said, these are fundamental reforms and I do welcome many of these reforms that we are discussing. These reforms will give an unprecedented opportunity for MPs to comment and to scrutinise government legislation before it is debated and voted on in parliament. It will also give the public much better access and improve its scrutiny of the legislative procedures and processes. Hopefully, that will provide a much better opportunity for better legislation, and better laws hopefully mean better government.

Inevitably, as politics is part of the parliamentary process, some people will look at these reforms and look at who are the winners and who are the losers. Does it favour the government? Does it favour the opposition? The reality is we should ask the question: are Queenslanders the winners out of this, irrespective of who may be in power at the time? I think what these reforms do is produce a better government and a better parliamentary process, and that is better for the Queensland public.

There are two points in the report itself that I would like to particularly mention. One is that, while there is greater scrutiny and the establishment of these committees does provide greater opportunity to scrutinise legislation, it is important that a government that wins power has the ability to function and to administer effectively. Therefore, it is important to have a look at that and ensure that the legislation going to committees is not held up unduly. There is a process and provisions here to provide urgency for legislation and also the six-month limitation. It is important that that is maintained.

The other point in the report that I would mention specifically is in relation to the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee. I am currently a member of that committee. I do note the comments by the chair of the committee, the Hon. Judy Spence, where she says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... we are concerned that the public has little understanding of the work or scrutiny function of this committee--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: that is, the PCMC--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: or indeed its capacity to undertake its responsibilities. Consequently, we are recommending the inclusion of lay members on this committee and a greater use of open and publicly broadcast proceedings of its meetings.
XML.Hansard-Body: Can I just raise one concern about that. While I am in favour of greater scrutiny of all committees, the reality is that the scrutiny by the PCMC is often of many confidential matters--matters that are raised with us by members of the public in the belief that they will be held confidential. Obviously common sense, I am sure, will need to prevail in terms of the public broadcasting of any of the deliberations of that committee. The issue of lay members also needs to be carefully clarified in terms of those members appearing on that committee. It is a Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee, a review by parliament of the CMC. It is not a question of the broader public being members of that committee and scrutinising the dealings of the CMC. There are other avenues for that to occur.

Finally, in terms of the limitations on members speaking in this chamber following scrutiny of legislation by a committee and the reduction in the time limits for speaking, it was Mark Twain who once said that he would have written less but he did not have the time. I encourage members to realise that sometimes being more efficient in what they say can make what they say more effective. Given those comments on the importance of efficient speaking, I will conclude my remarks there.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP) (4.37 pm): I, too, rise to speak to this report on the Queensland parliamentary committee system.
