Whilst I am very cognisant that I remain one of the inexperienced, newer members of this chamber--particularly compared to many of my colleagues and certainly those who sat on this Committee System Review Committee--and that I am still learning about the operations of the parliament, I do know enough to know that what we are debating and discussing this afternoon is probably one of the most significant reforms in the Queensland parliament in recent decades, certainly in the post-Fitzgerald era.

New, as I am, I agree wholeheartedly with the Committee System Review Committee members and some of the comments just made by the member for Indooroopilly. Our present committee structure is certainly underresourced and does not have sufficient influence over the executive of the government, nor does it have sufficient attention within parliament itself. As the member for Indooroopilly just pointed out, the committee system probably remains all but an unknown to the majority of Queenslanders.

All of this is in the rather unique environment of being a unicameral parliament--that is, having only a lower house and not an upper house. I must support the comments made by a number of members whom I have heard speak in the House that this is probably a far more beneficial response than reinstating the upper house. It is certainly more cost-effective for Queenslanders and for the taxpayers.

Combined, these deficits have led to scepticism and cynicism by not only opposition parties but also certainly the broader community, particularly with respect to accountability, transparency and scrutiny of legislation, public policy and public administration. This cynicism is perhaps best exemplified through the farce that is the current budget estimates process.

In what I can only describe as a highly risk managed piece of theatre, shadow ministers ask a range of questions from the serious to the scuttlebutt while ministers dodge, weave, prevaricate, stall or simply blatantly refuse to answer them. The majority of questions asked relate to previous expenditure, not to examining the budget for the year to come. The time allocations--for example, two hours of questioning for a Health portfolio of some $8 billion--mean that the real focus for both sides becomes nailing that seven-second grab for the media, not seriously questioning the operations and expenditure of the public administration.

Reform is needed. Change is needed. But change can be unnerving for many. Whilst I lean to the side that embraces change, I do not believe in change for change’s sake, which is why I do cautiously study any elements of change. In studying the review of the Queensland parliamentary committee system I see much to be applauded and certainly a lot to adopt. At the outset I, too, commend the committee members who prepared this committee report for their bipartisanship and their openness. If that sentiment and the sentiment of this report is translated into practice, it certainly could herald in a new era of cross-party cooperation on ensuring the legislation passed in this House is of the highest quality.
Ms Grace interjected.
Mr POWELL: As I said, it is a possibility. It will be interesting to see if it translates into practice.
Mrs Pratt: Don’t hold your breath.

Mr POWELL: I am certainly not holding my breath, member for Nanango. The establishment of statutory portfolio based committees will ensure greater parliamentary scrutiny of bills, subordinate legislation, regulations, public works and public accounts by those who understand these portfolios best. For instance, the opposition will now be able to place shadow ministers and shadow parliamentary secretaries on portfolio relevant committees.

I do at this point want to raise a word of caution and a word of warning. As a current member of the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee, I cannot stress enough the importance of examining legislative compliance with fundamental legislative principles--principles we all hold dear; principles such as natural justice, the rights and liberties of the individual, rights to privacy, the onus of proof, retrospective operation of legislation, Aboriginal tradition and Islander custom and the delegation of legislative power.

As the review committee identified, every jurisdiction they studied has some form of legislative scrutiny against fundamental principles and/or human rights. I understand that the review committee was impressed by the New Zealand model. I note that the member for Gaven went into some detail regarding that model. I also note that the review committee has not chosen to implement the complementary New Zealand bodies of the Legislation Advisory Committee nor the Regulations Review Committee. It has chosen to put the scrutiny under these portfolio based committees without establishing the necessary bodies to assist those committees in conducting that sort of scrutiny.

In New Zealand the Legislation Advisory Committee is not actually made up of parliamentarians at all. It includes law commissioners, academic public law specialists, senior private and public sector lawyers as well as senior policy advisers, parliamentary counsel and senior members of the judiciary. Although it is serviced by the Ministry of Justice and reports annually to the Attorney-General on its activities, its varied membership facilitates independence from the executive and another level of parliamentary and legislative scrutiny.

The Regulations Review Committee, on the other hand, is a specialist committee dedicated to the technical scrutiny of subordinate legislation using criteria set out in the standing orders. This scrutiny in New Zealand is not an add-on; it is an intrinsic part of ensuring the legislation they pass is of the highest quality possible. It should be the same for the Queensland parliament. Scrutiny of legislation against fundamental legislative principles should not be an add-on. It has to be an intrinsic part of ensuring that legislation that we pass is also of the highest quality possible.

These new portfolio based committees must ensure this scrutiny occurs, as directed by recommendations 6 and 7 of this report. I would ask that the committees ensure that scrutiny against fundamental legislative principles becomes a specific standing agenda item at all of their meetings and that committees report annually on their compliance with these recommendations and against those principles.

Returning to the other recommendations, I applaud the establishment of the Committee of the Legislative Assembly, the CLA, incorporating the most senior members of both the government and the opposition. I am also pleased to hear that the government potentially is flexed and is proposing, or at least talking about, including the Speaker as an ex officio member of this committee and that this committee, rather than the Department of Public Works, will oversee the construction and maintenance of the parliamentary buildings and electorate offices. These were certainly some concerns of mine from my initial reading of the report.

I am pleased to hear that the CLA will also determine the budget and the resources of committees and make submissions to government to ensure the committees of parliament are sufficiently resourced. There were some conversations occurring about this here earlier. If the government is intent on making these changes cost neutral then I have serious concerns. My hope is that as part of this reform we are actually going to resource the committees to the level that they actually require to do the job properly. That may not be cost neutral. Either way, it is certainly going to be far cheaper than reinstating an upper house, as the member for Toowoomba North highlighted earlier.

The proposal to allocate time within the parliamentary week for committees is eminently sensible and embeds the role of committees well and truly into the work of the parliament as a whole. The restructuring of standing orders and speaking times in particular also makes sense given the level of discussion and debate that will now occur through the portfolio based committees. The opening of committee proceedings to the public is also commendable. I hope that this will go a long way to addressing what both the member for Indooroopilly and I have previously stated--that is, people really do not know that committees exist let alone understand what they do.

The recommendations that budget estimates be considered by portfolio committees without restricted, structured time frames for questions and answers will go a long way to turning farce into functionality. By allowing the attendance of officials before committees, estimates will potentially become truly transparent and accountable, as they should be.

As I said earlier, reform is needed. Change is needed. Change can be challenging though. But in this instance change will deliver more transparent and accountable public administration, higher quality legislation and ultimately better outcomes for Queenslanders.

Mr WETTENHALL (Barron River--ALP)
(4.46 pm): It is with great pleasure and a sense of anticipation that I rise to contribute to this debate about the review of the Queensland parliamentary committee system. At the outset, I would like to thank and commend the members of the committee for their thoughtful and thought-provoking report. I think it is very possible and desirable that the report will lead to some very far-reaching reforms to the way this parliament operates.

Strengthening the role of committees through the changes recommended in the report of the review committee will, I believe, produce a better democratic system overall, a better parliament, better MPs, better government, better legislation and more opportunity for effective scrutiny of executive government. I have confidence that a strengthened committee system is warranted, based, at least in part, on my own experience in this place as a member of three estimates committees, a member of the Legal, Constitutional and Administrative Review Committee, a member of the Investigation into Altruistic Surrogacy Select Committee and currently as a member of the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee.

Leaving aside the way in which estimates committees currently work for the time being, I can say that some of the most rewarding work I have undertaken as a member of parliament has been in those committees. By and large, committee work provides an opportunity for MPs to consider important matters of public policy and administration, less fettered by partisan consideration than in other settings and forums where an MP undertakes their work. In some cases, such as in the exercise by the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee of certain statutory functions, the resolutions of the committee are required to be bipartisan.

Whilst I am on the topic of the PCMC, I might just mention, because the observations of the member for Toowoomba North are fresh in my mind, that I agree with his remarks about the proposed incorporation of lay members on the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee. I can understand why the review committee has given consideration to that proposal. I think it is a proposal, in those circumstances, worthy of consideration. But in my experience--limited as it is as a member of that committee--having regard to the very sensitive and highly confidential nature of much of that committee’s work, it is difficult for me to imagine circumstances where a lay person would be able to take part in the committee’s deliberations in a way that would add to its effectiveness.

In most cases, the work of the committees in which I have been involved has been achieved without bringing partisan politics into those debates and considerations. That is, for the most part, a good thing. Not only does it produce better reports, but it provides opportunities for MPs to bring their education, their qualifications, their values, their personal opinions and their experience of life to bear on the matters before them. Happily, my experience of committee work has been a positive one and has possibly led to some major reforms. That is why I see so much potential in expanding and strengthening the role of committees. In particular, giving portfolio based committees a role to consider bills before the second reading is one of the most important reforms contained in the recommendations of the committee.

I have no doubt that subjecting bills to the scrutiny of MPs in committee will produce better law. This will occur because they will detect and rectify minor or technical defects through to more substantive amendments. Of course, not all amendments will necessarily be agreed to by the government of the day or be passed by the parliament, but the debate will be more informed and the public will have an opportunity to better understand the pros and cons of proceeding in a particular way.

Affording members of the public an opportunity to take part in this process is a significant and historic reform. Neither ministers, their advisers, their departmental officials nor MPs themselves can claim a monopoly of wisdom in the development and formulation of legislation. I acknowledge already that there are many ways in which stakeholders and members of the public can be and are consulted and provided with opportunities to give feedback on proposed legislation. That is a good thing that that occurs, but formalising those arrangements within the context of committee hearings is a significant step forward. It will broaden the range of people and organisations that will take part in the process and it will improve the quality of the submissions. Therefore, it will enhance the ability of us as legislators to frame good law.

As well as establishing portfolio based committees to examine legislation, it is proposed that the committees will incorporate the role of the Public Accounts and Public Works Committee and also become the estimates committees. These changes make sense and will enable the members of those committees to develop expertise in those portfolio areas that will in turn enable more effective scrutiny and more effective representation of their constituents and constituencies.

The reform of the estimates process to enable CEOs and statutory officers to be asked questions will give effect to one of the very important objectives of the estimates process, which is to provide opportunities for accurate information to be elicited in connection with the expenditure of public moneys. Provided that the power to ask questions of public officials is exercised responsibly and respectfully and the exercise does not become a witch-hunt, this reform will tend to reduce the imperative for defensive responses and significantly improve the flow of information which is at the heart of the estimates process.

There are many other worthy recommendations in the report. I am delighted that this parliament has the opportunity to consider the report today and debate and discuss its recommendations. I think it is one of the most significant and fundamental historic set of reforms this parliament has had to consider for a very, very long time. I consider it a great privilege and matter of good fortune that I am able to take part in that debate and consider those reforms. Ultimately, I hope to be in a position to see their implementation.

I would like to conclude on this note: to make these reforms work and to make them effective, many of them--although not all of them--will require a considerable degree of resourcing. The members we have heard from so far in this debate have indicated that the essence of those reforms are supported across both sides of the House and that there is a need for resources to be brought to bear. That gives me confidence that that level of support will continue in a bipartisan way when those decisions are to be made, which will thereby make the decisions the government will need to make to resource these reforms that much easier and that much sooner. That is something which I think we can all look forward to. With those remarks, I once again thank all of the members of the committee for their thorough work and thorough consideration of the matters that have been brought forward. I commend the report.

Hansard-Body.A: (Everton--ALP) (4.56 pm): I too rise to speak in support of this motion. The last couple of decades have seen tremendous reforms to improve the accountability of government in Queensland. This approach to accountability has been a hallmark of the Goss, Beattie and now Bligh Labor governments. The Goss government, beginning in 1989, established estimates committees, fair electoral boundaries, freedom of information laws and the Criminal Justice Commission. Following it, the Beattie government established the Crime and Misconduct Commission, the Integrity Commissioner and the Information Commissioner. Over the last couple of years, the Bligh government has introduced refreshed right to information laws, restrictions on lobbyists and, more recently, restrictions on political donations.

XML.Hansard-Body: The reforms that are foreshadowed by this motion are another fantastic step in improving the accountability of government in Queensland. I am pleased that in this instance the opposition has been a willing partner in undertaking those reforms. It is a feature of Westminster parliaments, such as the Queensland parliament, that there is a system of committees of parliamentarians to inquire into the activities of government. As a first-term member of this House, I cannot compare the current committee system to what has come before, but many more experienced members have spoken today about the deterioration in influence and effectiveness of the committee system. Certainly, my own experience since I was elected and in my time as a ministerial adviser is that on many occasions committees have had limited impact on the operations of government. Personally, I do believe that this is at least partly due to the less than diligent attitude shown by some members of those committees, but I do accept that there are probably also some systemic barriers to committees functioning effectively as well.

As has been mentioned previously, the reforms proposed in this motion arise from the recommendations of a bipartisan committee of parliamentarians. Like many other speakers, I commend that committee on its work. I understand that its work was undertaken in a cooperative and bipartisan spirit, and that attitude has led to some constructive suggestions that will improve government accountability.

I am going to touch on a couple of the recommendations of the committee. The first is its recommendation that the current committees be replaced by nine portfolio based committees, the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee and a Committee of the Legislative Assembly. I think it does make sense to expand the committees to give them more of a portfolio focus. I think this move will allow for greater specialisation among parliamentarians and the nature of their inquiries. It will allow committees to delve into greater detail when approaching things at a portfolio level than is currently the case when a committee’s activities are spread across a number of portfolios.

I also support the committee’s recommendation that the new parliamentary committees have a greater role in interrogating bills prior to them being debated in the House. I think we all have to admit that the current system does not allow for particularly detailed consideration of bills to determine their impact on a member’s electorate or how they accord with a member’s own values or those of their political party. I believe that empowering the new committees to scrutinise bills will result in better legislation and it will allow members of parliament to better do the job they all came here to do.

To conclude, our system of democracy functions only when it has a competent, diligent opposition and effective transparent systems of holding the government to account. These reforms are another plank in establishing such systems. They will go a long way towards continuing to make the Queensland government more accountable. I commend the motion to the House.

Mrs PRATT (Nanango--Ind) (5.00 pm): As I was part of this committee and had input during the whole process, I will endeavour not to speak for too long. I have to say in speaking to the report, the Review of the Queensland parliamentary committee system , that it was the best, most stimulating, most exciting committee that I have been a part of.
Mr Lawlor: What about the Palm Island committee?

Mrs PRATT: I have to say that this is the first time that I have ever debated a report like this. We did not get to debate the Palm Island Select Committee report. I cannot remember ever debating another report.
Ms Stone: We have spoken on the committee report.

Mrs PRATT: But it was never debated in the House as such. I think that this could be the first step towards something great for Queensland. But there is something I would like to correct. The chair stated that I have been here for just over 10 years. In fact, I was elected to this House in 1998 with Jeff Seeney. So come June, I will have been here for 13 years. So if the chair does not mind, and just to get the record straight, those years could be added to make our experience that little bit more. Believe me, you remember every year you have been here. It can be one of those journeys in life. I do not think there are many jobs quite like this one. Every year has memorable events.

I am going to be very honest here--and I hope I have always been as honest as I possibly could--and say that I came to parliament with a very naive view of how parliament worked, and I believe a lot of people in my electorate also believed parliament worked that way. That was it. We thought that parliament worked in a certain way. I can tell members that probably within three months I was totally disillusioned. I can also say that, since I got on to this committee, I now have a little bit of hope. It took a long time. This new committee system should work well and it needs to work well with the goodwill of everybody in the House and of future politicians to come. In fact, I would rather not see politicians but statesmen and women, because then I know the committee system really would work. But like I said, I am a naive person in a lot of ways and I am probably going to prove that in my speech today.

As the chair said, there were compromises made and I believe that everyone came in knowing that the committee system, as it has existed in the time I have been here and probably since everybody else has been here, had perhaps deteriorated in its value to Queensland and really was in need of reform. I am under no illusion that we have it 100 per cent right, but I believe this proposal is a great foundation and a great step forward for this parliament. It can be built on and changes made when needed. But as I said, this proposal relies on the goodwill of everybody in this chamber to change the mind-set. To make this new committee system work requires a huge, fundamental change in our way of thinking.

We all saw the committee system in New Zealand. For me, at that point I could see the reality of what the committee system could be and I will work very hard in the time that I am here--and I hope everyone who was on the committee will do the same--to try to make it work in the best possible way. In saying that, I do not believe that the committee system should be jeopardised in any way, shape or form by not being funded correctly. It is going to need extra dollars. As has been stated before, there has to be dedicated committee rooms, there has to be the research staff and the allocation of funds to do the job properly.

If and when this proposal gets through, everybody in this chamber will have to pull their weight. I can say that I am pretty sure that everyone in this chamber could say that they have not pulled their weight every minute of every day that they have been here.
Mr Schwarten interjected.
Mrs PRATT: Absolutely.
Mr Schwarten interjected.

Mrs PRATT: That is exactly right. I know that in the country for every dollar we spend we expect at least $5 back in effort, and I think that is what we have to do. The thing I like about this proposal is that every single member of this chamber will be working hard. They will be having to read and study the legislation. They will have to communicate with the general public and with each other. Without the adversarial carrying on that goes on in the chamber, members can put forward their ideas to the committee knowing that there is not just going to be a blank minister’s face in front of them. We all know that in here, once a bill is tabled, it is going to go through anyway with virtually no change at all. It is a fait accompli.

The question I often ask myself--and I ask my husband--is, ‘Why do I even bother?’ ‘Why does a person come down here and sit here just to go through a show?’ That is exactly right. It is because I care and I do not believe that all legislation is correct. I do not believe that it is all wrong, either. If we do not have a say, then the legislation goes through as though everybody is happy. Everybody is not always happy. Under this proposal, everybody has a chance to have a say. Everybody can put in their two bob’s worth, get it considered and possibly have it incorporated or get changes made. If this committee system works even half as well as it does in New Zealand, I think we would have made a major leap forward.

Often over the past almost 13 years that I have been here I have been at meetings where opposition members have attended. The very first time I went to a meeting Rob Borbidge was the Leader of the Opposition. I was very green then. We were sitting there and I said, ‘No, let Rob talk first,’ because I wanted to hear what he had to say--mainly because I was so green. He said, ‘We can do this and we can do that’--meaning the opposition. At the end I could not stand it anymore and I said to him and the other people at the meeting, ‘With all due respect, Rob, you cannot do anything until you are in government. So you are as ineffective as anybody else in the chamber.’ That is how it has really been. We can yell and we can rant and rave in this place, but it is just hot air going around because we know that when that legislation is tabled it is a done and dusted deal. To me, that has been the most disillusioning part of being in this chamber.

Under this proposal, everybody has a chance to make an input. There is no loss of face, if you want to call it that, because something has had to be changed. It is beholden on every one of us to make sure that the best possible legislation comes into this House. Often we come into this House and legislation is tabled. At times the amendments to the legislation can be greater in volume than the actual bill. We should have got it right in the first place. Hopefully under this proposal that will occur. There are so many things that a few members of government cannot come up with. A few bureaucrats cannot always get it right. But when you have everyone in the chamber working for the betterment of Queensland for the best legislation, when you have every interested party outside these walls also being able to contribute their ideas, we must get closer and closer to getting the best possible legislation for the state.
The member for Nicklin said that this is an historic day. It will be history in the making if the changes do in fact go ahead. I am quite proud to have been on the committee and to be a part of that.

There is no doubt that I have concerns about certain parts of the report. As has been said, there were compromises made and it may not necessarily be as good as it possibly could be. We have looked at other jurisdictions. I believe that we have taken what was the best of those jurisdictions and hopefully it will work. That is all part of growing. It is about not being afraid to look elsewhere and to pick up other people’s ideas. A saying I have always liked is that a good idea is worth stealing. I have no problem with that.

To reform the Queensland parliament is a good idea. I think it is very sad that a person like myself, who had such faith in democracy and the system, could be so disillusioned by being part of the system for so long. To me, that is probably the saddest thing of all about this parliament.

The majority of speakers so far have supported this change. The government is supporting it and those who have spoken from the opposition are also supporting it. Hopefully most of the Independents will support it, although there may be reservations. That is what this chamber is for. There were only nine members on that committee and there are 89 in this chamber. All 89 members need to make a contribution to the process. I will not go any further. I was proud to be on that committee. I enjoyed working with the chair and the members of the committee. I thank them. We had great staff who worked hard on this. They put in a lot of effort. Every committee needs staff of that quality.

In the past, committee reports have been lost in the ether. I cannot remember any report that has been tabled in parliament about which I have heard what happened subsequently. Was there any progress made in the areas where we tried to help people?

I have to be quite honest and say that I find estimates committees as frustrating as all get-up. They were frustrating to me because there were times when I wanted to question people for a long time and there was no time at all. In New Zealand, if I recall correctly, if a committee had very little to be questioned on it only went for an hour or so, but if they had a lot to be questioned on it did not just finish at the end of that day; it was brought on the next day and the next day, too, until everyone was happy. There is much that we as a parliament can learn. I hope that we have picked out the best of what we have studied and that every member of this House will give their ideas and their opinions here today because we need them. That is what it is all about. Hopefully we have made a huge leap forward for Queensland when it comes to democracy and this the people’s parliament.

Mr CRANDON (Coomera--LNP)
(5.13 pm): I want to make a few comments on the report by the committee. The chair’s foreword states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Our review of our committee system has been the most comprehensive assessment of our parliament’s structure that has been undertaken.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: In closing in that foreword the chair states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Committee System Review Committee members believe we can transform the way the Queensland Parliament operates by giving members greater responsibility for the scrutiny of the executive; by using the parliament to enliven the executive to their constituents concerns; by ensuring that every Queenslander has the opportunity to have a say on laws that may affect them; and by giving the parliament a committee system that is strong and dedicated to the purpose of scrutiny, review and deliberation.
The recommendations that we have proposed could potentially result in the most significant changes to the Queensland Parliament since the abolition of the Upper House ...
XML.Hansard-Body: I applaud the committee for being forward thinking and recommending fundamental change, change that looks at what is best for Queensland and Queenslanders. The executive summary comments--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: One of the key functions of a parliament is scrutiny of the executive. Proper scrutiny of the executive helps to ensure accountability and transparency and in turn better administration.
XML.Hansard-Body: I must say that in the two years I have been in this place that certainly has not happened. I take the point that the member for Nanango made in relation to the disappointment in the way the place has worked in the past. I could go on about that but let us move forward.

If one was going to create a new parliament today, how would one do it? Interestingly enough, it is probably very similar to the one that we are in the midst of creating here today. I have visited several parliaments, including the Scottish parliament. As members would know, the Scottish parliament has been in existence for about 11 years and it has a very strong parliamentary committee system. In fact, I must admit that when I did the tour--a very special tour of the parliament laid on thanks to the Clerk of the Parliament here arranging it for me--I was most impressed with the committee rooms and the way those committee rooms are set up. I was thinking then, ‘Am I missing something here? There is something very wrong here.’ A unicameral parliament with the committee system that the Scottish parliament has and the facilities that the Scottish parliament has is certainly very, very impressive. The executive summary in the report states further--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It is now time for committees to take on a greater role in examination of executive action across all the policy areas of government and in considering proposed legislation, building on the moves made in this direction in early 2009.
XML.Hansard-Body: How true that is when we consider that we are coming forward in leaps and bounds. The suggestion in the report is that there be nine committees--I have heard that there may be some variation on that and that, of course, will be fleshed out over time--with a subject based jurisdiction, which is absolutely wonderful, mirroring the various portfolio areas of government. It goes on to say that the following functions are part of that nine-committee system--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • Monitor and review of all issues and executive action, including operational matters and events
• Consideration of proposed legislation, both from a policy point of view and to ensure compliance with fundamental legislative principles
XML.Hansard-Body: I think we are all going to learn something as part of this process--something that we probably have not been learning a great deal about certainly in the time that I have been here. I have to confess that I have not studied each and every bill that has come through this place. Continuing with those functions--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • Scrutiny of the estimates
• The ability to consider petitions.
XML.Hansard-Body: Once again, the petitions come in, they are sent off to a minister, the minister responds to the petition and that is where it dies. Now we are going to have this opportunity to flesh things out far more than ever before.
Turning to the recommendations that are made in this report, recommendation 1 states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Committee recommends that in place of the current committees there be the following committees:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • nine statutory portfolio based committees to cover the array of government activities
• the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee
• a Committee of the Legislative Assembly.
XML.Hansard-Body: Once again, it is a strong structure that is going to be of great benefit to this place as we move forward. It will deliver what the people of Queensland deserve, which is appropriate legislation properly researched and properly fleshed out in that committee system. Recommendation 21 states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Committee recommends that all bills, with the exception of those deemed ‘urgent’, be referred to portfolio committees for inquiry and report, using a model that achieves the following:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • there shall be a presumption that the Legislature will refer legislation to a committee, and any exceptions must be transparent, narrowly-defined, and extraordinary in nature
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is a very powerful sentence: ‘narrowly-defined, and extraordinary in nature’. The people of Queensland will not bear this committee system being used on an ad hoc basis when, in reality, it should be used for the majority of legislation that comes through this place. The recommendation goes on to state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • committees shall scrutinise legislation referred to them and have the power to recommend amendments
• opportunities shall be given for public input into the legislative process.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is all very well and fine, but I do have one question. I note that in the committee system in Scotland, which I was referring to earlier, the committees have the opportunity to initiate legislation. I wonder whether or not that possibility will exist in this place for our committees. They will end up with a wealth of knowledge and experience from the various testaments that come to them and the various people who talk about their needs. I wonder whether it will be possible for the committees to initiate legislation in their own right. Of course, all individual members have the capacity to do that, but a well-resourced and staffed committee would be perfectly positioned to see any holes in legislation. I believe consideration should be given to that proposition. Recommendation 31 states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Committee recommends that the maximum timeframe for committees to inquire and report on bills be six months.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Is it anticipated that that be the exception or the rule? Six months is a long time. We expect most legislation to be dealt with fairly quickly. I note that recommendation 32 states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Committee recommends that Standing Orders be amended to provide that committees must report on a bill within six months of the bill being referred to it or by such other time as fixed by the Committee of the Legislative Assembly.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Does that mean that it could be longer? Does that mean that, in most cases, we will see them turning things around in a four-week or six-week period? I am curious about that recommendation.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Schwarten: You have to manage your own workload.

Mr CRANDON: That is absolutely right. I take the interjection. They will be managing their own workload, but how will that recommendation be fleshed out? That sort of consideration should be taken in hand. It seems to me that there might a conflict in the terminology used in recommendations 33 and 34. Recommendation 33 states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Committee recommends that bills be set down for the second reading a minimum of three sitting days after a committee reports.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: In effect, that would probably mean the next sitting week. Recommendation 34 states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Committee recommends that Standing Orders be amended to provide that following the presentation of a committee report on a bill, the bill is set down for second reading on the third sitting day following.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Recommendation 33 refers to a minimum of three sitting days and recommendation 34 states that it will be set down for second reading on the third sitting day. Is there a conflict there in the terminology? Having asked those few questions, and hopefully they will be answered, I finish simply by saying that I look forward to working in this place in this new paradigm and to making a difference for all Queenslanders.

Hansard-Body.A: (Southport--ALP) (5.24 pm): I also support the motion. The report states--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: One of the key functions of a parliament is scrutiny of the executive. Proper scrutiny of the executive helps to ensure accountability and transparency and in turn better administration.
XML.Hansard-Body: In Queensland we have a parliament that is essentially a two-party system, with 89 members elected from single member consistencies through an optional preferential voting system. The levels of scrutiny that are provided in other jurisdictions in Australia by upper houses has not been available in Queensland since 1922. As other members have observed, I do not think we would be able to sell the Queensland people on more politicians by reinstating the upper house. Certainly, I would be opposed to that. Therefore, the parliamentary committee system is more important in Queensland than in any other jurisdiction. In Queensland we had an ineffective committee system until the advent of the Fitzgerald inquiry which established the modern committee system, with some variations in 2009.

This report recommends nine committees. Their functions would be to monitor and review all issues and executive actions, including operational matters and events; the consideration of proposed legislation, both from a policy point of view and to ensure compliance with fundamental legislative principles; the scrutiny of the estimates; and the ability to consider petitions. The government intends to form, by resolution of the House, a Committee of the Legislative Assembly to consider issues surrounding the implementation of the review’s recommendations, including the formation of the committees. It is proposed that each committee have six members and that the chair have both a deliberative and a casting vote. I agree with many of the comments that have been made in this place, but I particularly agree with the comments made by the member for Toowoomba North about the problems that could be created by having lay members sit on the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee. Certainly that step should be approached with caution.

The new structure proposes greater consideration by the parliament of committee reports and that those committees be supported by adequate funding, staffing, accommodation and other resourcing. Proposed amendments to the committee system will lead to a more efficient use of the time available to this parliament. Recommendation 26 proposes that following the first reading stage, the introducing Member shall move that the bill be referred to a particular portfolio committee. Recommendation 31 proposes that the maximum timeframe for committees to inquire and report on bills be six months. That can be varied by the Committee of the Legislative Assembly pursuant to recommendation 32, assuming that in most cases that may well be shortened.

Given the lengthy and exhaustive consideration of bills by the proposed new committee structure, recommendation 35 proposes a reduction in the time limits for the second reading debate. In this particular report I was most attracted to recommendation 36, because it would allow the following time limits during a second reading debate: the Leader of the Opposition, one hour to reply; members of portfolio committees, 20 minutes; all other members, 10 minutes; and the mover in reply, 30 minutes. That will be a huge step forward and will lead to a great saving of time for parliament. Too many members seem to think it is compulsory to speak on bills for 20 minutes. In fact, many do not even deliver a 20-minute speech; they deliver a five-minute speech four times, just to use up their 20 minutes.

I support the motion to note the report. I commend the committee on the excellent work that it has done, which has resulted in this report. The committee has worked hard and obviously with goodwill, as evidenced by this unanimous report. That is commendable given the make-up of the committee, which included both members of the LNP, the government and an Independent member. They have certainly worked with goodwill. I commend the committee on the report.

Hansard-Body.A: (Yeerongpilly--ALP) (Minister for Government Services, Building Industry and Information and Communication Technology) (5.28 pm): I rise to support the motion and to make a brief contribution today. It was an honour to serve as a member on the Committee System Review Committee and to participate in developing a reform program for the functioning of the parliament and, in doing so, recommend changes that deliver great input for all Queenslanders in the legislative process. This forms the parliamentary and democracy reforms of the government’s integrity review which also includes the recently announced campaign finance reforms.

XML.Hansard-Body: The debate about whether Queensland should retain its unicameral structure emerges regularly. Whilst there is a range of views on this matter, the debate usually revolves around the greatest benefit being an upper house and more elected representatives or a more rigorous and better informed committee system. For the record, I do not believe that Queensland would be better served by the re-creation of an upper house. In fact, I do not believe there is community benefit in upper houses at the state level in the Australian democracy.

State governments are service delivery and administrative arms of government which effectively prioritise expenditure that has been raised and allocated by another level of government. This differs from the federal level, where the government has vast revenue powers including collection and expenditure of income and consumption based taxes for all Australians as well as determining signatures to international covenants and decisions to commit Australian troops. It is reasonable that these fundamental decisions on the rights, freedoms and prosperity of a nation be made with a check and balance that includes elected representatives of the states.

The report we consider today will change both the culture and functioning of the Queensland parliament. The most significant reform is the development of portfolio based committees which will consider legislation in the period between its introduction to and debate in the House.
Debate, on motion of Mr Finn, adjourned.

Hansard-Body.A: (Callide--LNP) (5.30 pm): I move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1) Condemns the incompetence of the former Minister for Mines and Energy in issuing an exploration permit over a closely settled area at Gowrie Junction near Toowoomba.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And calls on the newly appointed Minister to:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 2) Recognise the grave concern, the emotional turmoil and the negative impact on property prices the EP has caused across the local community and in Toowoomba area generally.

3) Immediately make whatever legislative change is necessary to revoke the exploration permit at Gowrie to remove any suggestion, no matter how remote, that a mine could ever be established in what is an entirely unsuitable area for mining.

4) Strictly enforce the provisions of section 147A of the Mineral Resources Act to ensure all of the exploration permits covering the Felton valley and other areas of Prime agricultural land are not renewed so that landholders and communities in the region can be given some security and can be freed from the threat of an inappropriate mining development in their area.

5) Ensure no more exploration permits or other mining authorities are issued and no existing permits or other mining authorities are renewed for the Darling Downs region until a statutory regional plan is established identifying appropriate land uses across the region and giving statutory legal protection for prime agricultural land and establishing statutory separation distances between all resource industry authorities and urban areas.
XML.Hansard-Body: I want to consider the motion before the House in two separate parts. The first part of the motion condemns the incompetence of the former minister for mines and energy in issuing an exploration permit over a closely settled area at Gowrie Junction near Toowoomba and calls on the newly appointed minister to recognise the grave concern, the emotional turmoil and the negative impact on property prices that the EP has caused and immediately make whatever legislative changes are necessary to revoke the permit to ensure that, no matter how remote, a mine can never be established in what is an entirely unsuitable area for mining.

Anybody who knows that area knows that that last statement is undoubtedly true. It is undoubtedly true that the Gowrie area is completely unsuitable for mining. The minister admitted as much this morning in this House when he spoke about the issuance of exploration permits. There is no question that it is a totally unsuitable area for mining and there should have been no question in the minister’s mind when he issued the exploration permit that it was going to produce a terrible reaction, a terrible effect, a terrible impact on the people who live in that area.

Unfortunately, at the moment there is a heightened atmosphere of distrust of the resources industry--a great industry for Queensland, an industry that I have supported in this place over and over again and will continue to support. There is a degree of heightened emotion out there, especially in this area of the Darling Downs. For the former minister to issue an exploration permit over an area such as Gowrie was gross incompetence, and he should be condemned for that.

The broader issue here is the need to recognise that the impact of mining does not start when the ground is dug up. The minister needs to understand that the legislation needs to change in order to recognise that the issuance of such mining titles has a great impact on people’s lives. The issuance of an exploration permit causes an impact on the people who live in that particular area, especially when it is a closely settled urban area such as Gowrie. We have seen that impact expressed in the anger and the frustration of people who have to contemplate the possibility, no matter how remote, that a mine is going to be constructed in their area.

It is almost impossible to explain to a member of the general public that just because an exploration permit has been issued it does not mean that a mine will be built. As one very angry lady said to me in Toowoomba last weekend, ‘Why would they be looking for coal if they are not going to mine coal?’ It is a logic that is understandable amongst the general public. It is all very well for Michael Roche and the QRC to suggest that people have to go through some sort of a long, convoluted process to identify the impacts. However, the impacts begin when the title is issued. There is no greater example of that than what we have seen at Gowrie, at Toowoomba, at Felton and at so many other places. The issuance of a title causes the impact. People who suffer that impact get no input, get no say and are not even advised before those titles are issued.

The legislation needs to be fixed; it needs to be changed. At the moment, all of the decision making is at the end of a long, convoluted process that can drag on for years. At the end of that EIS process a decision is made about the social acceptability and the environmental acceptability of a particular mining project. Much of that decision making needs to be moved to the front of the process. There needs to be an assessment at the beginning, when the exploration permit is applied for, of whether or not there is a reasonable chance that a project in that area is going to be socially acceptable, whether or not there is a reasonable chance that a project in that area is going to be environmentally acceptable and whether or not there is a reasonable chance that the exploration is going to produce something of worth that justifies the impact that it has on the local community. That local community has to live with doubt, fear and trepidation for the five, seven or 10 years it takes for that process to be completed. It is a totally unacceptable impact. It causes enormous stress on individuals. It causes enormous doubt. It causes people’s lives to be disrupted. It causes falls in property prices--quite dramatic falls--which people have to endure for years until they receive some sort of a conclusion to the long, convoluted EIS process.

It is bad enough that people have to endure that sort of process in areas that are highly prospective, in areas where there is a real chance that a mine can be developed. In those areas there is no other option. I accept that in those areas that is the reality. However, in areas where it is almost impossible to conceive of a mine being developed--such as Gowrie Junction near Toowoomba--residents should not be subjected to those five, seven or 10 years of doubt, fear and trepidation. There is no justification for that.

This is the result of an incompetent minister who did not understand the impact of the action that he was taking, who did not understand the impact of the mining title that he was issuing. This House should condemn the former minister as being incompetent in that action. This House should insist that the current minister recognise the impact that that absurd issuance of such a title has had on so many innocent Queenslanders and move to rectify that, move to implement whatever legislation is required to take away that doubt, that fear, that uncertainty that is hanging over that community. Unless the minister acts, it will continue to hang over that community for five, seven or 10 years into the future. It is a totally unacceptable situation and the minister must move to rectify it.

The second part of the motion before the House calls on the minister to enforce the provisions of section 147A of the Mineral Resources Act in relation to all of the other exploration permits that exist across the Darling Downs in areas where it is almost impossible to conceive of a coalmine being developed. Yet those permits exist and they cause uncertainty, trepidation and fear for the people who live there. I speak of places such as the Felton Valley, where residents’ lives have been put in limbo for so long now by a project that continues to change in concept every time we hear about it. We wonder how much real chance those projects have of becoming reality. How much real chance does a project such as this one at Felton have of ever becoming a reality?

What is a reality is the impact that has on people’s lives, the destruction it brings to families, to businesses and to the value of the assets that, in many cases, form their superannuation and their entire asset base. They have to live with that uncertainty and that fear for years while mining companies dither and dream and carry on with projects that, in real terms, could be seen as completely unrealistic.

The whole issue of prime agricultural land is one that the minister needs to address. He needs to apply this section of the Mineral Resources Act to those mining authorities on that prime agricultural land to give some substance to the government’s words that they are committed, as we are committed, to protecting that prime agricultural land. The best way to protect that prime agricultural land, the best way to address many of these problems that exist across the Darling Downs and the more closely settled areas in the vicinity of Toowoomba, is by a regional planning process that should have been done by now--a regional planning process that ensures proper separation distances between mining industries and urban areas, a regional planning process that identifies the prime agricultural land that should be protected and that identifies the places where mines can be built and where permits can be issued, and a regional planning process that avoids the sort of community impact that we have seen caused by an incompetent government that does not understand the impact of the actions that it takes.

There is a chance in this parliament tonight for the new minister to show whether he understands the impact of the mining authorities that he issues. There is a chance for the new minister to show that he is prepared to take the actions that are long overdue in terms of a regional planning process that should ensure the proper separation distances between what can be competing industries. The mining industry is a great industry but so is agriculture and so is the lifestyle of the Darling Downs, and they all should be protected.
Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (5.40 pm): I rise to speak to this motion and I second the motion.
Mr SPEAKER: You do not have to second it.

Mr LANGBROEK: Yes, I know, Mr Speaker, but I am happy to do it because it is that important. It is not just about mining but about agriculture and lifestyle, as the member for Callide just pointed out at the end of his contribution. We are seeking to rectify and remedy these unfair decisions made by the Bligh government that have caused great disquiet and upset in these affected communities. I saw it just last Sunday and Monday when I was in Toowoomba with my shadow cabinet. People were deeply concerned and angry that the government has granted this exploration permit for coal in this area between Gowrie Junction and Kingsthorpe.

If successful, this joint venture between Australia Pacific Coal and Blackwood Coal could see an open-cut coalmine in operation on the outskirts of Toowoomba just minutes away from Highfields. A couple of hundred people turned up to express their concerns to our shadow cabinet in Toowoomba and, as the member for Callide, the shadow minister, has just pointed out, they are genuine concerns felt by young people, by elderly people, by people who are very upset about the uncertainty that has been put upon them. I expect many more to turn up to protest at the government’s community cabinet meeting in Toowoomba. When they do turn up, as I know they will, I encourage the government to give them a fair hearing and recognise the genuine concerns that these people hold for the future--for the future of their city, for the future of their families, for the future of their economic and financial security as well.
Mr Shine: You should come.

Mr LANGBROEK: I say to the member for Toowoomba North who is here that I hope he will be there standing with some of his constituents who are relatives of people in these areas and who are concerned. He needs to be there to respond to this community’s justified anger. The people of Toowoomba have put their faith in the member for Toowoomba North for a number of years now, and it is time for him to stand up on behalf of his community and get this government to revoke this exploration permit at Gowrie. The government should admit that they were wrong and admit that this permit should never have been approved.

Most of the group that came to see us in Toowoomba were from the Toowoomba Coal Mine Action Group, a group of residents and families that was formed in response to this issue. They held a community meeting on 18 February at the Gowrie Junction community hall. More than 700 people attended this meeting--a clear indication of the depth of feeling in that community. These people have a right to be concerned. They have a right to be angry. I understand that the first time they learned of this exploration permit was through one of their local newspapers. That is unacceptable. They live in a beautiful community, a community that they are now worried could experience a similar fate to Acland, which has been deserted since a coalmine was developed there years ago.

They are worried about the increase of traffic on already bad roads, the impact on local tourism, and the pollution and dust that comes with this type of industry. As I was leaving Toowoomba and drove through the streets of Toowoomba, I was surrounded by B-doubles and trucks that go through the city. As we have heard from the member for Toowoomba South many times over the last number of years, up to 500 trucks every day go through 16 sets of traffic lights. Elderly ladies are concerned about driving because they are surrounded by these huge hulking vehicles. Many of these trucks do not appear to be covering their loads, and that is leading to the dust pollution and pollution from coal affecting people in these communities.

I made a commitment to these people that an LNP government would rule out the approval of open-cut mining in environmentally sensitive, urban and prime agricultural areas. Under an LNP government, this type of exploration permit would never be granted. The Toowoomba Chronicle conducted a poll asking: is Gowrie Junction too close to Toowoomba for a coalmine? Eighty-nine per cent of people said yes. We in the LNP wholeheartedly agree with that. Toowoomba Regional Council’s Mayor Peter Taylor has said his council is unanimously opposed to the mine and it should not go ahead in such a closely settled area. The area has been identified in council’s planning for future growth. Water has already been laid on and sewerage is also planned in their budget. I quote Mayor Taylor, ‘It is prime agricultural land, the best in the country, and it’s too close to Toowoomba and Highfields.’

The LNP made a commitment in March 2009 that we would protect prime agricultural land from mining. We stand by this commitment. We recognise the long-term need to preserve prime farmland for continued agriculture. We welcome the government’s recognition that prime agricultural land should be protected. However, we are still waiting for the detail. People want certainty, and I would encourage the government to release the mapping and identification of relevant areas to provide this certainty to landowners and the mining industry. We want the Mineral Resources Act to be enforced. We want to support and restore the peace of mind to good people whose lives have been affected by these government decisions.
Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Employment, Skills and Mining) (5.46 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That all words after ‘House’ be deleted and the following words inserted:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • Notes that the previous Minister for Mines led development of the Strategic Cropping Land policy framework.
• Acknowledges the strong provisions in the Mineral Resources Act to protect landholders if permits to explore have been placed over their land.
• Recognises the importance of the resources industry to the state economy and to jobs for Queenslanders now and in the future.
• Supports the development of the resources industry subject to meeting legislative requirements and strict environmental conditions already in place.
• Notes that less than 1% of land explored for mining has a mining lease placed over it.
XML.Hansard-Body: Queenslanders must once again be confused about the LNP’s stance on the mining industry and the jobs it brings to Queensland. Just yesterday the member for Callide stood in this House claiming the LNP supported Queensland’s resources industry. Today we hear that the LNP wants to place ad hoc limits on the mining industry and risk thousands of jobs for Queenslanders. Queenslanders should be confused and concerned.
In relation to CSG mining, the Leader of the Opposition, whom we have just heard from, was yesterday quoted on ABC saying a moratorium was not the answer. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Those things need to be balanced with issues like sovereign risk. Sovereign risk that will say we can’t invest in Queensland because the government is coming out with moratoriums.
XML.Hansard-Body: Placing unpredictable and ad hoc limits on mining exploration will create a risk in the eyes of those looking to invest in our state and risk the jobs of the future for Queensland. Figures released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics reveal that some $990 million is being invested in mining exploration alone in Queensland. So let us be clear about this. This is a $990 million investment in the jobs of the future for a prosperous Queensland. Attempting to create rules and regulations that mean the government of the day can tear up an exploration permit on a whim will lead to uncertainty in the industry and a reluctance to invest in the state. That is why these commitments by the LNP are putting Queensland’s jobs of the future at risk. Not even Russ Hinze would have proposed something as ad hoc and irresponsible as this for Queensland.

We understand community concerns. We certainly do. One of the first people who contacted me when I became minister for mining about these issues was the member for Toowoomba North. I did not hear from too many others. I heard from the member for Toowoomba North. He has been very active in raising questions on behalf of the people in his local area and has encouraged people to meet with me and other ministers this Sunday at community cabinet. I am looking forward to setting the record straight on some of the scaremongering that has come from those opposite. I want to make it absolutely clear. There is no application for a permit to start a mine at or near Kingsthorpe. There is no application for a permit to start a mine at or near Gowrie Junction.

There is a permit to explore an area as broad as 150 square kilometres. Companies are looking for what is in the ground, not proposing to dig it out. I have made that clear to the House. Laws already exclude exploration near places of residence, churches, sporting or community facilities, bores, dams, wells and permanent stockyards. We do not permit undermining in residential areas.

Historically speaking, when the permission to explore is granted it is very rare for that land to ever be mined. As I have made clear and as can be seen in the amendment to the motion that I commend to members, less than one per cent of land explored for mining has a mining lease placed over it. Even if exploration reveals that a commercially viable operation will be possible, there are still so many boxes that a company must tick before operations can start. I am sure the Minister for Environment and Resource Management will go through that.

Once again we see the division among those opposite that this motion before the House is trying to paper over. I am sure that moving this motion in the House today left a bitter taste in the mouth of the member for Callide. He has clearly been rolled by the party room. It is all about the divided forces opposite--the old Country Party trying to roll the future for Queensland and overturn the understandings and arrangements that have been around this industry for many years.

Hansard-Body.A: (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Environment and Resource Management) (5.51 pm): I support the amendment moved by the honourable minister for mines. Queensland has come a long way since the dirty days of conservative rule. Many of the people who were in here when they were last in government--

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Hobbs: What have you done about it?

Ms JONES: Thank you for the question. I will articulate that now. We have come a long way in Queensland. We have seen a number of amendments to toughen up the laws in this area which have, in the main, received bipartisan support.
The LNP has the gall to come in here and lecture this government and this side of politics about how to approve mining projects when all of us know the terrible history that they have in this regard.
Mr Hobbs: Like what?

Ms JONES: Let me get to it. As we know, all of the legislation that they are now relying on to ensure there are protections for their stakeholders, for their communities and for their farmers and the people they represent they opposed in this House. They opposed amendments to the Environmental Protection Act.

Before I became the minister for environment I was actually doing my masters in environmental law. I examined when the Environmental Protection Act first came into play. I read all of the speeches you made where you said that it was going to be the end of the world--that this would stop development in Queensland, that this was attacking the heart of the industry, that mining companies would never be able to operate. You opposed all of those safeguards--
Mr SPEAKER: Direct your comments through the chair.

Ms JONES: The LNP--the then Liberal and National parties; we used to have a Liberal Party in those days--opposed the introduction of that act. Those opposite are now saying that they support those safeguards that we have relied upon and put into law.

Let us be very clear about the heart of the matter that we are debating here. We are talking about an exploration permit at Gowrie Junction just outside Toowoomba, as members have acknowledged. The granting of an exploration permit, as the minister for mines highlighted and as the shadow minister is fully aware, does not indicate or prejudge automatic approval for a full-scale mine. He knows that. The reason it does not is that the laws I have highlighted, which those opposite opposed in this place, provide protection against that.

Any proponent managing a project of this nature would have to apply to the Coordinator-General to have the project declared a significant project under the State Development and Public Works Organisation Act. It would also be captured by the Environmental Protection Act, which those opposite opposed. This ensures there is an environmental impact statement process to be gone through which we, as the Department of Environment and Resource Management, also have a say in. We provide advice on what the conditions should be. Should this project proceed to assessment then the environmental impact statement would need to describe all the potential impacts on land, water--including flooding, which is one of the issues that the honourable member raised--and vegetation as well as, of course, the impact on the local community. Actions that the proponent would have to take to avoid and mitigate any adverse impacts would also need to be identified and addressed.

Before the project can be approved, the proponent will need to, as we have seen time and time again, demonstrate to the government that it can meet all the legislative and policy requirements that apply to that proposal. Once again these are the safeguards that this side of politics put into law in Queensland that those opposite opposed. They come in here tonight crying crocodile tears because suddenly it suits them.
Mr Seeney: Acknowledge the impact. Acknowledge the impact of the title.

Ms JONES: What I am acknowledging is that we put safeguards in place in legislation for the very reasons you are highlighting tonight and you opposed them. I challenge anyone out there who thinks that the LNP in Queensland is going to safeguard their communities to look at all the promises they have already made to wind back the environmental legislation we have put in place in Queensland. It is a shame the shadow minister responsible for the Great Barrier Reef is not here because the LNP voted against its protection but it has a shadow minister responsible for Great Barrier Reef protection. That highlights where they stand on the environment.

What we are doing is continuing to expand the legislation that we have put in place to not only protect communities but also guard against environmental impacts. We will continue to do that. I note that members were interjecting about the strategic cropping land policy. That is something I am absolutely committed to. I am delighted that now, as the minister for natural resources, I can make that happen in Queensland. I am working overtime to deliver that for the communities that are waiting on that regulation. We will build on our record, not dismantle it like those opposite would.

Hansard-Body.A: (Condamine--LNP) (5.56 pm): I support the motion moved by the shadow minister for mines and energy, natural resources and water. Exploration permit 1979 encompasses a significant area of the electorate of Condamine, which I represent, including the communities of Gowrie Junction and Kingsthorpe. It is astonishing that the former minister for mines and energy could even consider issuing an exploration permit in this closely populated area, located less than 10 kilometres from Toowoomba’s CBD, less than five kilometres from the heavy populated Highfields area and less than 20 kilometres from the township of Oakey. But issue it he did.

XML.Hansard-Body: Exploration permit 1979 borders the member for Toowoomba North’s electorate. I am sure his office has been bombarded with calls, emails and letters regarding the close proximity of the proposed mine to the residents of Highfields and Toowoomba. These residents share the same concerns as those of Gowrie Junction and Kingsthorpe. There are 125,000 people who reside in Toowoomba and the surrounding districts. Approximately 3,500 people reside in the communities of Gowrie Junction and Kingsthorpe. The issuing of this exploration permit has caused considerable concern to these residents and the neighbouring communities of Highfields, Toowoomba and Oakey--health concerns, financial concerns, emotional concerns; concerns these communities did not have several weeks ago.

On Friday, 18 February I attended the first community meeting of the Toowoomba Coal Mine Action Group at the Gowrie Junction community hall. Approximately 700 people attended this meeting--loudly and clearly expressing their disgust with the then minister. My office has received countless phone calls and emails and, to date, 543 letters from residents and concerned citizens registering their objection to the proposed mine.

I add my support to the motion moved by the shadow minister for mines and energy, natural resources and water for the newly appointed minister for mines to immediately make the necessary legislative changes to immediately revoke exploration permit 1979 and to remove any suggestion that a mine could ever be established at this site. Already negative impacts have been experienced on property valuations for residents in Gowrie Junction, Kingsthorpe and adjacent communities. This is attributed to the issuing of exploration permit 1979. Making legislative changes to revoke exploration permit 1979 would provide residents within the EP area with the security that the investment they have made in their homes, properties and businesses will be safe.

I endorse the motion calling for the enforcement of the provisions of section 147A of the Mineral Resources Act to ensure that all of the exploration permits covering the Felton Valley and other areas of prime agricultural land are not renewed. Minister, you have the opportunity to also stop that mine at Felton by not renewing those permits.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member will address his comments through the chair.

Mr HOPPER: Mr Speaker, I apologise for that. This would provide landholders and communities in the region with some much needed security--security that has been taken away from them for a long time--and allow them to be free from the threat of any unsuitable mining development in their region so that they can progress and invest in their businesses with certainly. They cannot sell their farms even if they want to.

I support the motion to ensure that no more exploration permits or other mining authorities are issued and, furthermore, that no existing permits or other mining authorities are renewed for the Darling Downs region until a statutory regional plan is established. The sustainability and viability of much of the cropping area of the Darling Downs is dependent upon landholders having the ability to continue to invest in the future of their business and their family without the threat of further exploration permits being issued over their highly productive land.

I endorse the motion calling for the establishment of statutory legal protection of prime agricultural land and separation distances between the resource industry authorities and urban areas. The protection of our prime agricultural land resource is essential to the ongoing successful production of food and fibre on the Darling Downs and to providing food security for Queensland. Any industry that is allowed to negatively impact upon the business or lifestyle of other entities will not be supported by the LNP.

I must say that this amendment before the House is nothing but a wet lettuce amendment. I look forward to the contribution of the member for Toowoomba North. I look forward to your contribution tonight, because the 700 people who attended that meeting missed you that night. They would have loved to have you there to stand up and explain what is happening to their future, as I did.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Direct your comments through the chair.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Agriculture, Food and Regional Economies) (6.01 pm): Historically, mining and agriculture have been the cornerstone of the Queensland economy and we need to continue to recognise the importance of both sectors, even when they compete for the same land. We recognise that the best cropping land, defined as strategic cropping land, is a finite resource that must be conserved and managed for the longer term.

XML.Hansard-Body: Queensland has only a very small area of the best quality agricultural soil resources. This is typically represented by the iconic deep black soils of the eastern Darling Downs. This quality agricultural land is critical to Queensland’s food value chain, which is worth $18.7 billion and employs approximately 267,000 Queenslanders. Agriculture is particularly vital to the economy of rural and regional Queensland, and we want to ensure it grows so that the industry will be worth approximately $34 billion by 2020.

This is why we are managing competing land uses--such as agriculture, mining and urban development--to ensure balanced outcomes for the benefit of all Queenslanders. The government will conserve and manage our best cropping land for the longer term. This does not mean that all farming land will be locked up and not available for other use. We want to ensure that land use competition is managed in a way that enables agriculture, mining and urban development to co-exist for the long term. Where land use competition exists, we want to ensure the best possible outcomes for producers in dealing with mining or urban development.

It is understandable that people have concerns about the potential rapid growth of mining and what that means to them and the environment. The proposed strategic cropping land legislation will provide a level of protection for agricultural producers not seen anywhere else in Australia, if not the world. In fact, the Liberal-National coalition in New South Wales has lifted our policy and taken it to the election, so we must be getting some things right.

I want to highlight a couple of things. Of all the exploration permits which have been issued, only one per cent have a mining lease issued over them. Under the law, even with an exploration permit exploration cannot happen near homes, churches, community facilities, bore wells or permanent stockyards. To go from an exploration permit to a mine is a long process.
Mr Hopper interjected.

Mr MULHERIN: I am talking about assessing the project against legislation like the Environmental Protection Act, the Nature Conservation Act and the Vegetation Management Act, if it applies. The important thing is that there will be several chances for public input along the way and it may even require Commonwealth government approval.

Any mining application that does not uphold the strictest environmental standards will not get the go-ahead. Once again, the LNP members have proved that they are a divided rabble with no leadership. We have seen in this parliament time and time again how LNP members have opposed the establishment of the Environmental Protection Agency, the Environmental Protection Act, the Nature Conservation Act and the Vegetation Management Act.
