It increases penalties for failure to report and for giving false information from a maximum of two years imprisonment and 150 penalty units to a maximum of five years imprisonment and 300 penalty units. I will conclude shortly, because I know other members from our side of the House wish to speak. The reality is that the opposition does not hold the floor on this issue. This sickens each and every one of us. We will not be attacked because opposition members think that they are the guardians of the morals of this House. As I said, the reality is that we deal with the mundane, the mechanical and the sickening. In reality, none of us has the right to suggest that we are not all concerned about our children, our children’s children and their future.

Ms GRACE (Brisbane Central--ALP) (8.46 pm): I rise to support the government’s Child Protection (Offender Reporting) and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 and to oppose the opposition amendment bill. If one had been listening to the contributions of the member for Kawana and the member for Noosa, one might think that they had come in here with a comprehensive amendment bill that they had really thought through. One might think that they had thought about national consistency and how to better protect children. However, they have introduced an amendment bill that contains two minor amendments that, in reality, do absolutely nothing.
Mr Elmes: So what does yours do?
Ms GRACE: I will tell you what ours does. I take that interjection. If you had only taken the time to read--
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms O’Neill): Order! You will address your comments through the chair.

Ms GRACE: I will address my comments through the chair. If they had taken the time to actually read our bill and understand its contents, they would know how their bill is completely empty of any proper policy to protect children in this state. Their bill contains absolutely nothing when compared with the government’s bill. It is a disgrace that Laurel and Hardy over there can stand up and make outlandish comments about how this government’s bill does not adequately protect children and that the only saviour of children in this state was a government that, despite being in power for 32 years, never introduced such a bill. It was a Labor Party that first introduced an offenders’ register. So what if, in April, they introduced an inadequate amendment bill? After extensive consultation, having looked at the recommendations of the committees that provided the reports, this government has brought in a much more balanced and comprehensive amendment bill that will actually do something to protect children in this state. In this House nothing gnaws at you more than hearing the high moral ground being taken by members opposite, as if members on this side of the House do not care about children. We take great offence at that. That kind of talk should stop, because nobody in this House owns the defence of children in this country. It is absolutely pathetic and, honestly, members on that side of the House lose respect by saying that.

I return to the bill and I will address my comments through the chair. There are two minor amendments to the requirements to report to police. One of them is about offenders reporting not every 12 months, but every three months. Members opposite ignore all the stuff that is contained in this bill, and I know a number of speakers will go through it. Let me remind the House once again that it was a Labor government that introduced into Queensland some of the toughest sex offender laws in this nation--this government. The opposition has brought in a piddling amendment bill so that somehow it can now claim the moral ground. It is offensive and ridiculous and I am just about to point out how ridiculous it is.

This bill requires extensive reporting now, with a number of changes incorporated in this legislation. It brings about consistency not only in Queensland but throughout Australia. It has taken on board the recommendations of a number of committees that have reported. It takes into account the vulnerable nature of the children. Rather than prolong the time limit in which these offenders are to report when they have had three days of contact with children--not necessarily consecutively--they have to report not in three months as the opposition bill says, but within 24 hours. That is the difference between our bill and the opposition’s. Under the opposition bill, offenders would only have to report every three months. Our bill requires that, if they are in contact with a child, the reporting time is to be reduced from 28 to seven days. In one week they have to report--
Mr Elmes: What about just the normal reporting process?
Ms GRACE: Yours still maintains it at three months.
Mr Elmes: Every 12 months.
Ms GRACE: So yours is inadequate.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms O’Neill): Order! I ask the member for Noosa to cease interjecting and for both of you to talk through the chair.

Ms GRACE: In relation to contact with a child in any one day, once that reaches three days, they have 24 hours in which to report it. Members opposite come in here with a provision for contact every three months and claim that theirs is going to protect children. It is utter rubbish and we all know it.

The government bill goes even further. The bill requires the reporting of telephone carriage services, internet service providers, email address and other electronic identifiers used or intended to be used by a reportable offender. That is not contained in the opposition’s bill. The LNP does not even address the issue. This overcomes a significant deficiency in the existing legislation that we have identified--and the LNP has not--whereby such devices are used to facilitate the kinds of crimes committed by child sex offenders. There is not a word of it in their amendment bill; it is very strong in ours. The obligation for reportable offenders to provide these particular details will also assist in deterring reportable offenders from accessing child exploitation material and engaging in predatory behaviour such as grooming via the internet. I repeat once again that it is not included in their bill. A failure to comply with reporting obligations--

Mr ELMES: I rise to a point of order. I detailed, point by point, through my presentation the provisions that are in the government’s bill that we welcomed and we will support. To have the member for Brisbane Central casting over that old ground is just not acceptable. I take offence at it.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: There is no point of order.

Ms GRACE: A failure to comply with these reporting obligations will result in an offence committed under section 50 of the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004, the penalties for which have been significantly increased.

This government has left no stone unturned in identifying the ways that a reportable offender might communicate with potential victims to commit offences. The bill amends the existing legislation to require the offender to provide details of any carriage service, internet service provider or carriage service provider within the meaning of the Telecommunications Act 1997--very extensive in modern-day social media techniques. Reportable offenders will be required to provide details of the type of any internet connection used including whether the connection is a wireless, broadband, ADSL or dial-up connection and details of any internet user names, instant messaging user names, chat room user names or any other user name intended to be used by the offender through the internet or other electronic communication services. It covers all grounds.

The bill also requires reportable offenders to present valid passports--another issue which has been ignored by the opposition--when reporting personal details and, subsequently, when returning from travel outside Australia along with any travel documents in their possession. This measure is for verification of reported travel and deters child sex tourism while also supporting the investigation of it.

Our bill is comprehensive. There are many other areas that it covers. It increases the penalties from a maximum of two years to five years. It expands the matters about which offenders need to report. It tightens the reporting time frames related to completing initial reports in circumstances where an offender genuinely resides or has an unsupervised contact with a child. It even requires offenders to provide DNA samples. It expands the range of offences which will require reporting and it introduces provisions to protect special needs offenders. This is a far more comprehensive amendment bill than the opposition’s bill. I fully support and congratulate the minister on its introduction. I support our bill and claim that the LNP bill is glaringly lacking the necessary amendments to make children in this state safe and also in Australia. I commend the government bill to the House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Nanango--Ind) (8.55 pm): I rise to speak to both bills. Both of these bills have been brought into the House to protect children. Both of these bills can complement each other. There is no need for this attack from both sides of the House on the other because we are all very passionate about the safety of our children. I am seriously sick to the stomach that the members who spoke before me carry on like this over the most important things in our society--the children. They are both on the same court and yet they cannot play together. Just grow up and get on with it. They are both aiming for the same thing. The bills complement each other. Yes, the opposition bill does have glaring omissions; the government’s bill fills them in. Get on with it. They are working to protect our children.

XML.Hansard-Body: I have let all honourable members know in no uncertain terms what I think of child sexual offenders and my opinion has not changed. I do not often get very angry in this place, but when it comes to this subject and the absolute stupidity of such a conflict, when both sides are working together to try to belittle the other side, it just does not cut any ice. It does not cut any ice with anyone else, either. This is the kind of bill that should be going to the committee that we were talking about today. We would get good ideas from both sides of this House. We would make it a workable thing or we would work our guts out to make it work and protect the children. Yet here in this adversarial arena honourable members are playing pure politics and it makes me really, really sick.

As I said before, the object of these two bills is to protect the children. There is not an MP in here who does not feel for the children, who does not relate to the children and what they would be going through. There is not one person here who would condone a sexual offence against a child. It is just so sad that members carry on like pork chops. Quite frankly, I agree with both of the members who spoke before me.

Sexual offenders are devious and opportunistic, as was said earlier. It is a despicable crime to commit upon a child. I do not agree with a lot of the views of the Labor Party. Its members seem to have a lot more faith in sexual offenders’ behaviour than I do. They are required to report after 24 hours.
Ms Struthers: Faith in behaviour?

Mrs PRATT: Maybe I worded that incorrectly. However, members opposite have a lot more faith in the fact that they will comply with regulations in the legislation. I do not. I do not think they will comply. If they can get away without reporting they will have a go. Those members have already said they are devious and despicable, which they are. These types of offenders will be sorry if they are caught because they did not report, but I do not have faith that they will take much notice of the legislation.
Ms Grace interjected.

Mrs PRATT: It is not wasting the member’s time. However, she has to recognise the reality that we are dealing with perverted people, and perverted people are not law-abiding people. Those who are not law-abiding people do not really give a stuff whether there is a law or not; they just go out and break it. Let us get realistic here. We are dealing with people who really do not give a toss what we think. They only care about what they care about and that is the next offence against a child. They are adults and we are protecting the children. It is the children who are the victims, not the predator. That is why I can never quite get my head around this.

Every time I have to speak about child sex offenders my heart races. It is an involuntary thing because I know a bit about it. It is not pleasant. If anyone thinks these individuals--these animals--are going to take a bit of notice of a piece of paper, well, believe me, they are wrong. If it is true that one in three sex offenders breaches their reporting requirements then there has to be a change. It is not right. It does not matter if we have to change the law to protect our children every single day that we are in this chamber. It does not matter if the opposition, the Independents, The Queensland Party or Labor brings in legislation. It does not matter. We should just do it, because every time we make a change hopefully one more child is protected from a predator. I have hopefully let members know how I feel about this. I feel very strongly about it. Both parties have a great idea, so let us just get on with it and pass both bills.
Debate, on motion of Mrs Pratt, adjourned.
Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (9.01 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House do now adjourn.

Hansard-Body.A: (Coomera--LNP) (9.01 pm): I refer to the Premier’s answer to a question without notice asked this morning. The question was--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Can the Premier update the House on the significant increases in the uptake of solar energy throughout Queensland?
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: In her answer the Premier said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Today, we are at 375 megawatts, with an astounding 63,000 solar PV systems on Queensland roofs.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: She went on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We put in place a Solar Bonus Scheme, where people who are generating power from their own roofs can actually be paid for the excess that goes back into the grid and there are many Queenslanders who are now receiving the benefit of that.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Let me tell you who is not benefiting from those rebates: people in residential parks. A letter I received from one of my constituents states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The current Solar Bonus Scheme has allowed us to “fall through the cracks” because we don’t export to the Qld Grid but to our Park Owners (PO) private grid. As a result we are left to negotiate with our own individual PO’s--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: park owners--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: within the laws of the Manufactured Homes Act. This is proving to be very unsatisfactory with varying agreements being negotiated with PO’s ... that will not necessarily apply to any other residential parks.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: You can assist by making parliament aware of the anomalies in our situation and help to remove this unfairness because of where we live. We are not asking to earn large amounts for our exports like suburbia can achieve, only to reduce our power bills by receiving a fair price for them, and that isn’t zero! After all, the PO--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: park owner--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: is currently onselling our exports to other residents for the same price charged for their normal usage provided by him, and that equals 100% profit. Please give this issue your urgent attention.
XML.Hansard-Body: Under the Manufactured Homes (Residential Parks) Amendment Bill 2010, section 99A, ‘Separate charge by park owner not to be more than cost of supply for use of utility’, clearly states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: (2) The park owner must not charge the home owner an amount for the use of a utility that is more than the amount charged by the relevant supply authority for the quantity of the service supplied to, or used at, the site.
Maximum penalty--20 penalty units.
XML.Hansard-Body: The explanatory notes state that this section clarifies that park owners must not charge homeowners more than the actual cost of providing a utility service. I call on the Premier to look at this growing group in our community--that is, homeowners in residential parks--who believe they are falling through the cracks and being done over by unscrupulous park owners.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: State Archives Exhibition, Top 150: Documenting Queensland ; Natural Disasters
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms van LITSENBURG (Redcliffe--ALP) (9.04 pm): Last week the State Archives exhibition Top 150: Documenting Queensland opened at our local museum. This exhibition includes photos, documents, maps and diaries from the Queensland State Archives from separation in 1859, including documents signed by Sir George Bowen and Sir Samuel Griffith. There are also documents from Anderson Dawson, the first elected Labor leader in the world; Dame Nellie Melba’s marriage certificate; and a note from Sir Charles Kingsford Smith. There are also documents from champion shearer Jackie Howe and from suffragette Emma Miller as we are celebrating 100 years of International Women’s Day. And of course there are documents relating to Expo and the Commonwealth Games.

These Queensland icons are an important part of our history and who we are today. But earlier in the year we lived through a series of history-making natural disasters--disasters that will, like the 1974 floods, be an even stronger landmark in Queensland’s history, a history that will sculpt the bones of the Queensland we will be in the future. Strong in our memories and the stories that we pass on to our children and their children will be those of the mud army and how those committed volunteers brought hope to many victims and also the generosity of Queenslanders who have donated to the Premier’s disaster appeal. A couple of weeks ago my local Redcliffe RSL put on a concert featuring a variety of musicians, including headliners Wickety Wak, after which president Gary Nolan presented me with a $15,000 cheque for the Premier’s disaster fund.

Another strong feature of these historic natural disasters has been the strong, effective leadership of the Queensland Premier. Queenslanders continue to talk about her leadership during this terrible time. Her management of these disasters in the preparation time, during the disasters and in the clean-up will also go down in history, and her work will become a benchmark for how other leaders will manage any disasters in the future. This is what good government is all about, and that is what Queenslanders expect from their Premier and the Queensland Labor government.

Hansard-Body.A: (Buderim--LNP) (9.07 pm): Here we go again: another Labor tax. Straight on the back of the flood levy, the Labor Prime Minister has announced that there will be a carbon tax. Yes, the federal Labor government is going to turn every power point and light switch into a branch of the taxation department. And for what? It has nothing to do with climate change, which we all know is real. The climate has been constantly changing for millions of years, and always will. Long before there were power stations and petrol refineries, the climate changed. No. We know why we are going to have a carbon tax. Bob Brown told us a couple of Sundays ago on TV. He said that the Prime Minister is following through on a promise made in negotiations to form a minority government. As I said, it has nothing to do with climate change and everything to do with the Primer Minister staying in government.

XML.Hansard-Body: Also, the carbon tax is about trying to get back some of the voters Labor lost to the Greens in the federal election. I wish to quote the Prime Minister. Days before the federal election in August the Prime Minister said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There will be no carbon tax under the government I lead.
XML.Hansard-Body: Technically, I suppose the Prime Minister’s statement is correct, because Julia Gillard is not really running the government; Bob Brown is. The loonies from the Greens are running the show in Canberra.

Just have a look at what has happened over the flood levy. The Prime Minister said that $1.8 billion would be found in the budget as part of reconstruction funding. But that would have meant canning a couple of the dodgy green promises made by the PM during the election campaign, like cash for clunkers. So Bob Brown and co. said to the Prime Minister, ‘We’ll just see about that.’ In order to get the Greens on-side and get the flood levy through the parliament, the Prime Minister has had to reinstate a heap of dodgy promises worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
What about Wayne Swan, the federal Treasurer from Queensland? When asked about a carbon tax, he said on Meet the Press six days before the election--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... what we rejected is this hysterical allegation that somehow we are moving towards a carbon tax.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Three days before that, Mr Swan said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We have made our position very clear. We have ruled it out.
XML.Hansard-Body: It was reported on 24 February, ‘Queensland Premier Anna Bligh supported the carbon tax announcement.’ It is likely that electricity will go up by $300 per year, petrol will go up by at least 6c per litre and the Premier thinks a carbon tax is great. I have said it before and I will say it again: when the people of Queensland go to the ballot box at the next state election they should take their electricity bills and their fuels bills along with them and use them as their how-to-vote card. I understand the people of New South Wales will be going to the polls on 26 March. I think that could be a bloodbath. I am pretty sure the people are going to take their power bills and their fuel bills along with them and are going to use them as their how-to-vote card. I think that how-to-vote card is going to say, ‘We are not voting for Labor.’
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Woodridge State High School, Awards Ceremony
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mrs SCOTT (Woodridge--ALP)
(9.10 pm): Giving recognition to students for their effort and improvement is so important, and nowhere more important than in schools such as Woodridge State High School where hundreds of students who may speak two or even up to five languages other than English come from many lands, some of which are wracked by war, many of them having lived for years in refugee camps and witnessed scenes no child should ever have to be exposed to. Many have no English language at all and some have had no schooling or very little.

It was my pleasure recently to attend their biannual honours ceremony for second semester 2010. Merit, attendance and improvement awards were granted to students from communities such as the Chin and the Karen from Burma; Burundi, Somalia, Sudan from Africa; others from Afghanistan, Iraq, Thailand, Laos and many more; and, of course, our own Indigenous students and those from the Pacific Islands and New Zealand. Sprinkled throughout the student body are our home-grown Aussie students.

Of great interest to me were the final honours awards. These were presented to students who had increased their achievement level in all subjects by a whole grade--a white bar for their first award, a green bar for their second award and a purple bar for those who had for a third time increased their level of accomplishment. I later spoke to some of these honour students and found a number of them had been in Australia for two years or less.

Several days later I visited the Intensive Learning Support Centre, which is housed in two new demountables joined by a timber deck with shade cover. Ms Amy Sullivan, year coordinator, and Ms Pat Dore, acting head of the intensive learning support and English second language departments, explained their programs and introduced me to each class. With almost 100 students in the ILS class and 86 in the ESL class, this area is a hive of activity. Some of the students read to me and one class sang the national anthem beautifully.

When we consider the script of a language such as Thai and the different sounds within the language, many of these students have to learn a whole new change in how they use their tongue and facial muscles as well as a new alphabet and sounds--no easy task. With six teachers in ILS and five teachers in ESL plus aides and volunteers, this is a very rewarding and happy place to teach.

Apart from language, writing, reading, numerics, many practical skills are taught such as cooking, computing, beach safety and swimming, how to use public transport and, as funds allow, visits to places of interest. Woodridge State High School is a mini United Nations and students are so privileged to have as friends students of many lands. I congratulate Mr John Norfolk, his deputies and staff for the exceptional school this has become--connected to every world with opportunity for all.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP)
(9.13 pm): Times are tough, there is no doubt about it. But it has come to my attention that there is a small group of families in my electorate and from across the Sunshine Coast that are doing it far tougher than the rest of us. Late last year I was contacted by three families from Glass House. Each of these families has the challenging but rewarding responsibility of raising a young person with a disability.

Jude and David Mannix’s son Levi is typical of these young people. I had the opportunity to meet Levi last week. He is a great kid. We shared stories of shaving mishaps. Until the age of 18 Levi received wonderful care through the education system. He attended a Sunshine Coast special school and did so five days a week--like any kid his age. The education was not only a positive for Levi but for his parents who could use the respite offered by the schooling to pursue careers and earn the wages required to continue caring for Levi.

But all that changed when Levi graduated, as it did for the children of the other families. Suddenly their parents had to apply for post school funding through Disability Services Queensland. After talking up their children’s progress for the previous 12 years, parents like Jude and David had to talk down Levi’s abilities. They had to prove, again, Levi’s disability in the hope of securing some post school funding. The application process was distressing and lengthy, and in the case of all of these families ultimately unsuccessful.

So in one fell swoop Levi has gone from five days a week support through the education system to zero support through the disability system. His disability pension of less than $10,000 per year does not even offset the lost income his parents have incurred through now having to care for him full time.

Levi had hoped to attend a life skills and Get Set for Work program offered through a local disability service provider, Compass in Palmwoods. The program is offered three days a week at a cost of $15,000 per participant per year. So rather than dash his hopes, Jude and David are covering the cost out of their own pockets. Not all families with a young disabled adult are so fortunate.

The really distressing element to this story is that when I wrote to the disability minister I was told the investment in post school funding would be increasing through budget announcements later in the year, but that it would not be applied retrospectively. So families like the Mannix family would continue to miss out. It is distressing because all these families are looking for is $15,000 per year. For the 24 young people who graduated from special schools on the coast last year that would amount to a paltry $360,000. When we consider this government has wasted $400 million on a pipeline to nowhere, our heart breaks.

Even Labor’s basket case, New South Wales, has got this one right. It offers banded community participation funding ranging from $21,000 for young people with moderate disability needs up to $54,000 for exceptional needs. They also offer $18,000 for transition to work programs. Minister, I know you are new to the position; here is an opportunity to get some runs on the board.

Mr WENDT (Ipswich West--ALP)
(9.16 pm): I wanted to advise the House tonight of some recent events in my electorate, particularly involving the BSA, the Building Services Authority. It has done a fantastic job after the floods that affected my whole electorate. We have had two BSA sessions in my electorate--one at Fernvale and one at Karalee last Monday night. These sessions are run by BSA staff. They also involved staff from Master Electricians, Workplace Health and Safety Queensland, the Electrical Safety Office and many others.

They talked about things like when repair work should commence; choosing contractors and the importance of these contractors to be licensed; the importance of homeowners signing contracts and paying home warranty insurance so they are covered by the BSA; the BSA’s new natural disaster repairs contract, which I found very interesting; drying requirements in relation to specific building elements--and that is very interesting when we consider that some of the wood in houses that were submerged six weeks ago is still not really ready to be sheeted--timber framing, wood products, lining and cladding issues; floor and wall furnishings and products; septic tanks and effluent systems. I found it remarkable to learn that some of the septic systems in my area are not covered correctly and certainly need to be redone. They also talked about electric and gas installations. Building planning and approval and plumbing approvals were talked about by council staff who were present on the night. The types of construction and the availability of products for kitchens and wet areas was also discussed.

People who contributed to these events were Lyn Shanahan, Sharon Hopkins, Nick Davies, Doug Sparkes, Dave Benson and Michael Chesterman from the BSA; Peter Steven from Workplace Health and Safety Queensland; David Hine from the Master Electricians; and Graham Nyman and Casey Kendrick-Ward from the Electrical Safety Office. The electrical people provided expertise in relation to trying to rewire houses and when it is safe to do so.

On the night I also made sure that we had some people along who were about to provide other types of support, particularly legal aid support. Loretta Kreet from Legal Aid was able to provide advice in relation to insurance issues, specifically those issues where people were not responded to in the correct fashion by insurance companies. We also had Department of Communities staff from the recovery centre who were there to help individuals affected by floods complete forms and explain them to them. Our counsellors from Lifeline were also there. These counsellors have been around for a long time now. With the communities staff they have been doing a fabulous job. The minister visited Ipswich recently and we spoke to some of the people involved, particularly with the Salvation Army.

I take my hat off to all of these people. Without these people and the support of the government, people in my electorate would not be where they are. I know that a lot of them would like to be back to where they were before the floods, but, unfortunately, that will not be able to happen at this point. I also noticed yesterday the Premier’s announcement of further flood assistance, which I think is outstanding. I am sure that people really do appreciate that.

Hansard-Body.A: (Cleveland--LNP) (9.19 pm): The rising price of water in the electorate of Cleveland and the broader Redlands has become a major concern to the rate-paying population. The ongoing issue stems from the fact that Redlands water, which once was cheap, is now on a pathway to more than double over the next seven years under this Labor government’s mismanagement. This government has proven, in its poor water management policies alone, that it is not worthy of another term in office. Four years ago, Premier Bligh claimed that she would ensure water was ‘not priced beyond the reach of ordinary Queenslanders’. Today it is clear that she has failed to live up to that promise. Water has become another Labor broken promise.

XML.Hansard-Body: The problem in the Redlands is exacerbated because Redlanders remember what low-price water was like, and they have a good memory. Previous Redland councils planned well for the future water needs of the area. Redlands had control of its precious water seized, however, by the Labor government, and Redlanders have watched as this government has not done well with it and attempted to cut and run from its responsibility, leaving behind a price path that Redland residents would never have dreamed of.

The most recent manifestation of Labor failure to manage water is the utility Allconnex. Allconnex was never welcomed from the beginning in Cleveland and the Redlands by the general population. It was tolerated by some in the hope that it could not be as bad as something directly run by this incompetent government. However, Allconnex to date has not turned out to be such a good deal for Redland ratepayers. The Redlands council holds only a 10 per cent equity in Allconnex, and this is far too low. It should have been somewhere around 15 per cent.

Allconnex has not responded well to local concerns, and recent inconsiderate comments from Allconnex have further infuriated local residents. Something needs to be done to deal with this. Allconnex is a state government creation and the government cannot just wash its hands of responsibility. A major review of Allconnex operations is required before the people of Redlands will be happy. In fact, many in the Redlands are calling for it to be scrapped and for water management to again be placed under council control.

The LNP has committed to policies that drive state bulk water prices down. The Leader of the Opposition, John-Paul Langbroek, has committed the LNP to a policy of capping increases in the bulk water price to CPI. We will also thin out Labor’s fat cat water bureaucracy. The LNP has also committed to preventing councils from price gouging water. The Leader of the Opposition introduced a policy to prevent price gouging and in recent days the Premier has been dragged into supporting our policy.

Residents are so angry at this government that they are deciding to do something about it. Ordinary citizens like Rose Doyle have become active locally by launching petitions. I have sponsored this petition as an e-petition in the Queensland parliament to bring down the cost of water. I commend the e-petition to the Queensland public, particularly the people of Cleveland and the Redlands.

Hansard-Body.A: (Southport--ALP) (9.22 pm): On Tuesday of last week, I represented the Minister for Employment, Skills and Mining, Stirling Hinchliffe, at the celebration of the achievements of 23 people who graduated with qualifications in two fields: 12 graduated with a Certificate III in Children’s Services and 11 graduated with a Certificate III in Aged Care. Pretty soon they will probably be looking after me!

XML.Hansard-Body: Multicultural Communities Council Gold Coast partnered with Training Tailor Made to deliver these Productivity Places Program courses. Whilst the primary target group was intended to be people from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds, this group were in fact from highly disadvantaged backgrounds. The aim of the project was to help meet the demands for assistants in nursing, aged-care workers and children’s service workers on the Gold Coast, with certificate III being the entry level qualification for these sectors. All participants undertook appropriate vocational placements at local aged-care and child-care facilities in addition to the classroom training.

There are many employment opportunities in child care and aged care on the Gold Coast, and that is why the state government has provided funding of $192,000 to the Multicultural Communities Council. That means that they will be able to help 60 job seekers complete accredited training in aged care, children’s services or disability services.

Of the 23 graduates, over half had already found a job. This Productivity Places Program is about making sure Queenslanders have the best chance possible of finding a job and providing the training to make that happen. Many of the participants have overcome health, domestic, financial and transport issues to complete and graduate from these programs. The feedback from the vocational placement organisations was very positive, and the employment outcomes already achieved are indicative of the success of the program and the hard work put in by the participants.

I would like to thank the 23 graduates and participants in this program; DEEDI regional officer Roxanne Scott; Tony and Pauline Luxford and Dianne Bailey from Training Tailor Made; Norm Steere, the executive manager of Multicultural Communities Council Gold Coast; and also other board members who were in attendance at the presentation, Eric Markham, Anne Nides, Senlie Tong and Nao Hirano.

Hansard-Body.A: (Callide--LNP) (9.24 pm): There has for many years been a recognition that water allocations held by landholders in the Callide Valley are much larger than what the system can sustainably supply. However, proposals in the draft Fitzroy River plan have caused widespread community concern in the area. The issue of water allocations is always an emotional and highly charged one, as access to water is the very basis of many rural farming businesses, and urban and industrial supplies are very important. However, in all systems, having physical access to water is a very different thing to having a water allocation, and in the Callide Valley especially the two things are a long way apart and mean very different things.

XML.Hansard-Body: It has become obvious to most local people that the government’s current proposal for reform to the allocations is an inadequate way to address the issue and has the potential to create significant injustices if it is adopted in its current form. I urge the new minister and the department to consult closely with local water users, who understand the system better than anyone else. Unfortunately, the public debate has been too much influenced so far by a small number of people who do not have allocations in the system and are inflaming the issue with nonsensical conspiracy theories about Callide Valley water being sold on some worldwide water market in the new world order. I hope the minister and her department can ignore all of that nonsense and ensure that any change is focused firmly on ensuring a better deal for the genuine irrigators and water users in the system and a better future for the Callide Valley community.

There is a huge difference between water allocation holders within the benefited area who must pay the part A allocation price and those outside that area who do not pay anything at all. There are a number of sleeper licences where no development has ever occurred and a number of dozer licences where irrigation has ceased for a range of reasons. That all adds up to a very complex situation that will not be solved by any simplistic solution. It has been made more complex by the long dry spell that has seen very little recharge to the system for many years, with the Callide Dam at critically low levels. Now, however, the dam is full and the recent floods have been a welcome boost to water levels, but the extent to which the water levels will recover throughout the valley is still unknown. It may well be that this situation is too difficult to resolve and that the best approach may be to just leave it alone, but I believe that decision priority needs to be given to the genuine irrigators whose businesses make up a valuable part of the local economy.

Whether the government decides to proceed or leave the allocations as they are and manage the actual use through announced allocations, it needs to consider first and foremost the impacts of its decision on the genuine water users, the genuine irrigators, not the people from outside the area who are making lots of noise about things they do not understand. I will work closely with the new minister and her departmental officials to ensure the views of those genuine water users are foremost and that the best outcome is achieved for their future.

Hansard-Body.A: (Everton--ALP) (9.27 pm): Tackling traffic congestion is one of my biggest priorities as a local member. It is a big issue for my constituents, and as a father I know that every minute spent in traffic is a minute not spent with our families. The electorate I represent is one of many that faces the challenges of dealing with the population growth we continue to see in South-East Queensland. As more people settle in the north-west of Brisbane and in the South Pine area, we see more traffic on the roads.

XML.Hansard-Body: One of the worst areas for congestion in my electorate is the intersection of Stafford Road and South Pine Road at Everton Park. Commuters regularly face long delays at this intersection, and anyone who has travelled through that intersection will understand that their frustration is only heightened by the fact that they have to stare at a billboard of me, since my electorate office is located at this very intersection. For the last 12 months I have been lobbying ministers to improve this intersection.

I was pleased that, after a deputation at the Albany Creek community cabinet in December, the Premier insisted the Department of Transport and Main Roads bring forward planning work on how this intersection could be improved. I will obviously continue lobbying to improve this intersection, but something else has arisen that threatens to make the congestion there even worse. Woolworths owns a massive site on one corner of the intersection. It is the site of its former northside distribution centre and Woolworths is currently applying to the Brisbane City Council to redevelop the site into a supermarket, specialty stores, a hardware superstore and 170 apartments.

My consultation with Everton Park residents has told me that most residents support some form of development on that site. That is not surprising, as it is currently an eyesore, with the grass regularly overgrown and graffiti all over the derelict buildings on site. However, most people in the area share my concern that the development will make the existing congestion even worse. There is no doubt that a development of this size and nature will attract a huge amount of traffic seven days a week. I think the council should make its approval of Woolworths’ development application conditional on Woolworths funding the improvements to the South Pine Road-Stafford Road intersection, or at least make a substantial contribution towards it. I have no problem with Woolworths making money out of redeveloping its site, but the least it can do is put its hand in its own pocket and contribute to improving traffic in the area.

Recently, I lodged a submission with the council outlining my position. As part of that, I requested local residents to sign letters demanding that Woolworths fund the improvement of this intersection. I have been overwhelmed with the response. Already I have received back hundreds of letters supporting my position.

I will keep working hard to improve traffic congestion at Everton Park and I will certainly keep working hard to make sure that Woolworths pays its fair share and to make sure that we make this terrible bottleneck better for local commuters.
Question put--That the House do now adjourn.
Motion agreed to.
The House adjourned at 9.31 pm.
